# Project File Hierarchy

- `00_User Data/Domains/time_domain.json`
- `01_User Feature Requests/calendar_view_v2.md`
- `02_System Layers/orchestration_layer.md`
- `02_System Layers/ux_layer.md`
- `03_Core Components/calendar_view.md`
- `03_Core Components/calendar_view.py`
- `04_Solution Architecture Options/calendar_ui_comparison.md`
- `05_Version Release Plan/v1.0/diff_summary.md`
- `05_Version Release Plan/v1.0/plan.md`
- `05_Version Release Plan/v1.0/release_notes.md`
- `97_Build Configs/build_config.yaml`
- `97_Build Configs/github-actions.yml`
- `98_User Tutorials/how_to_use_calendar_view.md`
- `99_Meta Processes/dev_workflow.md`
- `99_Meta Processes/how_to_add_a_feature_block.md`
- `99_Meta Processes/prompting_guidelines.md`
- `README.md`

# Life Planner Project

Welcome to the Life Planner. Here's how the project is structured:

- `00_User Data/`: Domain-specific data
- `01_User Feature Requests/`: Internal backlog
- `02_System Layers/`: UX, logic, orchestration
- `03_Core Components/`: Final specs and source code
- `04_Solution Architecture Options/`: Trade studies and decisions
- `05_Version Release Plan/`: Milestone tracking and release notes
- `97_Build Configs/`: CI/CD and automation scripts
- `98_User Tutorials/`: User-facing how-tos and validation tests
- `99_Meta Processes/`: Development workflows and conventions

This is your new *vault*.

Make a note of something, [[create a link]], or try [the Importer](https://help.obsidian.md/Plugins/Importer)!

When you're ready, delete this note and make the vault your own.

For example -> 
- Human-readable task checklists, for printing, are maintained.
- There is some sort of a code change -> check list has changed.
- If User has printed the checklists out, their physical copy is now lagging behind the virtual copy.
	- This may not be an issue if checklists are primarily used on ipad or something.

Some text describing the first image: ```mermaid graph TD; A --> B; A --> C; B --> D; C --> D; ``` Some text describing the second diagram. ```mermaid sequenceDiagram Alice ->> Bob: Hello Bob, how are you? Bob-->>John: How about you John? Bob--x Alice: I am good thanks! Bob-x John: I am good thanks! Note right of John: Bob thinks a long
long time, so long
that the text does
not fit on a row. Bob-->Alice: Checking with John... Alice->John: Yes... John, how are you? ```

# Prompting Guidelines

How to structure prompts for GPT.

Example ChatGPT Integration Prompt:

~~~ Markdown
#project: life_planner
#feature: calendar_view_v2
#goal: implement this feature request using the orchestrated UX model
#context_files:
  - 00_User Data/Domains/time_domain.md
  - 02_System Layers/ux_layer.md
  - 03_Core Components/scheduling_logic.md

Please propose code and structure for the new calendar view interface. Make it extensible to support recurrence and multiple domains.
~~~

# Prompt Template
~~~
#project: life_planner
#feature: calendar_view_v2
#goal: implement the feature as described in the linked request

## Provided Context
- 00_User Data/Domains/
- 02_System Layers/ux_layer.md
- 02_System Layers/orchestration_layer.md
- 03_Core Components/

## Task
Based on the user request in `feature_request.md`, design the implementation strategy and propose source code modules and architectural placement. Prioritize modularity and clarity.

## Output Format
- Summary of interpretation
- Key design decisions
- Folder(s) or module(s) to be created
- Initial code or scaffolding
~~~
Takes the "happy path" testing from the Architect and comes up with edge cases to test for as well.

Role: Technical Writer
Inputs: Detailed Developer User Stories
Outputs: Makes changes to flowcharts and sequence diagrams.
Prompt role: 
- Expert on flowcharts and sequence diagrams.
- Makes clear but concise annotations.  
- Is an expert at knowing when to break a complicated diagram into smaller ones.

Role: Software Engineer
Main function: 
- Write software based on a detailed user story from the architect. 
Prompt Role: 
- Experienced Software Developer.
- Writes readable, maintainable code that is well documented and self-describing.

Role: Product Owner and Architect
Main function: Turning text-based user feature requests into actionable developer tasks to include spec for code, tests, and documentation
Your background and experience:
- You are an experienced developer and project manager.
- You know the code base inside and out.
- You have strong knowledge of developer practices, what it's like to be a developer, how to create strong readable documentation etc.

Inputs: User Feature Requests
Outputs: Detailed developer User Stories

Articulates what the impact of a proposed solution is, decides where the changes should be made.
Decides what tests are required to be updated and/or changed.

Take this whole repo -> pull it onto a server -> start it up. 
Then: 
- All functionality is up.
- I can get to all the various views.
- Alexa can hit my server.

# Dev Workflow
How to go from feature request to merged code.
# Conrad Actions
- Write Feature request and/or user story.
# Python Actions
- Populate chat GPT template.
# ChatGPT Actions
- Write prompts.
- Write code.
- Write tests.
- Update documentation.
# CI/CD Actions
- Git hook actions, for example: 
	- Generate human-readable diagrams.
- Run tests on feature branch.
	- If tests pass: Open pull request.
- Deploy release candidate for manual testing.
	- Conrad to perform manual testing.
	- Conrad to approve the merge.
- Merge release candidate.
- Deploy merge commit to prod server.

# Adding a Feature Block

1. Create feature request
2. Link to domain
3. Design in System Layer
4. Implement in Core
5. Document in Version Plan

Flow Diagrams
Sequence Diagrams
Etc etc

# Decision: Calendar UI

| Option | Pros | Cons |
|--------|------|------|
| FullCalendar.js | Feature-rich | Heavy |

# Using the Calendar View

Step-by-step guide for scheduling.

# Feature: Calendar View v2

## Context
User wants a scrollable weekly calendar view...

## Goal
Enable drag-and-drop scheduling.

# Orchestration Layer

Coordinates feature logic and data flows.

# UX Layer

Defines user interface views and navigation models.

# Component: Calendar View

Implements scheduling UI and logic.

# Release Notes v1.0

- Added core calendar view
- Defined UX layer

# v1.0 Plan

Includes time domain + calendar view base.

# Diff Summary

Compared to previous draft, added orchestration logic.

A dream written down with a date becomes a goal. 

A goal broken down into steps becomes a plan. 

A plan backed by action makes your dreams come true.

### 00_User Data

| Field         | Answer                                                  |
|---------------|----------------------------------------------------------|
| Purpose       | Programmatically consumed user domain and context data   |
| Content Type  | Structured data files (e.g. JSON, YAML, CSV)             |
| Versioned?    | Yes                                                      |
| Built Output  | Used to populate runtime behavior or examples            |
| Notes         | Should be machine-parseable and schema-consistent        |

---

### 01_User Feature Requests

| Field         | Answer                                                              |
|---------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Purpose       | Structured internal backlog of user-facing enhancements              |
| Content Type  | Markdown user stories, with structured sections (context, goal, etc) |
| Versioned?    | Yes                                                                  |
| Built Output  | Linked to dev branches and commit trails                             |
| Notes         | Tag with domain/component when possible                              |

---

### 02_System Layers

| Field         | Answer                                                                          |
|---------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Purpose       | Persistent system design abstractions (UX layer, orchestration, interface)      |
| Content Type  | Markdown specs, diagrams, decision summaries                                     |
| Versioned?    | Yes (evolves carefully)                                                          |
| Built Output  | Forms semantic backbone for ChatGPT context + contributor onboarding             |
| Notes         | Layer ownership could be mapped in Meta folder                                   |

---

### 03_Core Components

| Field         | Answer                                                                 |
|---------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Purpose       | Finalized implementation specs and source logic (markdown + code)      |
| Content Type  | Markdown specs, source files (e.g. Python/JS), links to requirements    |
| Versioned?    | Yes (production-ready content only)                                     |
| Built Output  | Generates executable scripts, docs, or reference code                   |
| Notes         | Pseudocode lives in dev or exploration folders, not here                |

---

### 04_Solution Architecture Options

| Field         | Answer                                                                 |
|---------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Purpose       | Alternative approaches, trade studies, and design justifications        |
| Content Type  | Markdown ADRs, comparison tables, performance evaluations               |
| Versioned?    | Yes                                                                     |
| Built Output  | Influences `02_System Layers`                                           |
| Notes         | Promotion rules live in `99_Meta Processes`                             |

---

### 05_Version Release Plan

| Field         | Answer                                                                 |
|---------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Purpose       | Map actions and user stories to version milestones                     |
| Content Type  | Markdown milestone files, changelogs, feature mapping tables            |
| Versioned?    | Yes                                                                     |
| Built Output  | Historical documentation of progress                                    |
| Notes         | CI/CD and build plans should live in a new folder: `97_Build Configs/`  |

---

### 98_User Tutorials

| Field         | Answer                                                   |
|---------------|-----------------------------------------------------------|
| Purpose       | User-facing guidance and test targets for UX completion   |
| Content Type  | Markdown walkthroughs, screenshots, test flow diagrams    |
| Versioned?    | Yes                                                       |
| Built Output  | Test cases, onboarding support, UI validation             |
| Notes         | Use these to validate system layer implementation         |

---

### 99_Meta Processes

| Field         | Answer                                                                 |
|---------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Purpose       | Codified dev workflows, prompting guidelines, merge protocols           |
| Content Type  | Markdown SOPs, diagrams, templates, checklists                         |
| Versioned?    | Yes                                                                     |
| Built Output  | Developer understanding, team alignment                                 |
| Notes         | Include branching strategy, ChatGPT prompt formats, feature workflows   |

---

### üÜï 97_Build Configs (Recommended Addition)

| Field         | Answer                                                                 |
|---------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Purpose       | CI/CD pipelines, build targets, deployment automation                   |
| Content Type  | YAML files (GitHub Actions, Makefiles), bash/python scripts             |
| Versioned?    | Yes                                                                     |
| Built Output  | Triggers tests, documentation builds, deployment processes              |
| Notes         | Separate from `05_Version Release Plan` to avoid mixing dev plans       |

file_path: /home/conrad/git/yggdrasill/_older versions/v01/97_Build Configs/Build Pipeline Example for "Calendar View".md
body:
### üîÅ Build Pipeline Example for ‚ÄúCalendar View‚Äù

1. **Source**
    - `03_Core Components/calendar_view.md`
    - Describes logic and layout
        
2. **Build (Human-Readable Output)**
    - `98_User Tutorials/how_to_use_calendar_view.md`
    - Generated diagrams or walkthroughs
        
3. **Build (Executable, Optional)**
    - `run_calendar_view.py` (if you automate any part of it)
        
4. **Build (Prompt Artifacts)**
    - Prompt + ChatGPT-generated code
    - Stored in Git and versioned under `05_Version Release Plan/v1.X`

### 1. **Keep Each Domain as Its Own Section**

Use the current format (hierarchical with pain points) but divide it into three clearly labeled parts for each domain:

#### Example Structure per Domain:

shell

Copy

`## Domain: Piano & Musical Practice  ### Description (Already written ‚Äî what this domain covers) ### Pain Points (Already written ‚Äî refine if needed) ### Desired Outcomes (NEW) (What a ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù version of this domain looks like for you ‚Äî just bullet points, not solutions yet)`

> **Why**: This structure mirrors the classic _problem ‚Üí vision ‚Üí actions_ model and sets the stage for future goal breakdown.

---

### ‚úÖ 2. **Create a Master Tracker or Index**

This can be in a simple spreadsheet, Notion database, or even an extended section in your canvas. For each domain, track:

|Domain|Value-to-Life|Current Friction|Confidence in Problem Understanding|Ready for Action?|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|Piano|High|Medium|High|Yes|
|Fitness|Medium|High|Medium|No (need clearer outcomes)|

> **Why**: This lets you triage which areas to act on first and helps you work _agilely_‚Äîby selecting areas that are high-value and well-defined.

---

### ‚úÖ 3. **Start a Backlog of Value-Adding Activities**

Once you define **desired outcomes** for each domain, you can:

- Break those into **specific projects, habits, or improvements**.
    
- Use a backlog format (e.g., Trello, Notion, or a markdown list).
    

Structure each backlog item like a mini user story:

> _‚ÄúAs a creative pianist, I want to record one session per week, so I can evaluate progress and prepare for performance.‚Äù_

---

### ‚úÖ 4. **Sprint-Based Planning**

You don‚Äôt need to go full Scrum‚Äîbut you _can_:

- Set aside **weekly or bi-weekly sprints** (even just an hour or two each week)
    
- Choose 1‚Äì3 value-adding items to work on
    
- Reflect after each sprint to re-prioritize

body: Should I be building toward my version release plan or continuing to flesh out the system design diagram?

| Concept             | Description                                                          | Example from Your Project                                            |
| ------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Source Code**     | Inputs to the system that define its logic, data flows, and behavior | Markdown specs in `03_Core Components/`, `02_System Layers/`         |
| **Build Artifacts** | Output generated for use by humans or machines                       | Tutorial docs, generated daily views, ChatGPT-complete code snippets |
| **Executable Code** | Optional ‚Äî if you actually write runnable Python/JS                  | A `run_daily_review.py` script                                       |
| **ChatGPT Inputs**  | Context files provided as prompts                                    | Most of the structured `.md` files                                   |
| **ChatGPT Outputs** | Code, logic, or designs written/generated by GPT and then committed  | Drafts or finalized files from `dev_notes/` to `core/`               |


| Concept          | Description                            | Example from Your Project |
| ---------------- | -------------------------------------- | ------------------------- |
| Feature Request  | Major effort -  commonly product level | Integrate voice commands  |
| User Interaction | Medium Effort - component level        | Improved task creation    |
| User Story       | Not used                               |                           |
| Task             |                                        |                           |


See also: [[01_Object Hierarchy]]

| Concept    | Description                | Example from Your Project |
| ---------- | -------------------------- | ------------------------- |
| Goal       | Vision-Drive Outcome       |                           |
| Project    | Scoped Container of Work   |                           |
| Milestone  | Progress Marker            |                           |
| Block      | Calendar-Size Working Unit |                           |
| Microtasks | Checkable Steps            |                           |

body:
As a user, I need to be able to easily add tasks.

The current workflow is to manually write them into the Google Sheets task database located at:
	https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TdtuvDYls1XUskhpKeu5z9NsFlKBp6hG0iii4ElAHJY/edit?gid=1582071785#gid=1582071785

Current Behavior:
- Manually type the task into the database.
- Manually add the task to the scheduling view.
- Update the cell references in the Weekly Planning scheduling view reports.

Desired behavior:
- 

Potential Improved Implementations:
- Integration with Google Tasks.
- Create Markdown files for each task.
- Integration with Alexa.
- Streamlit page.

What was planned? 
What actually happened?
Statistics over different time horizons.
Are the metrics improving in some way? 
If the trends continue, where will we go?

# v0.1
Google Sheets.
# v0.2
See Google Sheet: Completed Task Instance DB
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1MXgzyYI6OCrsrwJQFDP10uvhBrsJEdv2c8bjlPgiaic/edit?gid=0#gid=0
- Current Metrics:
	- Count of completed Tasks

Goal: Generate the "Daily View" Task Completion Tracker Log, based on the Task DB

References:
- Task DB: 
	- https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1wNL1eZ67Fxo9CPJdvttTRfHBqCD-UJFQhBGUnXqVOEA/edit?gid=0#gid=0
- Daily Tracker: 
		- https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/12ojEAWQyIcbnd0EtlxNcWbPJX1V-mK4I_fesLLfuad8/edit?gid=1984198854#gid=1984198854

Implementation: 
	- Task DB in .csv
	- Daily view in Streamlit

# Staging
## First
1. Export Task DB as a CSV.
2. Build a streamlit app that shows this CSV as a dataframe.
## Then
1. Add some basic (manual toggle) filters, i.e. multiselect for a couple of different columns, for example "area" etc.
2. Understand what logic is required to create the derived fields:
	1. Ultimate parent, etc.
3. Understand logic is required to create ability to show a sibling set.
	1. e.g. all Tasks associated with "Chef's Planner", recurring all the way down the tree underneath it.
		1. Show only "Operational" or "Vision" or "Strategic"

Component: Streamlit
Area: Productivity Planner
Other potential area uses:
- Exercise planner - Filter exercises at different levels, legs vs quad etc.

Current Version:
- See streamlit for snowflake.

### üß± **1. Data Hierarchy & Structure**

You‚Äôll need the system to natively support or simulate the following relationships:
- **Domains** (e.g., Flying, Piano, Finances)
    - contain ‚Üí **Goals** (broad, outcome-based)
        - contain ‚Üí **Projects** (concrete efforts with deliverables)
            - contain ‚Üí **Milestones** (intermediate checkpoints)
                - contain ‚Üí **Blocks** (schedulable, actionable units)
                    - may contain ‚Üí **Microtasks** (optional checkable steps)

Each level should:
- Be **taggable** (e.g., effort type, context, location)
- Support **notes, links, and status tracking**
- Relate upward (e.g., Block ‚Üí Milestone ‚Üí Project)

### üìä **2. Visualization & Decision Support**

You‚Äôll need to see and interact with the data in a few key formats:
- **Calendar View**: drag-and-drop or time-block-style view of scheduled blocks
- **Checklist View**: check off completed blocks/tasks and log history
- **Tabular View**: sortable, filterable table of current projects/milestones (by domain, status, tags)
- **Kanban/Board View** (optional): especially helpful for Projects and Milestones
- **Charts/Dashboards**:
    - Effort over time (by domain, block size, etc.)
    - Goal progress summaries
    - Weekly review metrics (e.g., how many blocks completed in each domain)

### ‚è≥ **3. Time & Rhythm Integration**

The system must allow you to:
- Allocate **blocks** to calendar time slots (manually or semi-automatically)
- Define **recurring blocks** (e.g., weekly planning session)
- Track what got **scheduled vs completed**
- Support **"look ahead" views** (What does my next week/month contain?)
- Attach **estimated and actual durations** to tasks (optional, for reflection)

### ‚úÖ **4. Action Logging & Review**

You‚Äôll want features that let you:
- **Check off blocks** and log their completion time/date
- Add brief **retrospective notes** or reflections
- Aggregate performance per week or month
- Track "streaks" or consistency in key domains

### üí¨ **5. Tags, Metadata & Categorization**

You‚Äôll need a robust tagging/filter system to slice across views:
- Effort type (`@deep`, `@admin`, etc.)
- Energy level or cognitive load
- Domain or subdomain
- Project status (Active, Planned, On Hold, Completed)
- Priority or importance

### üîÅ **6. Workflow Features**

Your system should support:
- **Weekly planning rituals**: pull blocks into calendar
- **Backlog grooming**: promote goals ‚Üí projects ‚Üí milestones ‚Üí blocks
- **Review cycles**: summarize effort completed, adjust future plans
- **Dynamic filtering**: ‚ÄúShow me all active projects with overdue milestones‚Äù
- **Smart scheduling**: ‚ÄúWhat can I do in the next 45 minutes with low cognitive load?‚Äù

### üóÇÔ∏è **7. Optional Enhancements**

Depending on your ambition:
- **Template system** (e.g., new project auto-generates milestone scaffolding)
- **Versioning** or history tracking (especially for creative/technical work)
- **Multi-device support** (syncing mobile, desktop, tablet)
- **Offline access** (for flying, travel, remote work)
Requirements are designed to provide the functionality that make the use cases possible.

body:
Yes‚Äîa **local Linux + Python + CSV (or SQLite) + Streamlit** stack is an **excellent and developer-friendly choice** for prototyping and eventually scaling this system. It gives you:

- üß† **Full control** over logic and layout
    
- ü™∂ **Lightweight setup** (no accounts, API rate limits, or permissions drama)
    
- üõ†Ô∏è **Hackability** (easy to add views, scripts, scoring, dashboards, etc.)
    
- üí° **Clear upgrade paths** (CSV ‚Üí SQLite ‚Üí full database, Streamlit ‚Üí web app)
    

Let‚Äôs break down how this would work and how to structure it.

---

## ‚úÖ What This Stack Looks Like

### üìÅ **Data Layer: CSV or SQLite**

- Start with a CSV or set of CSVs:
    
    - `tasks.csv`, `logs.csv`, `projects.csv`
        
- Fields: `Task ID`, `Title`, `Domain`, `Effort`, `Due Date`, `Scheduled For`, `Status`, `Completed Date`, `Notes`, etc.
    
- Store in a flat folder with your app (easy to version control)
    

> üí° Later: Migrate to SQLite with the same schema if needed‚Äîvery little code changes.

---

### üß∞ **Backend Layer: Python**

- Read/write CSVs using `pandas`
    
- Use `datetime`, `uuid`, `pathlib`, `os`, etc. for task metadata and filesystem ops
    
- Handle logic:
    
    - Suggest tasks
        
    - Track overdue/missing completions
        
    - Score and prioritize backlog items
        
    - Automatically assign from backlog to ‚ÄúToday‚Äù or ‚ÄúThis Week‚Äù queue
        

---

### üéõÔ∏è **Frontend Layer: Streamlit**

You can create multiple simple pages like:

#### 1. **Weekly Planning Page**

- View backlog of tasks (filtered, sorted, or scored)
    
- Add tasks to ‚ÄúThis Week‚Äù bucket
    
- See current effort allocation (visual bar or pie chart)
    

#### 2. **Today View**

- Show ‚ÄúScheduled for Today‚Äù tasks
    
- Mark as complete
    
- Add optional notes/reflection
    
- Show remaining capacity for the day
    

#### 3. **Completion Log**

- View completed tasks with date, domain, reflection
    
- Filter by domain, date, project
    
- Generate simple stats
    

#### 4. **Review Dashboard**

- Chart: blocks completed this week, by domain
    
- Heatmap: days with low vs high engagement
    
- Recap of what was neglected
    
- Text summary for journaling
    

#### 5. **Admin or Data Table Editor (Optional)**

- View/edit raw task list
    
- Add recurring tasks
    
- Export or import to other systems
    

---

## üîó Integration-Ready Features

This stack supports:

- Syncing CSV to cloud backup (e.g., with Dropbox or Git)
    
- Outputting .ics files for calendar imports (via `ics` or `vobject` libraries)
    
- Later connecting with:
    
    - Google Calendar API
        
    - Email digests (e.g., `smtplib`)
        
    - Task manager APIs like Todoist
        

---

## üß† Dev Experience

- You work in your terminal or IDE
    
- All your data is yours, local, transparent
    
- You can version control logic and even the data
    
- No waiting on third-party syncs or debugging Zapier logic
    

---

## üß™ Suggested Next Steps

1. **Prototype**: `tasks.csv` with key fields
    
2. Build simple Streamlit UI:
    
    - Load tasks
        
    - Filter by "Scheduled for Today"
        
    - Checkbox to mark complete ‚Üí logs to `log.csv`
        
3. Add a button: ‚ÄúSuggest a task for today‚Äù using scoring logic

## üß† Optional Future: Recommendation Engine (V1 Logic)

You could simulate a basic recommender by scoring tasks with a formula:

pseudo

Copy

`task_score =      
+ 2 if domain not touched in 14+ days     
+ 2 if due within 7 days     
+ 1 if effort size fits remaining weekly capacity     
+ 1 if marked high priority     
- 1 if already attempted this week`

Tasks with high scores bubble up in ‚ÄúSuggested‚Äù column for Today or This Week.

Specific tolerances on: 
- Task duration

Can provide scheduling recommendations/suggestions, based on value and what can fit in the calendar.
- I might need to set a priority or value allocation to specific domains.
- Particular Calendar Events might have some constraints
	- I want to eat 90 min before exercising +/- 30 min.

body:
## üó£Ô∏è **Voice Interface Integration Paths (Prototypable)**

### üîπ **1. Google Assistant + IFTTT + Webhook**

**Best for: Quick, no-code prototype voice integration**

#### ‚úÖ What You Can Do:

- Say: _‚ÄúHey Google, complete task ‚ÄòMorning Stretch‚Äô‚Äù_
    
- Google Assistant ‚Üí IFTTT ‚Üí Webhook to your Python server (or intermediate webhook service)
    
- Your Streamlit app (or background script) processes it and updates the task in `tasks.csv`
    

#### üîó Tools:

- [IFTTT](https://ifttt.com/) to create Google Assistant applets
    
- Webhook (Zapier or custom Flask endpoint)
    
- Local or cloud-exposed Python function to modify your CSVs
    

#### ‚ö†Ô∏è Limitations:

- Voice parsing is basic‚Äîno rich conversation
    
- IFTTT triggers require exact phrases
    
- Can be one-way unless you use email or text for feedback
    

---

### üîπ **2. Custom Alexa Skill (Moderate Complexity)**

**Best for: Structured voice commands with feedback**

#### ‚úÖ What You Can Do:

- Launch a custom skill: ‚ÄúAlexa, ask Life Planner what‚Äôs scheduled for today.‚Äù
    
- Alexa hits a Lambda function (or custom endpoint)
    
- Your backend returns a text string summarizing tasks, which Alexa reads aloud
    

#### üîó Tools:

- AWS Lambda (or FastAPI + ngrok for local dev)
    
- Alexa Developer Console
    
- Local CSV/DB queried by backend
    

#### ‚ö†Ô∏è Limitations:

- Requires account linking or a public endpoint
    
- Some learning curve around Alexa's Skill structure and intents
    
- More secure for long-term use than IFTTT
    

---

### üîπ **3. Siri Shortcuts + Script Trigger**

**Best for: Local Mac/iPhone-based voice automation**

#### ‚úÖ What You Can Do:

- Create a Siri Shortcut that runs a shell command or Python script
    
- Say: ‚ÄúHey Siri, log today‚Äôs morning review‚Äù
    
- It runs a script that marks a task complete or opens Streamlit locally
    

#### üîó Tools:

- iOS Shortcuts app
    
- SSH to local machine (if remote)
    
- Python CLI or Streamlit endpoint
    

#### ‚ö†Ô∏è Limitations:

- Not conversational
    
- Best suited for personal, local workflows (no cloud voice parsing)
    
- iOS/macOS only
    

---

### üîπ **4. Custom Voice UI with OpenAI Whisper or Vosk (Advanced)**

**Best for: Total control over local voice interaction**

#### ‚úÖ What You Can Do:

- Use a wake-word listener + Whisper transcription + keyword matching
    
- Say anything like "What's on my calendar?" or "Mark the piano task complete"
    
- System parses intent and triggers functions in your planner backend
    

#### üîó Tools:

- `whisper` or `vosk` for speech-to-text
    
- Local command parser (regex or NLP)
    
- Python hooks to Streamlit or CSV logic
    

#### ‚ö†Ô∏è Limitations:

- Local performance requires solid audio setup
    
- No built-in TTS (you‚Äôd need `pyttsx3` or similar)
    
- Not hands-free unless coupled with microphone/watch triggers
    

---

## üöÄ Suggested First Prototype (Low Friction)

### **Goal**: Use Google Assistant or Siri to:

- Query: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs on my task list today?‚Äù
    
- Command: ‚ÄúMark ‚Äòpiano practice‚Äô complete‚Äù
    

### Prototype Path:

1. **Create a command phrase** via IFTTT or Siri Shortcut
    
2. **Trigger a webhook** or local script (e.g., call a CLI endpoint on your system)
    
3. **Python script** updates the `tasks.csv` (e.g., sets status = Completed)
    
4. **(Optional)** Return a message summary (e.g., via text, read aloud, or push notification)
    

---

## üß± Integration Point in Your Stack

- **All voice triggers become function calls to your task DB manager**
    
- Extend your Python backend with CLI wrappers like:
    
    bash
    
    Copy
    
    `python complete_task.py --name "piano practice" python query_schedule.py --today`
    
- These scripts can be:
    
    - Triggered via voice assistant
        
    - Called by webhooks
        
    - Used internally in Streamlit too

file_path: /home/conrad/git/yggdrasill/_older versions/v01/04_Solution Architecture Options/02_Later/Voice Integration/Custom Alexa Skill.md
body:
## üß† **What Is a Custom Alexa Skill?**

A **Custom Skill** is an Alexa app that you design and deploy. Unlike pre-built voice commands, a Custom Skill can:

- Handle complex phrases or multi-step interactions
    
- Query or update external systems (like your life admin backend)
    
- Return structured responses spoken by Alexa
    

You define the **phrases (intents)** Alexa should recognize and how your **backend code (lambda or API)** should respond.

---

## üß© **Key Concepts in Alexa Skills**

|Component|Description|
|---|---|
|**Invocation Name**|The phrase to start your skill: _‚ÄúAlexa, open Life Planner‚Äù_|
|**Intent**|The user‚Äôs request: _‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs on my list today?‚Äù_|
|**Utterances**|All the phrases that map to an intent: _‚ÄúWhat do I need to do?‚Äù_, _‚ÄúShow me my tasks‚Äù_|
|**Slots**|Variables in a phrase: _‚ÄúMark {task_name} as complete‚Äù_|
|**Endpoint**|The code (Lambda or HTTPS server) that processes the request|

---

## üõ†Ô∏è **How Your Life Admin Stack Could Connect**

1. **User says**: ‚ÄúAlexa, ask Life Planner what I have to do today‚Äù
    
2. Alexa matches that to your `TodayTasksIntent`
    
3. Alexa sends a **JSON payload** to your endpoint (a server or AWS Lambda)
    
4. Your Python script reads `tasks.csv`, filters for today, builds a text response
    
5. Alexa speaks the response: _‚ÄúYou have three tasks today: piano practice, review finances, and schedule dentist appointment.‚Äù_
    

---

## üß™ **Common Intents for Your System**

|Intent Name|Example Phrase|System Action|
|---|---|---|
|`GetTodayTasksIntent`|‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs on my list today?‚Äù|Read from `tasks.csv` where `Scheduled = Today`|
|`CompleteTaskIntent`|‚ÄúMark piano practice as complete‚Äù|Update task status in CSV/DB|
|`AddTaskIntent`|‚ÄúAdd a task to review my flight plan‚Äù|Append new task to CSV|
|`GetSuggestionsIntent`|‚ÄúWhat do you recommend for this week?‚Äù|Run scoring logic and return top 3 suggestions|

---

## üîó **Architecture Options**

### Option A: **AWS Lambda (Most Common)**

- Deploy your skill's backend code as a **serverless function** on AWS Lambda
    
- Alexa hits it directly via HTTPS
    

‚úÖ Pros:

- Fast to deploy
    
- No infrastructure needed
    
- Secure and scalable
    

‚ö†Ô∏è Cons:

- You must zip and upload or use inline code editor
    
- Cold starts can delay response slightly
    

---

### Option B: **Public HTTPS Server (e.g., Flask + ngrok)**

- Run a Flask app locally or on a server
    
- Use [ngrok](https://ngrok.com/) to expose a secure HTTPS endpoint for Alexa to call
    

‚úÖ Pros:

- Great for development
    
- You can interact with your real local CSV backend directly
    

‚ö†Ô∏è Cons:

- Must handle authentication (Alexa verifies requests)
    
- Needs reliable internet if local
    
- Free ngrok sessions expire (unless upgraded)
    

---

## üß† **Skill Development Process Overview**

1. **Design your skill**
    
    - Define the invocation name
        
    - List intents, utterances, and slots
        
2. **Write backend logic**
    
    - Read/write to `tasks.csv`
        
    - Format responses Alexa can speak
        
3. **Deploy the endpoint**
    
    - AWS Lambda or Flask + ngrok
        
4. **Test in Alexa Developer Console**
    
    - Simulate voice inputs and debug output
        
5. **(Optional) Certify and publish the skill**
    
    - Use for personal or public use
        

---

## üß™ Example Response Logic (Python/Flask)

python

Copy

~~~ python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify 
import pandas as pd

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/alexa', methods=['POST'])
def handle_alexa():
    data = request.get_json()
    intent = data['request']['intent']['name']

    if intent == 'GetTodayTasksIntent':
        df = pd.read_csv('tasks.csv')
        today_tasks = df[df['Scheduled'] == 'Today']['Task'].tolist()
        response = "You have {} task{} today: {}".format(
            len(today_tasks),
            "" if len(today_tasks) == 1 else "s",
            ", ".join(today_tasks)
        )
        return jsonify({
            "version": "1.0",
            "response": {
                "outputSpeech": {
                    "type": "PlainText",
                    "text": response
                },
                "shouldEndSession": True
            }
        })

    return jsonify({"version": "1.0", "response": {"shouldEndSession": True}})

~~~

## üß≠ First Steps If You Want to Try This

1. Create a **developer account** on [developer.amazon.com](https://developer.amazon.com/alexa)
    
2. Use the **Alexa Skill Builder** to define one or two intents and utterances
    
3. Spin up a **local Flask app** with one endpoint (`/alexa`) that accepts JSON
    
4. Use **ngrok** to expose it, and paste the HTTPS URL into your skill‚Äôs endpoint setting
    
5. Test: _‚ÄúAlexa, open Life Planner and tell me what I have to do today‚Äù_

Aka "View"

Presenting Table data in a human-readable way.

See: [[UX Layer]]

| View Type           | Purpose                                       | Interaction Style         | Version |
| ------------------- | --------------------------------------------- | ------------------------- | ------- |
| **Weekly Planning** | Choose tasks from a backlog & allocate effort | Planning + selection      | v0.1    |
| **Today View**      | Focused list of what‚Äôs on deck today          | Execution + check-off     | v0.1    |
| **Domain Overview** | See progress and active tasks by domain       | Contextual prioritization | -       |
| **Review View**     | Reflect on what was done, skipped, or learned | Reflection + feedback     | -       |
| **Backlog View**    | View all unscheduled or future tasks          | Grooming + prioritization | -       |
i.e. Python scripts and orchestration thereof.

## üß± **System Layers (Think Like a House)**

### 1. **Data Layer (Foundation)**

Where all the task info lives‚Äîyour goals, projects, daily blocks, and status.

> Example: A `tasks.csv` file or Airtable table with all your life admin entries.

---

### 2. **Logic & Orchestration Layer (Plumbing)**

This layer handles logic like:
- Scoring tasks
- Marking things as complete
- Finding neglected areas
- Generating new weekly schedules

> Example: Python scripts that filter, update, or summarize your task list.

---

### 3. **UX / Interaction Layer (Rooms & Furniture)**

This is where you live‚Äîviews that help you _do_ stuff:

|View|Purpose|
|---|---|
|Today View|What do I need to do right now?|
|Weekly Planning|Choose what to focus on this week|
|Review Dashboard|What got done? What's being neglected?|
|Task Editor|Add or modify tasks|

body:
## üß≠ High-Level Concept: Views as Interaction Surfaces

Each view serves a distinct purpose:

| View Type           | Purpose                                       | Interaction Style         |
| ------------------- | --------------------------------------------- | ------------------------- |
| **Weekly Planning** | Choose tasks from a backlog & allocate effort | Planning + selection      |
| **Today View**      | Focused list of what‚Äôs on deck today          | Execution + check-off     |
| **Domain Overview** | See progress and active tasks by domain       | Contextual prioritization |
| **Review View**     | Reflect on what was done, skipped, or learned | Reflection + feedback     |
| **Backlog View**    | View all unscheduled or future tasks          | Grooming + prioritization |
## üìÖ **1. Weekly Planning View**

### Purpose:

Choose what to focus on this week, given:
- Time availability
- Cognitive/emotional capacity
- What‚Äôs due or stagnating

### Layout:

| Task Name             | Domain   | Effort Size | Priority | Suggested? | Scheduled? | Notes      |
| --------------------- | -------- | ----------- | -------- | ---------- | ---------- | ---------- |
| File taxes            | Finances | L           | High     | ‚úÖ          | This Week  | Due Apr 15 |
| Record piano practice | Piano    | M           | Med      | ‚¨ú          | -          | -          |

### Features:
- **Effort Budgeting Tracker** (e.g., 10 "slots" for the week)
    - Each block has a size (S, M, L ‚Üí worth 1, 2, 3 effort units)
    - As you add tasks to the ‚ÄúThis Week‚Äù list, your capacity fills
- **Suggested Tasks** (eventually)
    - Based on: domain neglect, upcoming due dates, effort size fit
    - ‚ÄúHey, you haven‚Äôt done anything in Tango in 2 weeks‚Äù
### Planning Actions:
- Drag or mark tasks as `Scheduled: This Week`
- See capacity fill up as you select
- Optionally assign to specific days or keep in a weekly bucket

## ‚úÖ **2. Today View**

### Purpose:
Focus your attention on a realistic, clear, short list

| Task                      | Domain | Effort | Status | Complete Time | Notes |
| ------------------------- | ------ | ------ | ------ | ------------- | ----- |
| Write Human Motion update | HMP    | M      | ‚¨ú      | ‚Äî             | ‚Äî     |

### Features:
- Status: checkbox or kanban-style toggles
- Visual effort load for the day (e.g., 5/6 units filled)
- Optional timer/log button

## üîç **3. Domain Overview View**

### Purpose:
Quick glance at what‚Äôs active or overdue by domain

| Domain | Open Projects | Last Worked On | Suggested Task | Time Since Last Action |
| ------ | ------------- | -------------- | -------------- | ---------------------- |
| Flying | 2             | 5 days ago     | Plan solo XC   | 5d                     |

Could evolve into a ‚Äúheat map‚Äù of attention over time.
## üìà **4. Review View**

### Purpose:
Evaluate what got done, how balanced things were, what you learned

| Task               | Domain | Status | Completed Date | Notes / Reflection        |
| ------------------ | ------ | ------ | -------------- | ------------------------- |
| Update estate plan | Admin  | ‚úÖ      | 2025-05-10     | Took longer than expected |

Can be filtered by:
- Date range
- Domain
- Status (Completed, Skipped, Delayed)

Eventually you could:
- Tag days with mood or energy levels
- Note what sabotaged or helped execution
- Build a dashboard showing domain balance or consistency over time

## üì¶ **5. Backlog View**

### Purpose:
View all unscheduled or future tasks and sort/groom

| Task | Domain | Effort | Priority | Last Touched | Milestone? | Notes |
| ---- | ------ | ------ | -------- | ------------ | ---------- | ----- |

### Use cases:
- Pull tasks into the planning funnel    
- See neglected projects
- Reassign or re-estimate effort
- Archive stale tasks

file_path: /home/conrad/git/yggdrasill/_older versions/v01/04_Solution Architecture Options/00_System Layers/UX and Interaction Layer/Interaction Layer.md
body:
## üß≠ **1. Key Interaction Goals**

Here‚Äôs what your system needs to support, conceptually:

| Interaction Need       | Description                                                                 |
| ---------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Capture**            | Add tasks, goals, and projects to the system with minimal overhead.         |
| **Select**             | Choose a subset of tasks to focus on for today, this week, or this month.   |
| **Schedule**           | Assign tasks to calendar time or day/week ‚Äúbuckets.‚Äù                        |
| **Execute + Complete** | Check off tasks as done, optionally logging completion time and reflection. |
| **Review**             | See what got done, what didn‚Äôt, and what needs to be rescheduled.           |
| **Visualize**          | View your planned vs completed work across time and domain.                 |

## üõ†Ô∏è **2. Key System Components (Conceptual)**

### üóÉÔ∏è A. **Master Task Database**

- Lives in a spreadsheet, Notion, SQLite, or Airtable.

- Includes: domain, goal/project association, effort size, due date, recurrence info, status (`Planned`, `In Progress`, `Completed`, `Skipped`), etc.
    
- Can filter by ‚Äúis ready for scheduling‚Äù.
    

### üìÜ B. **Scheduling View**

- Interface where you select tasks for **Today**, **This Week**, or **This Month**.
    
- Can be a dedicated column/tag (`Scheduled For: Today/Week/Month`) or a filtered view.
    
- Optionally synced with your calendar (e.g., export selected tasks to Google Calendar or embed a time block).
    

### ‚úÖ C. **Daily Execution View**

- Narrow, focused list of what you committed to today.
    
- Each task shows:
    
    -  Checkbox
        
    - Optional timer / log button
        
    - Optional notes field (for reflection or adjustments)
        
- Ideal for mobile, tablet, or at-a-glance desktop view.
    

### üìà D. **Review & Logging System**

- Completed tasks auto-log `completion time`, or allow you to log manually.
    
- Review view shows:
    
    - Total blocks completed per day/week
        
    - Domain coverage (e.g., 2x Piano, 3x Admin)
        
    - Tasks skipped or rescheduled
        
- Optionally includes journaling/reflection field


## üîÑ **3. Daily/Weekly Workflow Example**

> **Morning Routine**

- Open your **Weekly Planning View**
    
- Drag or select tasks into your **Today** list
    
- (Optionally) assign calendar time blocks
    

> **During the Day**

- Open **Today View**
    
- Check off tasks as completed
    
- Add notes, adjustments, or reschedule on the fly
    

> **End of Day / Next Morning**

- Review which tasks were completed
    
- Log optional reflections or notes
    
- Clear the day and plan for tomorrow
    

> **Weekly Review**

- Filter by domain or effort size to reflect on how time was spent
    
- Update longer-term goals or shift projects as needed

## üß† **Design Considerations**

- Don‚Äôt force everything into calendar time‚Äîuse ‚ÄúToday/This Week‚Äù tags for softer planning.
    
- Use filters (Notion) or queries (SQL) to pull ‚Äúready-to-schedule‚Äù tasks.
    
- Allow "uncompleted" tasks to easily roll over (carry forward logic).
    
- Use dashboard views to track momentum by domain or goal.

file_path: /home/conrad/git/yggdrasill/_older versions/v01/04_Solution Architecture Options/00_System Layers/Data Layer/Hierarchical Task Organization Framework.md
body:
## ‚öñÔ∏è **Hierarchical Effort Framework for Personal Life Ops**

### üîπ **1. Task Tiering**

Break tasks into three major scales, similar to Agile's Epics ‚Üí Stories ‚Üí Tasks:

| Tier        | Description                             | Calendar Impact            | Example                      |
| ----------- | --------------------------------------- | -------------------------- | ---------------------------- |
| **Project** | Multi-step outcome or goal              | Spread across weeks/months | ‚ÄúPlan a tango festival trip‚Äù |
| **Block**   | Standalone, unit of meaningful progress | 30‚Äì120 minutes             | ‚ÄúArrange piano intro for X‚Äù  |
| **Micro**   | Quick action, easily overlooked         | < 20 minutes               | ‚ÄúBook dentist appointment‚Äù   |

> Use ‚ÄúProjects‚Äù as planning units and ‚ÄúBlocks‚Äù & ‚ÄúMicros‚Äù as calendarable actions.

---
### üî∏ **2. T-Shirt Sizing for On-Task Effort**

Apply effort sizing that captures complexity and friction, not just duration:

| Size | On-Task Time | Typical Feel                    | Example                    |
| ---- | ------------ | ------------------------------- | -------------------------- |
| XS   | < 10 min     | Easy win / trivial              | Reply to recruiter         |
| S    | 10‚Äì30 min    | Straightforward                 | Clean kitchen drawer       |
| M    | 30‚Äì90 min    | Single session focus            | Practice piano technique   |
| L    | 1.5‚Äì3 hrs    | Requires batching or flow       | Organize financial records |
| XL   | 3+ hrs       | Mental load / multiple attempts | Plan cross-country flight  |

> You can mark task sizes directly in your task tracker (e.g., `[M] Write blog post`).

---
### üß† **3. Load Type Tags (Optional)**

Add optional tags that describe the _nature_ of the effort to help with batching and calendar fit:

- `@deep` ‚Äì needs full focus (writing, coding, arranging)
- `@admin` ‚Äì low-focus life tasks (bills, bookings)
- `@creative` ‚Äì expressive, generative tasks (music, cooking, photography)
- `@social` ‚Äì involves people, collaboration, or communication
- `@physical` ‚Äì movement, chores, errands
- `@logistics` ‚Äì planning, organizing, coordinating

---

### ‚è≥ **4. Calendar Fit Patterns**

Use your effort scale to align with real-life availability:

| Time Block Available | Task Type(s) to Slot In                          |
| -------------------- | ------------------------------------------------ |
| 10‚Äì20 min            | Micro tasks (XS, S, `@admin`)                    |
| 30‚Äì90 min            | Focused blocks (M, `@deep`)                      |
| 2‚Äì3 hrs              | Flow sessions (L, `@creative`)                   |
| Evening energy dips  | Light or logistical (S, `@logistics`, `@social`) |
| Weekend              | Projects, batching, `@physical`                  |

---

### üß≠ **Putting It Together: An Example**

> **Task:** ‚ÄúRefactor Human Motion Project file structure‚Äù
- Tier: **Block**
- Size: **M**
- Tags: `@deep`, `@logistics`
- Time Slot: 60 min, weekday morning

This helps you:
- Prioritize by tier
- Fit into your day by size
- Match to energy/context by tag

1. Recipe Management
	- Full version requires many-to-many database.

2. Exercise Solver

Until then:
- As ideas come up -> write them in the task list.
	- Schedule 30-60 min a day to tackle them -> 1:30pm

## What could be better

Completed these component versions

- Posted my blocks into the calendars (Google and Strato).
- Request: Exercise not really supported yet, but I'd like review what that would look like.

## üöÄ **Version Release Plan (MVP Roadmap)**

### ‚úÖ **Version 0.1: ‚ÄúWorking Prototype‚Äù**

- Manually populated `tasks.csv`
- Streamlit Today View (checkboxes to mark complete)
- Task Editor Form (title, domain, effort, etc.)
- Simple Weekly Planning view
- Effort counter (e.g., 10 units per week)

### üß™ **Version 0.2: ‚ÄúUseful Daily Tool‚Äù**

- Completion logs with timestamp
- Reflections input + journal summary
- Weekly review dashboard (chart + table)
- Task suggestion engine (basic scoring)
- CSV export + backup

### üóìÔ∏è **Version 0.3: ‚ÄúIntegrated Planner‚Äù**

- Google Calendar sync (push scheduled tasks)
- CLI tool for quick task actions
- Task recurrence logic

### üó£Ô∏è **Version 0.4+: ‚ÄúSmart Assistant‚Äù**

- Voice control via Siri Shortcut or Alexa
- Neglect detection & smart nudges
- Notion or Airtable sync

## üß≠ **Guiding Principles**

- **Interoperability first**: Use open tools (like SQLite, Google Sheets, or Notion DB) that can grow into or interact with custom code.
    
- **Data durability**: Your database becomes the source of truth for domain progress, tasks, logs, and metrics.
    
- **Incremental rollout**: Start small, validate value, automate or enrich only what proves sticky.
    

---

## üõ†Ô∏è **High-Level Development Path**

### üîπ **Phase 1: Foundation (Spreadsheet Prototype)**

‚úÖ Where you are now

- Build trackers (e.g., healthcare, vehicle) in Google Sheets
    
- Use formulas to handle frequency, status, next due
    
- Manually create calendar events + checklists
    
- Use simple metadata (domain, type, frequency)
    

> üìç Goal: Validate utility and structure. Identify friction.

---

### üîπ **Phase 2: Database + Scripting Layer**

Introduce a **real backend**‚Äîsimple at first. Could be:

- SQLite (local, lightweight, script-friendly)
    
- Notion database (low-code, easy views)
    
- Google Sheets-as-DB (plus Apps Script or Python API access)
    

Add scripts for:

- **Task generation** (e.g., generate next healthcare block if ‚Äúnext due‚Äù is in next 30 days)
    
- **Status updates** (completed? rescheduled? overdue?)
    
- **Scheduled exports** (push to Google Calendar, Apple Calendar, etc.)
    
- Optional: **email notifications or digests**
    

> üìç Goal: Create infrastructure for reusable logic and automatic task surfacing.

---

### üîπ **Phase 3: Multi-Domain, Multi-Tier Model**

Build out a full schema for:

- `Domain` (Flying, Piano, Admin, etc.)
    
- `Goal` (e.g., ‚ÄúMaintain IFR currency‚Äù)
    
- `Project`
    
- `Milestone`
    
- `Block`
    
- `Microtask` (optional)
    
- `Check-in` or `Reflection` (for journaling or logging)
    

Structure tables with:

- Relationships (e.g., block belongs to project)
    
- Status, timestamps, deadlines
    
- Metadata (tags, duration, cognitive load, etc.)
    

Build a dashboard or interface (e.g., Streamlit app, Notion views, Flask web UI).

> üìç Goal: Full system-wide visibility and planning capability.

---

### üîπ **Phase 4: Bi-Directional Integration**

Now interface in both directions with calendar and task tools:

- Pull existing calendar events ‚Üí suggest matching domain blocks
    
- Push generated blocks or reminders to calendar
    
- Optional: link to task systems like Todoist, Apple Reminders, Google Tasks
    

> üìç Goal: Seamless flow between your planning system and execution tools.

---

### üîπ **Phase 5: Smart Features and Dashboards**

Now the system can:

- Visualize time spent by domain or block type
    
- Detect ‚Äúneglected‚Äù goals
    
- Highlight overbooked weeks
    
- Propose tasks based on time/energy/context
    
- Use AI to suggest breakdowns for goals/projects (optional)
    

Could involve:

- Charts via Python (e.g., matplotlib, pandas, Streamlit)
    
- Chat-style input (e.g., ‚ÄúWhat should I do next?‚Äù)
    
- Command-line or app-based interface
    

> üìç Goal: Personalized productivity assistant powered by your own structure.

---

## üß± Example Schema (Simplified)

|Table|Key Fields|
|---|---|
|`Domains`|name, priority, engagement rhythm|
|`Goals`|title, domain_id, timeframe, success_criteria|
|`Projects`|title, goal_id, start_date, due_date, status|
|`Milestones`|title, project_id, order, due_date, completed_at|
|`Blocks`|title, milestone_id, effort_size, date, status|
|`Logs`|block_id, completed_at, reflection_text|

---

## ‚úÖ Starting Today:

You can start **Phase 1 and Phase 2 in parallel**:

- Spreadsheet tracker for a real domain (like healthcare or finances)
    
- Begin designing the schema and a local SQLite or Notion DB
    
- Write one script that syncs a block from the DB ‚Üí your calendar
