# Goal


Checklist_maker -> generates a checklist, from a database.
- i.e. creates a workout, creates a packing checklist, creates a task checklist, etc from data.

# Description
[[Feature 8 - Navigable Tree Structure]]

Here are **five different MVP options** for the Tree of Becoming that can deliver **immediate usefulness**. Each is scoped narrowly, has a tight feedback loop, and can evolve into the full system over time. You can treat these like alternate first paths‚Äîpick one, and it becomes the seed crystal.

---

## üîß **Option 1: Life Pattern Tracker (Execution MVP)**

> **Start from your existing Google Sheet. Turn logs into structured insights.**
### Core Idea:
Import your daily action logs (e.g. ‚Äúbrushed teeth‚Äù, ‚Äúwalked 20 min‚Äù) and map them to a lightweight **Skill Tree**. Use this to:
- Track streaks
- See life domain balance (e.g. hygiene vs fitness vs cooking)
- Export weekly summaries
### Immediate Value:
- Awareness of habits + blind spots
- Encouragement via visible consistency
- Launchpad for planning (‚Äúwhere do I want to shift effort?‚Äù)

---

## üåø **Option 2: Weekly Planning + Skill Surfacing (Planner MVP)**

> **Use the tree to _choose_ what to work on each week.**
### Core Idea:
Each week, you pick a few nodes from your Skill or Product Tree and schedule them (like a menu). Use checkboxes and logs to track completion.
### Immediate Value:
- Tactical focus without overwhelming scope
- Builds habit of selecting from intentional categories
- You get a weekly plan, and a way to reflect at the end
---

## üß† **Option 3: "I Did This‚ÄîWhat Did It Build?" (Reverse Mapper MVP)**

> **Every time you do something, tag which skills or products it contributed to.**
### Core Idea:
You don‚Äôt start with trees‚Äîyou build them _backwards_ from actions. Log what you did, and tag what it grew:
- ‚ÄúWrote flight log‚Äù ‚Üí Skill: Data Hygiene / Product: Pilot Log
- ‚ÄúCleaned kitchen‚Äù ‚Üí Skill: Domestic Flow / Goal: Calm Home
### Immediate Value:
- Visibility into what you're actually cultivating
- Deepens sense of meaning behind everyday effort
- Helps you form your trees based on _lived structure_

---

## üéØ **Option 4: One Product Tracker (Single-Node MVP)**

> **Pick one product (e.g., a dashboard, a song arrangement, a meal plan) and build a micro-system around it.**
### Core Idea:
Track only one thing you‚Äôre building‚Äîjust one product node. Attach:
- Skill requirements (linked tree)
- Logs of what you‚Äôve done
- Checklist of tasks
- Reflection thread(s)
### Immediate Value:
- Immediate structure around a real effort
- Fast feedback on how Skill ‚Üî Product linkage helps
- Scales easily into more nodes later
---

## üß≠ **Option 5: Narrative + Tree Mapper (Thread MVP)**

> **You live a week. You write a thread. You tag the tree. That‚Äôs it.**
### Core Idea:
At the end of each week (or day), write a short freeform reflection. Then tag which skills/products/goals were touched. These become:
- Thread logs
- Tree updates
- Cross-domain storylines
### Immediate Value:
- Emotional coherence + structured memory
- Great for identity-building, review, course-correction
- High ROI even without much infrastructure
---
## üß™ Which One‚Äôs Right for You?

|Option|Best If...|
|---|---|
|1. Execution Tracker|You already track stuff and want quick insights now|
|2. Weekly Planner|You crave structure but don‚Äôt want a rigid system|
|3. Reverse Mapper|You live organically and want to _surface structure_|
|4. One Product Focus|You‚Äôre deep in one project and want to organize effort|
|5. Narrative Threads|You reflect often and want to make it systematic|

# ChatGPT The Architect 2025-07-26
**Conrad said**
Let's say if I want to make an app (in a perfect world it would have an iphone, ipad, and web version). I want users to be able to log in and have their own data. I currently have a prototype working in streamlit. Walk me through, from a high-level perspective what tools I would need, at a minimum, to accomplish my goal.

###### ChatGPT said:

Perfect. You‚Äôre crossing the threshold from **prototype hacker** to **real product architect.** Let‚Äôs talk **what you need**, without bloated buzzwords or 50 AWS services you don‚Äôt want.

---

## üéØ Your Goal

> ‚úÖ Multi-platform app (web + iOS + iPad)  
> ‚úÖ User accounts and private data  
> ‚úÖ Existing prototype in Streamlit  
> ‚úÖ Maintain a great UX for logging things like workouts, procedures, and checklists

So here‚Äôs what you need at a **minimum**‚Äîby category.

---

## üß† 1. **Frontend Interface (UI Layer)**

### ‚úÖ **Current: Streamlit (for Web)**

- Good for MVPs and internal tools
    
- Fast to build
    
- Bad at real mobile support, no native iOS app
    

### üîÅ To support **iPhone + iPad + Web**, you need:

#### Option A: **Flutter**

- ‚úÖ Cross-platform (iOS, Android, Web)
    
- ‚úÖ Single codebase in Dart
    
- ‚úÖ Beautiful UI, works well for apps with lots of forms and checklists
    
- ‚ùó Requires learning Dart
    

#### Option B: **React + React Native**

- ‚úÖ React for Web, React Native for iOS/iPadOS
    
- ‚úÖ Reuse components across platforms
    
- ‚úÖ Huge ecosystem
    
- ‚ùó More plumbing needed (navigation, storage, etc.)
    

---

## üîê 2. **User Authentication (Login System)**

You‚Äôll need to:

- Sign up / Log in
    
- Store user accounts
    
- Restrict access to each user‚Äôs data
    

### ‚úÖ Options:

- **Firebase Authentication** ‚Äì Easiest to integrate across web/mobile
    
- **Auth0** ‚Äì Great for scalability, a bit heavier
    
- **Supabase Auth** ‚Äì Open-source Firebase alternative
    

---

## üóÉÔ∏è 3. **Database (User Data Storage)**

You need per-user data isolation and storage.

### ‚úÖ Options:

- **Firebase Firestore** ‚Äì Scalable, fast, real-time sync, mobile-friendly
    
- **Supabase (Postgres)** ‚Äì More SQL power, open-source
    
- **PlanetScale or Railway + Prisma** ‚Äì If you prefer SQL + custom backend
    

---

## üß† 4. **Backend (API + Logic Layer)**

In a real app, you‚Äôll likely need an API layer for:

- Authenticating users
    
- Reading/writing structured data
    
- Running business logic
    

### ‚úÖ Options:

- **Supabase** (Postgres + API out of the box)
    
- **Firebase** (uses Firestore + cloud functions)
    
- **FastAPI or Django REST** ‚Äì If you want a custom backend in Python
    

---

## ‚òÅÔ∏è 5. **Hosting & Deployment**

### ‚úÖ Options:

- **Streamlit sharing / Hugging Face Spaces** ‚Äì MVP only
    
- **Vercel or Netlify** ‚Äì If React-based frontend
    
- **Firebase Hosting** ‚Äì If using Firebase
    
- **Heroku / Railway / Fly.io** ‚Äì Quick backend + DB deployments
    

---

## üß© 6. **Minimum Tech Stack Example**

Let‚Äôs say you go full Firebase:

- **Frontend:** Flutter (Dart)
    
- **Auth:** Firebase Auth
    
- **Database:** Firebase Firestore
    
- **Hosting:** Firebase Hosting
    
- **Mobile Support:** Flutter builds for iOS, iPadOS, Web
    

Or if you like Python:

- **Frontend:** React (web) + Expo (React Native for mobile)
    
- **Backend API:** FastAPI
    
- **Auth + DB:** Supabase (with Postgres)
    
- **Deployment:** Vercel (frontend), Railway (backend)
    

---

## ‚ú® High-Level Flow (for your app)

pgsql

CopyEdit

`User opens app (web/iOS) ‚Üì Auth system (Firebase or Supabase) logs them in ‚Üì UI shows data fetched via API (or directly from DB if using client SDK) ‚Üì User creates log ‚Üí data saved under their user ID ‚Üì Procedures/checklists/etc shown only for their account`

---

## ‚ö° TL;DR ‚Äî What You _Need_ (Minimum Viable Tech Stack)

|Function|Tool (Minimal Option)|
|---|---|
|UI (Web + iOS/iPad)|Flutter or React + React Native|
|Auth|Firebase Auth or Supabase|
|Database|Firestore or Supabase (Postgres)|
|Backend/API|Firebase Functions or FastAPI|
|Hosting|Firebase, Vercel, or Railway|

‚úÖ You can swap Streamlit in short-term for MVP testing.  
‚úÖ Long-term: move logic and data to reusable backend + structured DB.

---

If you want:

- A tailored stack recommendation based on your current code
    
- A visual architecture diagram
    
- Help designing auth + database schema
    

Say the word, and we‚Äôll architect your path to greatness.

**Description**
An agent that runs in the background (or at night) and:
- Grabs all new ChatGPT chats since last time it ran - query and response.
- Organizes them into the tree of knowledge, e.g.:
	- maybe I'm asking about some python thing, then it puts it into the python skill tree as a reference.
	- maybe I'm asking "how would I implement such and such feature" and it would make draft descriptions for that feature and link to the technical work that has started.
- Estimates effort and value.

I want the humanoid to:
- Cook - ok but which recipe? and do I have the ingredients?
- Coach me for my workout - ok, how do we plan the session?

body:
# Description
Functionality to review procedure metadata e.g.:
	- What procedures exist?
	- Which have been executed (ever)?
	- When was the last time they got executed?
	- What is the projected execution time?
	- What's the lastest version of the procedure? 
		- Has this *version* of the procedure been executed?
			- i.e. has the procedure changed since it was last executed?
				- What is the relative risk of this procedure being executable, at all? 
				- What does this imply about projected execution time?
	- How many times total has this procedure been executed since it's creation?
	- Where does this procedure get used? 
		- Is it a subprocess in another procedure?

Impacted Components:
- Bifr√∂st
- Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf
- M√≠misbrunnr
- Obsidian <-> M√≠misbrunnr data io

what's the best way to turn a list of obsidian tasks (with checkboxes) to and from a database table? I'm trying to formulate how to: (1) make a procedure in obsidian, (2) instantiate an instance of that procedure, (3) capture the results, number of tasks completed, notes etc. in a database

###### ChatGPT said:

You‚Äôre describing something **beautifully structured**: turning Obsidian's markdown-based task system into a **procedural engine** with **database-backed tracking**. Let‚Äôs break it down:

---

## üß† Summary of What You Want

|Step|Goal|
|---|---|
|1Ô∏è‚É£|Define a reusable **procedure** in Obsidian (a list of tasks).|
|2Ô∏è‚É£|**Instantiate** that procedure (a run or execution).|
|3Ô∏è‚É£|Track **task completion**, results, notes, and store that in a **database**.|

---

## ‚úÖ Recommended Architecture

### üìÅ In Obsidian

#### 1. **Procedure Templates**

Each procedure is just a note:

markdown

CopyEdit

`--- type: procedure title: Whip Egg Whites id: whip_egg_whites version: 1.0 tags: [cooking, egg] ---  - [ ] Gather two bowls and whisk - [ ] Crack and separate 3 eggs - [ ] Place whites in one bowl - [ ] Whip whites until soft peaks`

#### 2. **Procedure Run Notes**

When you instantiate a procedure:

markdown

CopyEdit

`--- type: procedure_run procedure_id: whip_egg_whites run_id: whip_egg_whites_2025-07-17 started: 2025-07-17T09:02 notes: "" ---  - [x] Gather two bowls and whisk - [x] Crack and separate 3 eggs - [x] Place whites in one bowl - [ ] Whip whites until soft peaks`

---

### üßÆ In the Database (e.g., SQLite, PostgreSQL, or even Pandas CSV)

You‚Äôll want at least **three tables**:

#### `procedures`

|id|title|version|tag(s)|
|---|---|---|---|
|whip_egg_whites|Whip Egg Whites|1.0|cooking|

#### `procedure_tasks`

|procedure_id|sequence|task_description|
|---|---|---|
|whip_egg_whites|1|Gather two bowls and whisk|
|whip_egg_whites|2|Crack and separate 3 eggs|

#### `procedure_runs`

|run_id|procedure_id|started|completed_tasks|total_tasks|notes|
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
|whip_egg_whites_2025-07-17|whip_egg_whites|2025-07-17T09:02|3|4|...|

---

## üîÅ Transforming To/From Obsidian ‚Üî Database

### üîΩ From Obsidian ‚Üí DB

Write a Python script that:

1. Scans Obsidian notes (e.g. with `frontmatter` + `markdown` parsing).
    
2. For `type: procedure`, populate the `procedures` + `procedure_tasks` tables.
    
3. For `type: procedure_run`, extract the run ID, timestamp, number of `- [x]` vs `- [ ]`, and store in `procedure_runs`.
    

You could use `re` or `markdown-it-py` or even `obsidian-html` tools to parse tasks.

### üîº From DB ‚Üí Obsidian

To instantiate a run:

1. Select a procedure from the DB.
    
2. Create a new markdown file from a Jinja template.
    
3. Populate with tasks from `procedure_tasks`, and new frontmatter for the `procedure_run`.
    

---

## ‚ú® Why This Works Well

- Keeps Obsidian as your **human-editable front-end**.
    
- Lets your DB be your **powerful backend** for analytics, stats, and cross-referencing.
    
- You can later layer in logic for:
    
    - Auto-tagging procedures
        
    - Scheduling based on last run
        
    - Aggregated performance over time
        

---

## üß† Bonus: Logging Execution Data

Add fields like:

- `time_started`
    
- `time_completed`
    
- `tools_used`
    
- `problems_encountered`
    

To start building a real **execution log + analytics engine**.

---

Want me to generate:

- The Python parser skeleton?
    
- A JSON schema for the DB tables?
    
- A sample Obsidian‚Äì‚Üî‚ÄìDB sync tool?
    

Just say the word.

##### You said:

yes. Generate the python parser skeleton and explain in detail how the jinja template would work.

###### ChatGPT said:

Looks like I can‚Äôt install packages right now due to a temporary internet issue. But let me move forward with what _you_ can do locally, and explain the **Jinja template** logic too.

---

## üß± What You Now Have

A Python parser that:

- Reads your Obsidian vault.
    
- Identifies notes with `type: procedure` and `type: procedure_run`.
    
- Extracts task lists and metadata.
    
- Outputs structured CSVs.
    

---

## ‚ú® What‚Äôs Next: Jinja Template for Procedure Instantiation

When you want to **instantiate a new run** of a procedure (say, ‚ÄúWhip Egg Whites‚Äù), you can use a **Jinja template** to generate the markdown.

### üß™ Example Jinja Template

jinja

CopyEdit

`--- type: procedure_run procedure_id: {{ procedure_id }} run_id: {{ run_id }} started: {{ started }} notes: "" ---  {% for task in tasks %} - [ ] {{ task }} {% endfor %}`

---

### üß† How to Use It in Python

python

CopyEdit

`from jinja2 import Template from datetime import datetime  template_str = """ --- type: procedure_run procedure_id: {{ procedure_id }} run_id: {{ run_id }} started: {{ started }} notes: "" ---  {% for task in tasks %} - [ ] {{ task }} {% endfor %} """  template = Template(template_str)  rendered = template.render(     procedure_id="whip_egg_whites",     run_id="whip_egg_whites_2025-07-17",     started=datetime.now().isoformat(timespec='minutes'),     tasks=[         "Gather two bowls and whisk",         "Crack and separate 3 eggs",         "Place whites in one bowl",         "Whip whites until soft peaks"     ] )  with open("whip_egg_whites_2025-07-17.md", "w") as f:     f.write(rendered)`

You can run this to generate a run note that‚Äôs perfectly compatible with Obsidian and will show up in your dashboards.

---

## üîÅ Recap Workflow

|Step|Action|
|---|---|
|‚úÖ Define Procedure|In markdown with tasks|
|ü™Ñ Instantiate|Use Jinja + Python to create a new run|
|üìä Track|Script parses vault, counts tasks, logs metadata|
|üîó Sync|(Later) link this to Product Tree, Skill Tree, etc.|

---

Let me know if you want:

- A CLI tool that does this with flags
    
- Export to SQLite or JSON instead of CSV
    
- Integration with your existing Streamlit visualizer
    

You're dangerously close to a full-featured lightweight LIMS (lab information mgmt system) for _your life_.

file_path: /home/conrad/git/yggdrasill/prod_tree/yggdrasill/user_stories/User Story 1 - Filterable Trees/tasks/Task 2 - Yggdrassill v2 User Story 1.md
body:
# Goal
Get [[SW-P-6 Acceptance Test]] to pass.

# Method
Use Runestones.

# Description
Defines the app

# Usage	
- Features: 
	- By default loads and displays tree.csv as a tree.
	- Allows to filter the tree based on the status field.

# Description
Initial demo csv - at a minimum, needs to contain the fields: 
- name
- parent
- status

# Usage
 The tree will be built from the name and parent fields and filtered on the status field.

# Goal
Check to see if the user story is complete.

# Steps
**Optional Setup Steps**
- [ ] [[SW-P-01 Start Spyder]]
- [ ] [[SW-P-5 Start Streamlit App]] with  [[User Story 1 - Filterable Trees#app.py]]

**Check**
- [ ] Does the tree show up in the streamlit app?
- [ ] Does the structure of the tree (in broad terms) appear to match the structure of the csv

I want the user to be able to go to a "developer tab" and say things like:
- "I wish there was a button that does X" -> and the app makes you a version of itself that has that feature.
- Obviously they should be able to share this version of the app with their friends.

Example from cooking - 

I set parameters:
- Food allergies - 
- Nutrition goals - 
- Time (hrs) spent a week cooking - 
- What equipment I have - 
- My cooking skills - chopping, boil eggs
- How many separate cooking sessions I want to have? (how many leftovers I'm happy with)
- How adventurous I am (for recipe and ingredient choices)?
- What ingredients I like
- Meal planning windows - 1 meal, 1 month?

Then I push a "plan meals" button -> it shows me the plan.
- I can iterate on this with my parameters.
- Once I'm ready, I can make the shopping list.

"Make shopping list" button -> makes the list.
- I can tell it what I have in stock already -> if I always use it, then it knows already

"Order" -> it can place the orders, from multiple sources if required.
- I can tell it my favorite stores.
- It can give me a "walking map" around the store.

Walks me through the recipe step by step

There is a "feedback mode" where, after I cook the recipe, what I cooked, it can coach me through adding skills etc
- I can tell it if I liked the recipes, and it can adjust.
- It still works without the feedback, but obviously it won't update the skill parameters

**Description**
There are two relevant Obsidian fields: (1) parent, and (2) parent_link.

The parent_link is intended to be a "live" obsidian link. This is great for the developer because you can click around Obsidian. However, because of the syntax of the link, i.e. 
```
"[[SOME LINK]]"
```
it doesn't play nice with the tree reader. In short, the tree reader can't find the parent because it's looking for the name of the parent note (without the square brackets).

What's really good about the linking though, is that it updates live.

**Note**
It's worth mentioning that creating the parent from the parent_link, instead of vice versa, is good because the links update automatically, in Obsidian, if the name of the issue changes.

**Solution**
There are basically two (obvious) options to solve this:
1. In the tree builder (that makes the csv), we parse out the name, i.e. remove the square brackets, or
2. Before constructing the tree, we read the parent link and parse out the name into the *parent* field. I like this because:
	1. You can easily see both the parent_link and the parent in any given note. And they should match
	- Downside: an extra field. Also, if you have code to parse it back into the note, it seems like you'd be able to just parse it into the tree builder anyways.

# Feature Summary
For each product, track parent-child relationship so as to construct a tree.
- Each product shall only have one parent
- The one exception is the root node
# Version Implementation
v0 - obsidian note property ‚Äúparent‚Äù. 
- See [[Ygg 2 - R1 product parent existence]]

# Feature Summary
For each product, track product status (proposed,in-work,complete) 
# Feature Description

# Feature Summary
Longest term: 
- runs [[SW-P-2 Obsidian Sanitization]]
- runs [[Script - Obsidian folders -> Tree.csv]]
# Feature Description
Runs as a python script in GitHub actions.

body:
# Goal Summary

Goal: To always have funds available

Therefore, we need a way to:
1. See what payments are scheduled.
	1. Have, at the bare minimum, an estimate for the non-fixed expenses
2. See which payments have been processed already 
	- Rationale - It can depend on day of week etc, so just because the calendar says June 22nd, it could be June 19th, therefore it's already been paid and we don't need to make sure we are covering it.
3. Sum up the schedule payments to verify that the account balance will cover them (with some predefined buffer, e.g. $300)
4. Related task -> Move money around to cover expenses with the correct buffer.
	- If there is too much, put the extra into savings.
	- If there is not enough, move from savings.

# Feature Description

file_name: Feature 7 - yggdrasill tree display names non-unique.md
body:
Is there a way to use this script, but have the display names, in the animated tree, different from the actual parent child link structures

###### ChatGPT said:

Yes, absolutely‚Äîyou can decouple the **display name** (what shows up in the animated tree) from the **logical `__filename` and `parent` structure** used to build the tree.

---

## ‚úÖ You Just Need to Add a ‚ÄúDisplay Name‚Äù Field

### Step 1: Modify Your Output Rows

In your `load_obsidian_tree_by_folder.py` script, add a `display_name` field alongside `__filename`.

Here's what to change in **both folder and note sections**:

### üîß For folders:

python

CopyEdit

`output_rows.append({     "__filename": name,     "parent": parent,     "type": "folder",     "display_name": f"[FOLDER] {name}"  # or whatever you want })`

### üîß For notes:

python

CopyEdit

`all_props["__filename"] = md_file.stem all_props["parent"] = parent all_props["type"] = "note" all_props["display_name"] = all_props.get("title", md_file.stem)  # default to stem if no title`

This way:

- You still build the tree using `__filename` and `parent`
    
- But show users the friendlier `display_name`
    

---

### Step 2: Update Your Streamlit App / HTML Renderer

In your `collapsible-tree-template.html` or wherever you‚Äôre converting to JSON, update the D3 label generator:

#### Before (probably):

javascript

CopyEdit

`.text(function (d) { return d.data.name; })`

#### After:

javascript

CopyEdit

`.text(function (d) { return d.data.display_name || d.data.name; })`

Or if you're passing JSON already with `display_name`, set the tree data like:

javascript

CopyEdit

`name: node["__filename"], display_name: node["display_name"], ...`

Then you use `display_name` in rendering, and let the hidden `__filename` keep the structure intact.

---

## üß† Summary

|Purpose|Field|
|---|---|
|Tree structure|`__filename`, `parent`|
|Visual label|`display_name`|

---

Let me know if you want help adjusting the CSV writer or the JSON injection in `animated.py`. You‚Äôre very close.

# Feature Summary
For each note, be able to see how much of the tree (ie how much value, how many notes etc) doing a particular task would unlock.

# Feature Description

# Goal Summary

# Feature Description

It "would be nice" to be able to refer to dates relative to an event. 
- i.e. buy this 7 days before this trip

It's annoying to have to look up the dates in the calendar.

**Conrad said**
as an initial demonstration, I want to call the "database api" to get the contents of the csv trees here, instead of loading them from disk. Can you help?

###### ChatGPT said:

Perfect. You're currently reading CSVs directly from disk using:

python

CopyEdit

`df = pd.read_csv(some_path)`

But you want to **replace that with calls to your "database API"** to fetch the same tree data‚Äîlikely via HTTP requests to an endpoint that returns the CSV data or structured tree data.

---

## ‚úÖ Minimal Refactor Plan

Let‚Äôs assume your backend API has endpoints like:

pgsql

CopyEdit

`GET /api/tree?type=parent GET /api/tree?type=prerequisite GET /api/tree?type=driven_by GET /api/tree?type=template`

And it returns the CSV content as plain text or JSON.

---

## üîß Replace File Load With API Call

### Step 1: Add a helper function

At the top of your file:

python

CopyEdit

`import requests  def load_csv_from_api(tree_type: str) -> pd.DataFrame:     url = f"http://your-api-domain.com/api/tree?type={tree_type}"     response = requests.get(url)     response.raise_for_status()     return pd.read_csv(StringIO(response.text)).convert_dtypes()`

---

### Step 2: Replace `pd.read_csv(...)` calls

Instead of:

python

CopyEdit

`df2 = pd.read_csv(parent_tree_path).convert_dtypes()`

Do:

python

CopyEdit

`df2 = load_csv_from_api("parent")`

Apply the same to the other tree types:

python

CopyEdit

`df3 = load_csv_from_api("prerequisite") df  = load_csv_from_api("driven_by") df4 = load_csv_from_api("template")`

---

### Optional: Add a local/remote toggle

If you want to fall back to local files during dev:

python

CopyEdit

`USE_API = True  def get_tree_df(tree_type, local_path):     if USE_API:         return load_csv_from_api(tree_type)     else:         return pd.read_csv(local_path).convert_dtypes()`

Then call:

python

CopyEdit

`df2 = get_tree_df("parent", parent_tree_path)`

---

## üß† Interface Expectations for the API

Each endpoint should return either:

- Raw CSV string (`Content-Type: text/csv`)
    
- OR JSON if you're ready to handle `pd.DataFrame.from_records(...)` instead
    

---

## ‚úÖ TL;DR

- Wrap your API fetch in `load_csv_from_api()`
    
- Replace local `read_csv()` calls with that
    
- Use `StringIO(response.text)` to parse CSV from raw response
    
- Optional: add fallback to local files for dev
    

---

Want help writing a FastAPI or Flask endpoint that returns the tree data? Just say the word and I‚Äôll generate it.

##### You said:

yes. Which will be easier? FastAPI or Flask endpoint? Do I need to run this as a service continously?

###### ChatGPT said:

**FastAPI. No contest.**

Here‚Äôs the direct answer:

---

## ‚úÖ Use **FastAPI** over Flask

|Feature|FastAPI|Flask|
|---|---|---|
|Async support|‚úÖ Built-in (first-class)|üî¥ Add-ons or hacks required|
|Data validation|‚úÖ Pydantic-powered|üî¥ Manual or 3rd-party|
|Auto-generated docs|‚úÖ `/docs` and `/redoc` by default|‚ùå Requires plugins like Flask-RESTX|
|Developer experience|‚úÖ Type-safe, clear, modern|üî∂ Classic but verbose|
|Performance|‚úÖ Faster out of the box|üî∂ Good, but not optimized natively|

FastAPI gives you:

- Clean async endpoints
    
- Input/output validation
    
- Automatic OpenAPI docs
    
- Less boilerplate
    
- Easier scaling
    

---

## üõ†Ô∏è Do You Need to Run It Continuously?

**Yes**, but don't panic‚Äîit just means:

> **You need to run it as a lightweight web service** when your frontend (e.g. Streamlit) needs to access tree data.

This can be:

- A local dev service (`uvicorn main:app`)
    
- A background process on a server
    
- Hosted via Render, Railway, Fly.io, etc.
    

**No need to "deploy" at scale** yet‚Äîjust `uvicorn` it for local or internal use.

---

## üß™ Minimal Working FastAPI Tree Server

python

CopyEdit

`# tree_api.py from fastapi import FastAPI, Query from fastapi.responses import PlainTextResponse import pandas as pd  app = FastAPI()  TREE_FILES = {     "parent": "data/parent_tree.csv",     "prerequisite": "data/prereq_tree.csv",     "driven_by": "data/driven_by_tree.csv",     "template": "data/template_tree.csv" }  @app.get("/api/tree", response_class=PlainTextResponse) def get_tree(type: str = Query(..., description="Type of tree")):     if type not in TREE_FILES:         return PlainTextResponse("Invalid tree type", status_code=400)     df = pd.read_csv(TREE_FILES[type])     return df.to_csv(index=False)`

### Run it with:

bash

CopyEdit

`uvicorn tree_api:app --reload`

Then fetch from your frontend like:

python

CopyEdit

`response = requests.get("http://localhost:8000/api/tree?type=parent")`

---

## ‚ö° TL;DR

‚úÖ Use **FastAPI**‚Äîeasier, cleaner, more powerful  
‚úÖ Yes, run it as a service (locally or hosted)  
‚úÖ You can `uvicorn` this on your dev machine or use a cloud service when ready  
‚úÖ One script + one command = done

---

Want me to extend this to support JSON or add CORS so Streamlit doesn‚Äôt complain? Say the word.

body:
# Description

I need to build a navigable tree structure, for humans and AI, that includes:
- Formal definition of "where things should go", incl.:
	- disambiguation
	- deterministic addressing
	- types and where they belong, i.e. task vs feature, documentation vs decision

Against this navigable structure I can build:
- Programmatic context retrieval -> i.e. "I am defining a task and need to aggregate all the related materials, how do I go out, into the tree, and find what I need?"
- Enforcement -> QA that makes sure their aren't any orphans, that field values are consistent, that obsidian project folder definitions are valid etc etc.
- Client operations -> 
	- create new items ("task", "component", "feature") and make sure it's properly linked etc.
	- bulk edit values, i.e. all notes, in a particular obsidian folder get a certain value for a certain property.
	- Make trees based on different attributes -> types, parent, etc

file_name: obsidian_tools feature - find note by property.md
body:
make a python function that finds all the notes in an obsidian repo where a particular property has a particular value

###### ChatGPT said:

Here's a clean and simple Python function that searches an **Obsidian vault** for all notes where a given **YAML frontmatter property** has a particular value.

---

### ‚úÖ Function: `find_notes_by_property`

python

CopyEdit

`import os import frontmatter  def find_notes_by_property(vault_path, property_name, target_value):     matching_notes = []      for root, _, files in os.walk(vault_path):         for file in files:             if not file.endswith(".md"):                 continue              file_path = os.path.join(root, file)              try:                 with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:                     post = frontmatter.load(f)             except Exception as e:                 print(f"Error reading {file_path}: {e}")                 continue              if post.metadata.get(property_name) == target_value:                 matching_notes.append({                     "path": file_path,                     "filename": os.path.splitext(file)[0],                     "metadata": post.metadata,                     "content": post.content.strip()                 })      return matching_notes`

---

### üß™ Example usage:

python

CopyEdit

`vault = "/Users/conrad/Obsidian/Vault" matches = find_notes_by_property(vault, "status", "in_progress")  for note in matches:     print(note["filename"], "-", note["path"])`

Different functionality categories:
- Read stuff from the vault
	- Aggregate items for the trees.
	- Filter
- Edit items in the vault
	- Assign parents and/or fill out fields

**Eventually:**
Component A: 
- Feature A -> maps to Pain Point A
- Feature B -> maps to Pain Point B
- Feature B -> maps to Paint Point A

I am making an obsidian-python interface class/module. It needs to be able to (1) crawl an obsidian folder structure, (2) create yaml parent-child trees from obsidian folder structure, based on obsidian frontmatter properties (3) create mermaid diagrams (i.e. gantt, flowcharts etc) based on the folder structure and frontmatter properties. Recommend an approach.

###### ChatGPT said:

You're basically building a high-octane Obsidian-interop engine. To keep things scalable and composable, here's a battle-tested modular approach that will give you power, flexibility, and clarity.

---

## üß† High-Level Modules

Break this into **three core components**, and make them composable:

### 1. `VaultCrawler`: _Walk the folder tree and parse markdown files_

- **Input**: path to vault
    
- **Output**: list of markdown files and metadata
    

**Features**:

- Recursively walk directories
    
- Parse each file:
    
    - Get file path, folder, and filename
        
    - Parse frontmatter YAML (use [`python-frontmatter`](https://github.com/eyeseast/python-frontmatter))
        
    - Return structured Python dict per file:
        
        python
        
        CopyEdit
        
        `{   "path": "path/to/file.md",   "folder": "Weekly Plans",   "filename": "2025-08-01",   "frontmatter": {       "status": "in_progress",       "parent": "July",       ...   } }`
        

---

### 2. `VaultTreeBuilder`: _Construct trees from metadata_

- **Input**: list of parsed notes from `VaultCrawler`
    
- **Output**: structured trees (dictionaries or graph objects)
    

**Supports**:

- `parent` relationships from frontmatter
    
- Fallback to using folder structure if `parent` not defined
    
- Build trees using:
    
    - Dict of `{id: children}`
        
    - Or use `networkx` if you want to go full graph
        

Bonus: support alternative hierarchies (e.g., by `status`, `type`, `date`) for different mermaid views.

---

### 3. `MermaidRenderer`: _Render trees into Mermaid syntax_

- **Input**: structured trees
    
- **Output**: Mermaid text blocks for Obsidian
    

**Supports**:

- `gantt` charts
    
- `flowchart TD` / `graph TD`
    
- Custom coloring based on frontmatter (`status`, `type`, etc.)
    

Example:

mermaid

CopyEdit

`graph TD   A[Start] --> B[Planning]   B --> C{Status}   C -->|done| D[Complete]   C -->|in_progress| E[Working]`

---

## üõ† Suggested Structure

bash

CopyEdit

`/obsidian_interface/ ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ vault_crawler.py       # Class: VaultCrawler ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tree_builder.py        # Class: VaultTreeBuilder ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mermaid_renderer.py    # Class: MermaidRenderer ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ __init__.py ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ utils.py               # Shared helpers`

---

## üîÅ Example Usage

python

CopyEdit

`from obsidian_interface.vault_crawler import VaultCrawler from obsidian_interface.tree_builder import VaultTreeBuilder from obsidian_interface.mermaid_renderer import MermaidRenderer  vault = VaultCrawler("/Users/conrad/Obsidian/MyVault") parsed_notes = vault.parse()  tree = VaultTreeBuilder(parsed_notes) gantt_tree = tree.build_by_parent_fallback_folder() flow_tree = tree.build_by_status()  mermaid = MermaidRenderer() print(mermaid.render_gantt(gantt_tree)) print(mermaid.render_flowchart(flow_tree))`

---

## üß© Optional Enhancements

- Cache results using `pickle` or `joblib` if your vault is large
    
- Add CLI: `python interface.py --gantt Weekly`
    
- Add Streamlit preview module
    
- Add reverse mode: update frontmatter from Mermaid input
    

---

## ‚ö° Final Tip

Decouple **data gathering**, **structure building**, and **visual rendering**. That gives you flexibility to plug in other formats like CSV, JSON, or even export to other apps.

Let me know if you want a starter template with all three classes wired up.

I‚Äôm interested in automatically generating diagrams for a python repo. For example, the logic of a ci build sequence and/or a diagram of when a user does a specific thing, what the sequence of function calls is that makes that happen etc etc. I was notionally planning to make a thing that makes mermaid diagrams (maybe with ChatGPT api in the loop). But if there are existing tools, that might be easier. What do you think?

###### ChatGPT said:

Ah yes‚Äîyou‚Äôve wandered into the **Legendary Dungeon of Code Visualization**, where the dragons are broken call graphs and unreadable sequence charts. But you‚Äôre thinking the right way.

Let‚Äôs break it down:

---

## üéØ Your Goal

Automatically generate **diagrams** (e.g., Mermaid, PlantUML, etc.) that represent:

1. **CI/CD build sequences**
    
2. **Runtime execution flows (user interaction ‚Üí function call ‚Üí result)**
    

You‚Äôre even open to automating it with GPT in the loop (üí™ love it), but want to know if anything easier already exists.

---

## üß∞ Existing Tools (That Actually Work)

### ‚úÖ 1. **[pyan3](https://github.com/omni-us/pyan)**

- Generates **call graphs** from Python code
    
- Outputs `.dot` files (Graphviz), which you can convert to Mermaid or images
    
- Static analysis‚Äîno need to run the code
    
- Simple to use:
    
    bash
    
    CopyEdit
    
    `pyan3 your_module.py --dot > output.dot`
    

**You can then write a converter: `.dot` ‚Üí Mermaid graph**

---

### ‚úÖ 2. **pyreverse (part of pylint)**

- Generates **class and package diagrams**
    
- Command line:
    
    bash
    
    CopyEdit
    
    `pyreverse -o png your_package/`
    
- More useful for structure (UML class diagrams) than for runtime flow
    

---

### ‚úÖ 3. **snekbox + Mermaid + GPT** (DIY but sexy)

If you want to go semi-automatic:

- Crawl the repo
    
- Extract function names and docstrings
    
- Use GPT to generate `mermaid sequenceDiagram` or `flowchart` code
    
- Render using Mermaid live or embedded
    

**You can fine-tune this pipeline for:**

- CI logic flows (from YAML or shell script)
    
- UI-triggered runtime sequences
    
- Domain-specific flows (e.g. tree building, task surfacing)
    

---

### ‚úÖ 4. **[Code2Flow](https://github.com/scottrogowski/code2flow)**

- Python tool that creates flowcharts from code
    
- Can generate `.dot` or `.png`
    
- Works best on simple logic blocks
    

---

### ‚úÖ 5. **PlantUML + Scripting**

- Write function call chains in PlantUML syntax
    
- Some tools (like `pycallgraph2`) can generate PlantUML directly
    
- Not as human-readable as Mermaid, but powerful
    

---

## ü§ñ GPT-in-the-Loop: Where It Shines

If you're thinking:

> ‚ÄúUser clicks ‚Üí auth check ‚Üí DB call ‚Üí UI updates‚Äù

This is ideal for GPT to generate **Mermaid sequence diagrams** based on:

- Docstrings
    
- Comments
    
- Observed flow traces (e.g., from logs or tracing tools)
    
- Or natural language descriptions you provide
    

You can build a CLI tool that:

1. Reads Python file or CI YAML
    
2. Extracts function names / calls
    
3. Feeds into GPT with structured prompt
    
4. Returns a Mermaid diagram
    
5. Auto-renders via [Mermaid CLI](https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid-cli)
    

---

## üß† Recommended Hybrid Strategy

|Goal|Tool / Strategy|
|---|---|
|CI/CD flow diagram|Parse CI YAML + GPT ‚Üí Mermaid `flowchart`|
|Function call sequence (static)|`pyan3` ‚Üí `dot` ‚Üí Mermaid|
|Class hierarchy / architecture map|`pyreverse` or `pycallgraph`|
|UX-to-backend flow diagram|Use GPT with structured description|
|Runtime traces|Trace logs + GPT summarization ‚Üí sequenceDiagram|

---

## ‚ö° TL;DR

‚úÖ Use **`pyan3`** or **`pyreverse`** for static diagrams  
‚úÖ Use **GPT + Mermaid** for flexible, readable flow diagrams  
‚úÖ You don‚Äôt need to handwrite them‚Äîbuild a small tool to generate Mermaid syntax  
‚úÖ For CI/CD flows, parse your YAML and feed into GPT to convert into diagrams

---

If you want:

- A working GPT prompt template to generate Mermaid from Python or CI YAML
    
- A CLI that wraps pyan3 + GPT + Mermaid output
    
- An Obsidian plugin strategy to auto-link diagrams to notes
    

Say the word and I‚Äôll prototype it with you.

##### You said:

Yes tell me about an obsidian plugin strategy

###### ChatGPT said:

Absolutely‚Äîthis is where things get juicy.

You want a system that **automatically generates diagrams** (Mermaid preferred), **links them into Obsidian notes**, and ideally updates when the source code or CI definitions change.

Let‚Äôs build a mental architecture for your **Obsidian-integrated Diagram System**.

---

## üß± Core Strategy

You‚Äôre going to build (or script) a **local plugin + CLI hybrid** that does the following:

### üîÅ Pipeline Flow:

vbnet

CopyEdit

`Source code / CI YAML        ‚Üì Parse or extract structure        ‚Üì Optionally use GPT to summarize / format        ‚Üì Generate Mermaid code        ‚Üì Write to note or embed in existing Obsidian page        ‚Üì Optional: auto-link, auto-tag, or embed in graph`

---

## üß© 1. Plugin or Script Options

|Option|Pros|Cons|
|---|---|---|
|**Local CLI script**|Easy to build/test, language-agnostic|Not real-time inside Obsidian|
|**Obsidian plugin**|Fully integrated, auto-refresh possible|More complex to build & test|
|**Hybrid** (recommended)|CLI handles parsing + generation, plugin handles display/integration|Best of both worlds|

---

## üß† Architecture for the Hybrid System

### üîß The CLI

- Written in Python
    
- Parses:
    
    - Python files ‚Üí `pyan3` / AST / GPT
        
    - YAML files ‚Üí `PyYAML` ‚Üí GPT
        
- Generates:
    
    - `mermaid`-formatted `.md` files
        
    - Optionally updates frontmatter with tags/links
        
- Output file goes in:
    
    bash
    
    CopyEdit
    
    `vault/diagrams/generated/`
    

### ü™∂ Example Output

markdown

CopyEdit

`# CI Build Sequence  ```mermaid flowchart TD     A[Push to GitHub] --> B[Run Tests]     B --> C{Tests Pass?}     C -->|Yes| D[Build Docker Image]     C -->|No| E[Fail Build]`

yaml

CopyEdit

``---  ### üìé Optional Plugin Enhancements  - Watch `vault/diagrams/generated` and auto-link new diagrams to relevant notes using filename conventions - UI dropdown in command palette:   - ‚ÄúGenerate Diagram from File‚Äù   - ‚ÄúUpdate All Diagrams‚Äù   - ‚ÄúInsert Diagram into Current Note‚Äù - Add **frontmatter metadata** like:   ```yaml   diagram_of: feature/my-feature-name   generated_from: src/ci/main.yml``

---

## üß† GPT Prompt Strategy (example)

**For CI/CD YAMLs:**

> ‚ÄúSummarize this GitHub Actions workflow and convert the steps into a Mermaid flowchart. Highlight key decision points and build/test/deploy phases.‚Äù

**For Python source:**

---

## üß™ Example: GPT + Mermaid Output for a Feature Call

mermaid

CopyEdit

`sequenceDiagram     participant User     participant UI     participant API     participant DB      User->>UI: Click "Generate Report"     UI->>API: POST /generate_report     API->>DB: Fetch data     DB-->>API: Return dataset     API-->>UI: Render Report`

---

## üöÄ Getting Started Plan

1. **Build the CLI:**
    
    - Accept input files
        
    - Optionally call OpenAI API to generate Mermaid
        
    - Output `.md` files in a structured folder
        
2. **Add YAML frontmatter to diagram notes**

3. **(Optional) Build a plugin**

---

## üß† Bonus: Bi-Directional Links

Link diagrams to:

- Features (`[[feature/xyz]]`)
    
- Components (`[[component/xyz]]`)
    
- Stories, tests, etc.
    

Use **DataviewJS** to show:

js

CopyEdit

`TABLE generated_from FROM "diagrams/generated" WHERE contains(diagram_of, this.file.name)`

---

## ‚ö° TL;DR

- ‚úÖ Use a hybrid CLI + plugin setup
    
- ‚úÖ Generate Mermaid diagrams automatically from source
    
- ‚úÖ Write to `vault/diagrams/generated/`

component: Obsidian Reader

# Description
This is a module design to verify product requirements. 
Its intended to run as part of CI/CD QA.

## Examples
For a given requirement, such as [[Ygg 2 - R1 product parent existence]], this module will go through and check if there exist any products, which do not have a parent.

Check that there are no orphan:
- Components
- User stories
- Versions
- Features
- Requirements
- Tests
- Tasks
# User Stories
As a Yggdrasill developer, I need a way to quickly and easily verify that everything is linked properly.
- Generate a list of everything that is not linked
# Versions
v0.0 - manually use Obs Project to check and assign parent
v0.1 - python script that finds empty parent property fields
v0.1a - includes exclusion ie ignore list
v0.2 - LLM proposes/suggests a parent

See: https://chatgpt.com/c/6848f5c3-3c4c-8013-8877-24209df2d310

# Background
## üß† What is a **Planner**?

> A **planner** is a construct that takes a checklist template and fills it with context-specific data (from pools, priorities, or logic) to produce a **checklist instance**‚Äîusually scheduled for a specific time.

It‚Äôs the **thing that makes your system adaptive**.
## üîÅ Interface Overview

### üß© (1) Planner ‚Üî Checklist Template

The **planner uses the template as a form**. It:
- Reads structure: sections, task slots
- Reads rules: how many items to pull, constraints
- Knows how to fill each slot from the right pool or logic

### üßæ (2) Planner ‚Üî Checklist Instantiation

The **output** of the planner is a **concrete checklist run**, pre-filled for a given day or event.

**Example Output:**

yaml

CopyEdit

`# checklist_runs/2025-07-02_piano_practice.yaml  template_ref: piano_practice_template_v1.0 generated_by: piano_planner_v1 date: 2025-07-02  sections:   - name: Scales     task: Play Eb Minor (2 octaves, hands together)     skill_ref: scales_minor_2_octaves    - name: Tango Techniques     task: La Yumba rhythmic study     skill_ref: la_yumba_pattern    - name: Songs     tasks:       - Poema (locked-hands)       - Milonga del Angel (phrasing work)`

---

## ‚öôÔ∏è What the Planner Actually Does

1. **Reads template structure**
2. **Selects content** from pools based on strategy:
    - Rotation
    - Randomized with exclusions
    - Priority queue
3. **Constructs checklist run**
4. (Optional) **Schedules it** or links it to a day
5. (Optional) **Logs state**: last-used item, usage frequency, success rate

---

## üß† Why the Planner Matters

Without a planner, **you have to think at execution time**:

> ‚ÄúWhich scale should I do today?‚Äù  
> ‚ÄúWhich recipes do I feel like making?‚Äù

With a planner:
- You reduce decision fatigue
- You balance repetition vs. variety
- You turn **strategy into action**

---

## üîó Optional Planner Inputs

- **Goal tree node** (e.g. ‚ÄúFluency in all minor keys‚Äù)
- **Day of week** or calendar
- **Fatigue level** (light practice vs. deep work)
- **Time budget**

---

## üí° Analogies

| Planner           | Analogy                                                                |
| ----------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Meal Planner      | ‚ÄúChoose meals for the week from my favorites and what‚Äôs in the fridge‚Äù |
| Workout Generator | ‚ÄúPull 3 exercises from each muscle group rotation‚Äù                     |
| AI Dungeon Master | ‚ÄúCreate the next chapter using preset constraints and player choices‚Äù  |

# ROLES 
## 1. ‚úÖ **Template Validation**

> Ensure that the checklist template is structured correctly and references valid pools, counts, etc.

### üîç What to Validate:
- Each section has required keys (`name`, `pool`, `count`)
- The pool name exists in the system
- Values like `count` are integers ‚â• 1
- The checklist template declares a valid `version`

### üîß Example:

yaml

CopyEdit

`# checklist template sections:   - name: Scales     pool: minor_scales_rotation     # must exist in /pools/     count: 1                        # must be integer`

### üí° Implementation Concept:

python

CopyEdit

`def validate_template(template, available_pools):     for section in template.get("sections", []):         if 'name' not in section or 'pool' not in section or 'count' not in section:             raise ValueError(f"Invalid section: {section}")         if section['pool'] not in available_pools:             raise ValueError(f"Missing pool: {section['pool']}")`

---

## 2. ü™£ **Pool Definition and Access**

> Pools are collections of items the planner can draw from to populate tasks.

### üîç What a Pool Might Contain:
- Strings (`Eb Minor`, `La Yumba`)
- Dicts with metadata (e.g. skill ref, difficulty, last used)
- Grouping tags for smart filtering

yaml

CopyEdit

`# minor_scales_rotation.yaml items:   - Eb Minor   - Ab Minor   - F# Minor`

### üí° Pool Access Pattern:

python

CopyEdit

`def load_pool(pool_name):     with open(f"pools/{pool_name}.yaml", 'r') as f:         return yaml.safe_load(f)["items"]`

Pools might evolve to support:

- `weights` (for biased random selection)
    
- `history` (for rotation tracking)
    
- `tags` (e.g. #minor #2octaves)
    

---

## 3. üßæ **Checklist Run Instantiation**

> The core job of the planner: fill out the checklist with actual tasks.

### Steps:
- Start from a validated template
- Pull items from each pool using the planner‚Äôs logic
- Format those items into a structured checklist run
- Add metadata: date, source planner, goal reference (optional)

### üí° Run Format Example:

yaml

CopyEdit

`template_ref: piano_practice_template.yaml date: 2025-07-03 generated_by: piano_rotation_planner sections:   - name: Scales     tasks: ["Eb Minor"]   - name: Tango Techniques     tasks: ["La Yumba"]`

---

## 4. üìÖ **Calendar Interfacing (Optional but Powerful)**

> Allow the planner to _schedule_ checklist runs into a calendar system or timeline.

### Use Cases:
- ‚ÄúSchedule my runs for Monday/Wednesday/Friday‚Äù
- ‚ÄúAdd runs to my Obsidian daily note‚Äù
- ‚ÄúExport run dates to iCal/Google Calendar‚Äù

### üí° Integration Ideas:
- Write checklist run to a `YYYY-MM-DD.md` file in Obsidian `daily/`
- Save scheduled runs with a `due_date` key for syncing with a calendar
- Generate `.ics` entries for import into external systems
    

yaml

CopyEdit

`date: 2025-07-03 due_time: 08:00 calendar_event_title: "Piano Practice: Scales, Tango, Songs"`

### üíª Minimal Calendar Bridge (Obsidian-style):

python

CopyEdit

`with open(f"obsidian/daily/{today}.md", "a") as f:     f.write(f"- [ ] Piano Practice (auto-generated)\n")`

---

## üß† Summary Table

|Component|Role|Core Code Responsibility|
|---|---|---|
|**Template Validation**|Prevent garbage in|Validate structure + pool references|
|**Pool Access**|Feed the planner|Load and optionally filter or rotate items|
|**Run Instantiation**|Create checklist instances|Fill template with content and output YAML|
|**Calendar Interfacing**|Make it usable in real time|Sync to schedule, note, or task system|

# Planner Scope "pools"
Absolutely. The key idea is to give your planner **a scope**‚Äîa way of knowing _where in the Skill Tree to operate_. This scope can be defined in several ways, depending on how you want to interact with the Skill Tree: by path, by tags, by coordinate, or by linked goal.

Let‚Äôs walk through each option clearly.

---

## üß≠ Four Ways to Scope a Planner to the Skill Tree

---

### 1. **By Path** (Hierarchical Scoping)

> Specify a location in the Skill Tree hierarchy (like folders or nodes).

yaml

CopyEdit

`scope:   type: path   value: ["Music", "Scales", "Harmonic Minor"]`

‚úÖ Great for:

- Structural targeting
    
- Planning based on categories
    
- e.g., ‚ÄúPlan from everything under Harmonic Minor‚Äù
    

---

### 2. **By Tags** (Semantic Scoping)

> Use tags attached to skill nodes, like `#practice`, `#advanced`, `#in_rotation`.

yaml

CopyEdit

`scope:   type: tag   value: "#harmonic_minor"`

‚úÖ Great for:

- Thematic or cross-cutting concerns
    
- Temporary or dynamic scopes
    
- Seasonal/campaign-based filtering
    
- e.g., ‚ÄúAll nodes tagged #portuguese_cuisine‚Äù
    

---

### 3. **By Coordinates** (Spatial Scoping)

> Use spatial XY address logic (if Skill Tree is stored that way).

yaml

CopyEdit

`scope:   type: region   x_range: [2, 4]   y_range: [10, 20]`

‚úÖ Great for:

- Visual range selections
- Advanced planning algorithms that map learning zones
- Graph-style UI navigation

---

### 4. **By Linked Goal** (Intent-Driven Scoping)

> Let the planner follow a Goal Tree node, which defines a target area.

yaml

CopyEdit

`scope:   type: goal_ref   value: fluency_minor_scales`

Then the planner resolves:

yaml

CopyEdit

`goal_refs:   fluency_minor_scales:     linked_skills:       - [3,14,0] # Eb Minor       - [3,15,0] # Ab Minor`

‚úÖ Great for:

- Personal development plans
- Goal-driven automation    
- ‚ÄúJust tell me what to do to move forward‚Äù

---

## üß† How a Planner Uses the Scope

Let‚Äôs say you're writing a **Tactical Planner**. Its process:
1. **Reads scope definition**
2. **Resolves scope into a skill node pool**
3. **Selects one or more items from the pool**
4. **Fills the checklist template accordingly**

---

## üõ† Sample YAML for a Planner Config

yaml

CopyEdit

`planner_id: minor_scale_tactical_planner_v1 planner_type: tactical strategy: rotate_without_repeat checklist_template: piano_scale_warmup_v1 scope:   type: path   value: ["Music", "Scales", "Harmonic Minor"] pool_filters:   tags: ["#active", "#practice"]`

---

Would you like:
- A function or object schema to standardize this `scope` interface?
- A sample Skill Tree structure we can run scoped queries on?

# v0.0.1 - Simplest thing you can do.
Sort a list based on a unique integer *priority* field.
- Make a list of todo items, 
	- add a priority (low, med, high)
	- add an estimate completion time - 5,10,
- Filter based on priority - med, high
- Sort based on estimate completion time.

# v0.0.2 - Meat on the bones
Select x from y such that some constraint is met.
- Knapsack problem.

From the list of todo items, pick the most important that will fit in a given time window.

# v0.0.3 - Combinatorical
Meal plan from recipe library.
- hits calorie, macro, and prep time goals.

**Background** - in many cases there is significant overlap and interplay between the different features. 

*Example 1 -* 
- I want to plot my workouts.
- I want to plot my finance data.
	- Start by implementing plotting for workouts
	- Follow up by implementing plotting for finance.

*Example 2* - 
- I want to improve Runestone functionality.
- I have a task I need to complete
	- I try completing that task using Runestones.

*Example 3* -
- I want to build a feature to decide what workout to do next based on how this one went.
- I want to build a feature to decide what piano exercise to do next.
	- Add a feature in the planning framework.

**Visualization**
In many cases I have a progression mapped out in my head of which features precede what etc. So let's say I have a concept for implementing the finance data, I want to be able to quickly "discover", or surface, that it comes *after* the workout plots.

Another way to think of this is that it's combining development paths, from different domains, into one view, i.e. combining them into a _thread_.

## **Visualization Component v0.1 (Draft)**

A user-facing interface layer for interacting with the Tree of Becoming across time and domain.

### ‚úÖ Core Requirements

- **üìä Tree Diagram Viewers**
    
    - Visual representation of the Skill Tree, Product Tree, and Goal Tree
        
    - Show node hierarchy in XY grid form
        
    - Toggleable overlays:
        
        - Thread paths
            
        - Active planner contexts
            
        - Recently completed execution logs
            
    - Color or badge nodes by status (e.g., ‚Äúactive,‚Äù ‚Äúin progress,‚Äù ‚Äúmastered,‚Äù ‚Äúaspirational‚Äù)
        
- **üìÖ Time Navigator**
    
    - Scroll or select a day/week/month to visualize:
        
        - Which skills/products were targeted (from planner output)
            
        - What was actually completed (from execution logs)
            
    - Compare planned vs. actual
        
- **üìù Interactive Checklists**
    
    - Streamlit-based execution UI for checklist runs
        
    - Allow checking off items, adding notes, time spent, outcome tags
        
    - Log automatically to execution history
        
- **üîç Filtering and Sorting Tools**
    
    - For planner use:
        
        - Filter tree nodes by tag, domain, priority, goal linkage
            
        - Sort by recency, relevance, or historical underuse
            
    - For display:
        
        - Filter tree by current planner context or thread
            
- **üß† Context Awareness**
    
    - View or edit current `planner_context.yaml` for any domain
        
    - Preview impact of strategic planning decisions
        
    - See which checklist templates are in rotation for each context
        
- **üìÇ Thread Browser**
    
    - View list of threads (journal-style entries)
        
    - Click into a thread to see which skill/product/goal nodes it touches
        
    - Option to add new threads directly from UI
        
- **üìà Progress Heatmaps**
    
    - Show usage frequency or depth of work per skill node over time
        
    - Visualize growth patterns, skill neglect zones, and plateaus
        
- **üìÅ Export / Snapshot Tool**
    
    - Capture a frozen view of the Tree (and its mappings) at a point in time
        
    - Useful for versioning and retrospective review

# Architecture 
## Option Overview
1. Obsidian "Projects" - folder-based
2. Obsidian "Projects" - Dataview "prefilter"
3. Obsidian "Tasks" - 

## Architecture Trade
## ‚úÖ PROS of Folder-Based Projects

| Strength                 | Why It Rocks                                                                  |
| ------------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Simpler mental model** | No query syntax. It‚Äôs just ‚Äúnotes in this folder = project.‚Äù                  |
| **WYSIWYG setup**        | Drag a file into the folder, and it appears on the board. No metadata needed. |
| **Cleaner UI**           | Especially good for beginners or visually managing specific buckets of work.  |
| **Fast prototyping**     | You don‚Äôt need to think through your metadata architecture up front.          |

---
## ‚ùå CONS of Folder-Based Projects

|Limitation|Why It Might Hurt|
|---|---|
|**Not filterable**|You can‚Äôt say ‚Äúonly notes with `status: In Progress`‚Äù unless you move notes in and out of folders manually.|
|**Hard to scale**|If a note fits in two views (like `Tasks` _and_ `Shopping`), you can‚Äôt include it in both unless you duplicate it.|
|**No global project board**|You lose the ability to say ‚Äúgive me all notes with `project: true` across folders.‚Äù|
|**More drag-and-drop, less automation**|Dynamic updates require you to move files. Not ideal for checklist instances or ephemeral tasks.|

## Chosen Architecture
üí° **Hybrid Strategy** might be best for Hlidskjalf prototype:

| Domain         | Use Method                                      |
| -------------- | ----------------------------------------------- |
| Tasks          | ‚úÖ Dataview                                      |
| Recipes        | ‚úÖ Folder-based (each recipe is a note anyway)   |
| Checklist Runs | ‚úÖ Dataview (filter by `checklist:` and `date:`) |
| Shopping Lists | ‚úÖ Folder-based (drag-and-drop makes sense here) |

# View Types
**Tree Views** - good for finding stuff
- **Product Tree** -> primary purpose is for devs to find stuff: documentation, linked tasks, user stories, procedures etc, 
	- Would benefit from Tree Filter so I can configure that on-the-fly. [[Feature 6 - Filterable Trees]]
	- Could be where the item creation system gets implemented: [[User Pain Point 1 - Item creation tedious]]
- **Task Tree** - root is tasks that need to get done, and what they trace to (feature, pain point etc)
- **Procedure Tree** - organized by domain. The tips here are procedures.
	- Example use: "hmm I want to organize my sheet music, I know I have a procedure for that, where is it?" I would come here.
	- Could capture "nested" i.e. child and prerequisite procedures somehow.
- **Type Tree** - 
	- I know the *type* of the thing that I'm looking for (procedure, diagram, etc), but I forget where I saw it 
		- "it was a devops chart, was it under Devops? Was it under a specific component??"
	- This could also benefit from [[Feature 6 - Filterable Trees]]
- **Requirements (and Testing) Tree** - Bidirectional tracing: Product -> requirements -> tests files and functions -> code lines files etc
	- See: [[test tracing - chatgpt]]
- **Skill Tree** - What do we know how to do? This can be useful for identifying gaps for particular tasks, i.e. Runestones can come explore this tree, and if it doesn't find what it needs, then can go generate it and add it here.

**Calendar Views** - good for making plans. Ideally would have auto metadata display.
- Meal plan - drag recipes to meal slots
- Gym plan - drag workouts (i.e. biceps) to Program (i.e. Program B) slots.

**Kanban Views** - good for:
- sorting, 
- changes status of many issues,
- progressing issues through a workflow.

**Sequence View** - good for prioritizing
- What are the next tasks on a product (i.e. on the database)
- What are the next tasks on a pain point (could be related to any of database, frontend, or solver)
- What are the next tasks on a product or component feature (could be related to any of database, frontend, or solver)
- What are the next tasks for an agent/person
	- PM, Test, The Python Developer,.....

Absolutely. Let‚Äôs walk through each of those‚Äî**progress heatmaps**, **dependency trees**, and **inspiration maps**‚Äîusing small, digestible examples rooted in your **Tree of Becoming**. We‚Äôll look at:

1. What they are
    
2. What they _show_
    
3. How they _help_ you think, plan, and act
    

---

## üî• 1. Progress Heatmaps

### üß† What it is:

A **visual or tabular representation** of how far along you are in fulfilling the subcomponents of a larger goal or product‚Äîusually colored (green = done, red = not started, etc.)

---

### üìå Example:

#### Goal: "Record a Tango EP"

This goal links to 3 Products:

- P1: _La Cumparsita Arrangement_ (complete)
    
- P2: _Locked Hands Solo_ (in progress)
    
- P3: _Bandone√≥n Sketch_ (not started)
    

Each Product is linked to Skills and Tasks:

- P2 depends on Skill: "Locked Hands Technique"  
    ‚Üí Skill is 40% complete (based on checklist/task logs)
    

### üßæ View:

|Node|Type|Status|% Complete|Notes|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|La Cumparsita|Product|‚úÖ Done|100%|Exported from MuseScore|
|Locked Hands Solo|Product|üü° In Prog|40%|Needs bridge section|
|Bandone√≥n Sketch|Product|üî¥ Not Started|0%|Haven‚Äôt picked a melody|
|Locked Hands Technique|Skill|üü° In Prog|60%|Practicing right-hand rolls|

### üéØ What this shows:

You‚Äôre halfway to the EP. The technical bottleneck is your "Locked Hands" execution. Your next task might not be writing‚Äîit might be **practicing**.

---

### üß† How this helps:

- **Reveals weak links** in your capability chain
    
- **Highlights bottlenecks**‚Äîwhat‚Äôs holding up the next Product
    
- Helps **prioritize** effort (you don‚Äôt need more ideas; you need fluency in a technique)
    

---

## üå≥ 2. Dependency Trees

### üß† What it is:

A hierarchical or graph-based layout showing **what depends on what**‚Äîa visual representation of the upstream and downstream relationships between Tasks, Skills, Products, and Goals.

---

### üìå Example:

#### Product: "Cookbook Prototype"

yaml

CopyEdit

`Goal: Launch Food Blog ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Product: Cookbook Prototype     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Skill: Recipe Testing     ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Task: Cook 5 Sample Dishes     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Skill: Food Photography         ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Task: Set Up Lighting         ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Task: Take Hero Shots`

You can imagine this rendered as a mindmap or flowchart.

---

### üéØ What this shows:

This prototype has **two skill bottlenecks**: testing and photography. You can‚Äôt finalize the Product until both are satisfied.

---

### üß† How this helps:

- **Clarifies order of operations**‚Äîwhat you must learn or do before progressing
    
- **Breaks overwhelming goals into actionable roots**
    
- Useful for planning: ‚ÄúThis weekend I‚Äôll focus on cooking, next week on photos‚Äù
    

---

## üé® 3. Inspiration Maps

### üß† What it is:

A visual or tabular display of **external resources** (from the Link Layer) tied to one or more nodes‚Äîuseful when you want to immerse yourself in the _aesthetic_, _technical_, or _thematic_ reference pool.

---

### üìå Example:

#### Skill Node: ‚ÄúPortuguese Street Food Research‚Äù

Your Link Layer has:

- Pinterest Board: ‚ÄúPortuguese Tiles & Street Food Carts‚Äù
    
- YouTube Playlist: ‚ÄúLisbon Food Tour‚Äù
    
- Amazon Wishlist: _Street Food of Europe_ cookbook
    
- Audible: _Cultural History of Lisbon_
    

### üßæ View:

|Source|Title|Type|Linked To|
|---|---|---|---|
|Pinterest|‚ÄúPortuguese Food Aesthetic‚Äù|Visual|Skill: Street Food Research|
|YouTube|‚ÄúTop 10 Lisbon Eats‚Äù|Video|Skill: Street Food Research|
|Audible|‚ÄúCultural History of Lisbon‚Äù|Audiobook|Goal: Launch Food Blog|
|Amazon|‚ÄúStreet Food of Europe‚Äù|Book|Skill: Recipe Inspiration|

---

### üéØ What this shows:

This node is **rich in visual and cultural stimuli**. You‚Äôre already collecting the ingredients for mastery‚Äîyou just need to engage them intentionally.

---

### üß† How this helps:

- Turns passive consumption into **active research**
    
- Lets you **design your learning environment** ("watch these vids, read this book, pin this board")
    
- Informs future Product style and voice (e.g., ‚ÄúThis tile pattern should be in the header of my blog‚Äù)
    

---

## üß© Final Summary

|Tool|Shows|Helps With|
|---|---|---|
|Progress Heatmap|Where you are in a build chain|Prioritization, focus, avoiding stall|
|Dependency Tree|What work depends on what|Sequencing, scope control, feasibility|
|Inspiration Map|What resources feed your Tree|Immersion, creativity, idea capture|

- Trace each down so that the bottom of the new tree is essentially the root of the Product, goal, and skill trees, respectively.
v0.1 - Use the "streamlit-for-snowflake" code to see our trees.

LIST WHERE contains(file.folder, this.file.folder)

	- Only children of a given node, for example.

See: [[SW-P-1 Release Planning#Preliminary Planning]]

file_name: Tree display name different from key.md
body:
**Source:** *The Python Developer*
Is there a way to use this script, but have the display names, in the animated tree, different from the actual parent child link structures

###### ChatGPT said:

Yes, absolutely‚Äîyou can decouple the **display name** (what shows up in the animated tree) from the **logical `__filename` and `parent` structure** used to build the tree.

---

## ‚úÖ You Just Need to Add a ‚ÄúDisplay Name‚Äù Field

### Step 1: Modify Your Output Rows

In your `load_obsidian_tree_by_folder.py` script, add a `display_name` field alongside `__filename`.

Here's what to change in **both folder and note sections**:

### üîß For folders:

python

CopyEdit

`output_rows.append({     "__filename": name,     "parent": parent,     "type": "folder",     "display_name": f"[FOLDER] {name}"  # or whatever you want })`

### üîß For notes:

python

CopyEdit

`all_props["__filename"] = md_file.stem all_props["parent"] = parent all_props["type"] = "note" all_props["display_name"] = all_props.get("title", md_file.stem)  # default to stem if no title`

This way:

- You still build the tree using `__filename` and `parent`
    
- But show users the friendlier `display_name`
    

---

### Step 2: Update Your Streamlit App / HTML Renderer

In your `collapsible-tree-template.html` or wherever you‚Äôre converting to JSON, update the D3 label generator:

#### Before (probably):

javascript

CopyEdit

`.text(function (d) { return d.data.name; })`

#### After:

javascript

CopyEdit

`.text(function (d) { return d.data.display_name || d.data.name; })`

Or if you're passing JSON already with `display_name`, set the tree data like:

javascript

CopyEdit

`name: node["__filename"], display_name: node["display_name"], ...`

Then you use `display_name` in rendering, and let the hidden `__filename` keep the structure intact.

---

## üß† Summary

| Purpose        | Field                  |
| -------------- | ---------------------- |
| Tree structure | `__filename`, `parent` |
| Visual label   | `display_name`         |
|                |                        |

file_name: M√≠misbrunnr - a store for critical info.md
body:
**Note**
- Ultimately, I think this just becomes a table in Mimisbrunnr. Also, this is not high priority
# ChatGPT Design Doc
Ok I‚Äôm back again thinking about Askur Yggdrasil the tree of life and becoming. This time I want to understand how, or if, I should integrate my ‚Äúcritical info‚Äù in some way. For example I‚Äôm talking about travel confirmations, insurance providers (and their renewal dates), etc etc etc. what are the pros and cons of doing this? How would it work, conceptually?

###### ChatGPT said:

Welcome back to the Tree. Let‚Äôs talk about integrating ‚Äú**critical info**‚Äù like travel confirmations and insurance details into **Askur Yggdrasill**, your evolving system for life mastery and self-becoming.

---

## üß† TL;DR (Pros and Cons)

### **Pros**

- **Total system coherence** ‚Äì You reduce mental load by having _one tree to rule them all_.
    
- **Contextual awareness** ‚Äì Critical info can feed into planning, checklists, and execution logs (e.g., ‚ÄúTrip to Romania ‚Üí Insurance expires one week before‚Äù).
    
- **Lifecycle integration** ‚Äì Things like renewal dates become _temporal roots_ feeding into planner and goal systems.
    
- **Narrative continuity** ‚Äì The mundane becomes mythologized. Even your dental appointment has a place in the saga.
    

### **Cons**

- **Overcomplexity** ‚Äì Risk of bloating the Tree with stuff that doesn‚Äôt need to be immortalized.
    
- **Security/privacy** ‚Äì Insurance policy numbers and passport scans may require vaulting beyond your current note-taking setup.
    
- **Maintenance tax** ‚Äì Critical info needs regular pruning and updating or it becomes a graveyard.
    

---

## üå± Conceptual Integration

Let‚Äôs walk the roots through a few **Tree of Becoming components** and ask: _Where does Critical Info naturally live?_

---

### 1. **Threads**

_‚ÄúI booked a trip. Here's the receipt. Also, I need a visa.‚Äù_  
Use threads to **capture events and info together** in the moment.

- Entry: ‚ÄúBooked Argentina flights for milonga festival.‚Äù
    
- Attachment: PDF receipt, insurance doc, checklist link.
    
- Optional tag: `#critical-info`
    

> üîÆ _Threads are the journal layer of the Tree. Let them hold the memory of things past and future._

---

### 2. **Execution Logs / Planner Framework**

You want an upcoming action? Tie it to a renewal date or flight departure.

- Add to planner: ‚ÄúRenew travel insurance (expires July 12)‚Äù
    
- Execution log: ‚Äú‚úÖ Renewed July 5, new policy #ABC123‚Äù
    

> üõ°Ô∏è _This is where critical info transforms into action._

---

### 3. **Checklist Templates & Runs**

Routine renewals, travel prep, gear checks‚Äîthese thrive here.

- Checklist Template: `International Travel Prep`
    
- Item: ‚ÄúCheck insurance policy active‚Äù ‚Üí Link to policy doc
    

> üìã _Critical info becomes a pre-flight checklist item. Ritualized._

---

### 4. **New Component: Mi√∞gar√∞r** _(suggested)_

A dedicated ‚ÄúCritical Info Vault‚Äù that lives **alongside** M√≠misbrunnr.

- Structured table of:
    
    - Type: Insurance, Travel, Membership, Subscription
        
    - Provider
        
    - Status
        
    - Renewal Date
        
    - Attachments
        
- Cross-referenced to Threads, Checklists, and Planners
    

> üîê _Mi√∞gar√∞r keeps the world running. It‚Äôs not poetic‚Äîbut it is sacred._

---

## üß≠ Should You Do This?

### Do it **if**:

- You already feel fragmented across emails, spreadsheets, and apps.
    
- You want _critical context_ to surface at the right moment.
    
- You‚Äôre willing to spend a little time structuring it upfront.
    

### Avoid it **if**:

- You‚Äôre still early in building the Tree and don‚Äôt have stable practices yet.
    
- You already use a purpose-built app (like Notion, 1Password, or Apple Wallet) and it works.
    
- You don‚Äôt want to manage sensitive data in your knowledge graph.
    

---

## üõ†Ô∏è How to Start Light

1. **Thread-based capture**  
    Just start adding confirmations and receipts as attachments or links in related threads.
    
2. **Add a M√≠misbrunnr table**  
    `critical_info.csv` or Obsidian table:
    
    markdown
    
    CopyEdit
    
    `| Category   | Item                  | Expires      | Action Needed | Notes               | |------------|-----------------------|--------------|----------------|----------------------| | Insurance  | Travel Policy ABC123  | 2025-07-12   | Renew          | Email reminder set  | | Flight     | LIS ‚Üí OTP             | 2025-08-01   | Check in       | In Gmail, PDF saved |`
    
3. **Planner integration**  
    Add key dates to your planner and link to the entry above.
    

---

## üß¨ Poetic Frame

> The Tree remembers not only your dreams‚Äîbut your departure gates, your blood type, and the hour your shield needs reforging.
> 
> These are not distractions. They are the bark and root of the life you're building.

Let me know if you want help drafting the schema for `Mi√∞gar√∞r`, or if you want to plug this info into your planner via Streamlit or Obsidian.

**2025-06-23**
- For now I'm planning to internal linking as either:
	- Obsidian yaml frontmatter (metadata) or obsidian tags.
- In the future, this will likely become a table in Mimisbrunnr Database
### **Norna√ær√¶√∞ir**

_‚ÄúThe Threads of the Norns‚Äù_

Norna√ær√¶√∞ir is the living weave that binds the Tree of Becoming. It is the invisible, yet essential fabric that connects Skill Nodes, Product Nodes, and Goal Nodes‚Äîtracing the paths between action, creation, and intention.

Just as the Norns shape destiny by spinning the threads of past, present, and future, Norna√ær√¶√∞ir encodes the relationships that give meaning to growth. It does not _store_ knowledge‚Äîit _relates_ it. Each thread in Norna√ær√¶√∞ir is a commitment, a pattern of becoming, a subtle line of force drawn between who you are, what you make, and why.

Stored within **M√≠misbrunnr**, the deep well of wisdom, Norna√ær√¶√∞ir serves as both a map and a loom. It is queried by planners, revealed by visualizers, and updated through intention. No node exists in isolation; through Norna√ær√¶√∞ir, each is situated in the tapestry of purpose.

The table will be hosted in [[database]].

It maps relationships between The Four Trees:
- [[Tree of Goals]]
- [[Tree of Skills]]
- [[prod_tree/yggdrasill/yggdrasill]]
- [[Tree of Tasks]]

## ‚úÖ Internal Mapping Table

### üîπ Structure:

Each row links **exactly two nodes** between **two distinct trees** (e.g., Skill ‚Üí Product, Product ‚Üí Goal, etc.).

|`id`|`from_tree`|`from_node_id`|`to_tree`|`to_node_id`|`relationship_type`|`version`|
|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
|1|skills|S:0102|products|P:0234|"enables"|v1.0|
|2|products|P:0234|goals|G:0009|"contributes_to"|v1.0|
|3|skills|S:0102|goals|G:0009|"develops_for"|v1.0|

### üî∏ Notes:

- You‚Äôre right to limit each row to **two** trees‚Äîit keeps the table normalized and the relationships manageable.
    
- Tri- or quad-directional links are still fully representable: just use **multiple rows**.
    

> üìå You can always create **aggregated views** later to infer compound mappings (e.g., Skill ‚Üí Product ‚Üí Goal ‚Üí Task).

# Aggregated Views
**progress heatmaps**, **dependency trees**, and **inspiration maps**

# Formal Definition (yaml)
component: Norna√ær√¶√∞ir
type: internal_mapping_table
location: M√≠misbrunnr
version: v1.0

description: >
  Norna√ær√¶√∞ir is the internal mapping table of the Tree of Becoming.
  It encodes explicit many-to-many relationships between Skill Nodes,
  Product Nodes, and Goal Nodes.

functionality:
  - Links entities across different Trees via unique tree addresses
  - Supports directional mappings (e.g., Skill ‚Üí Product, Product ‚Üí Goal)
  - Enables querying of upstream and downstream dependencies
  - Allows planners and visualization tools to generate path-based insights

structure:
  fields:
    - source_node_address: string
    - target_node_address: string
    - mapping_type: enum [skill_to_product, product_to_goal, skill_to_goal]
    - notes: optional string
    - created_at: timestamp
    - modified_at: timestamp

linked_components:
  - Skill Tree
  - Product Tree
  - Goal Tree
  - M√≠misbrunnr (data storage)
  - Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf (visualization)
  - Vardlokkur (planner framework)

naming_origin: >
  "Norna√ær√¶√∞ir" means "Threads of the Norns" in Old Norse.
  It honors the mythic weavers of fate and reflects the table‚Äôs role
  as the binding force between past action, present creation, and future intent.

# About
## üß† **M√≠misbrunnr** ‚Äì The Data Well

> The silent root of the Tree. All knowledge is drawn from here.

### üîπ Purpose:

M√≠misbrunnr is the **canonical data store** for the Tree of Becoming. It houses all structured information across components, enabling querying, persistence, versioning, and interaction across domains.

---

### üî∏ Requirements:

- **Relational Schema (or equivalent structured store):**
    
    - Tables or entities for:
        
        - Skill Tree nodes
            
        - Product Tree nodes
            
        - Goal Tree nodes
            
        - Mapping Table entries
            
        - Planner contexts and outputs
            
        - Checklist templates and runs
            
        - Execution logs
            
        - Thread metadata and content
            
- **Versioning Support**
    
    - Each table must support full-tree version snapshots
        
    - Diff-friendly schema for comparing states over time
        
- **Timestamping and Lineage**
    
    - Timestamps for creation, update, execution
        
    - Linkage between planner outputs and execution logs
        
    - Foreign keys across trees via node addresses
        
- **Human-Readable + System-Resolvable**
    
    - Store both friendly labels and machine-resolvable paths (e.g. `[2,1,3]`)
        
- **Accessible by UI and Code**
    
    - Power the **Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf** visualization interface
        
    - Interact with Python planner classes and data pipelines
        
- **Lightweight, Portable, Durable**
    
    - Can start as SQLite or Pandas-on-CSV
        
    - Should be swappable to a full RDBMS or document store if needed

# About
Describes a workflow that enables making edits in native obsidian and converting that to a database (for example CSV) and vice versa.

See discussion in **The Task Manager - Topological Priority**
