Ok, before we get to the ‚Äúround-trip contract‚Äù I want to elaborate on why I like Obsidian: the live linking is very robust. It‚Äôs very convenient to link notes, include references to other notes, even put contents of a note as a link in a different note. This all makes obsidian extremely usable. I want to make sure the round trip contract accounts for this and is robust to it.

###### ChatGPT said:

Thought for 19s

Got it. Here‚Äôs a tight **round-trip contract** that plays beautifully with Obsidian‚Äôs live linking.

# Goals

‚Ä¢ Author comfortably in Obsidian (folders/notes, links, embeds).  
‚Ä¢ Persist the _same_ tree in a DB (CSV now).  
‚Ä¢ Export/import without breaking links, even after renames/moves.  
‚Ä¢ Support re-rooted views (alternate parents) without dup chaos.

# Assumptions (set these in Obsidian)

‚Ä¢ Turn on **Automatically update internal links**.  
‚Ä¢ Prefer **Wikilinks** (`[[Note]]`) + allow **Aliases** in YAML.  
‚Ä¢ Use **block IDs** (`^id`) for any block you plan to reference.  
‚Ä¢ One `_node.md` per folder gives that folder a node.

# Identity & Invariants

‚Ä¢ **node_id = stable UUID** (never hand-edit).  
‚Ä¢ **slug = stable filename stem** (can include a short UID prefix; human-readable).  
‚Ä¢ **aliases** (YAML) = list of human titles users might link with.  
‚Ä¢ **parent_id** = single primary parent (tree backbone). Extra parents via `edges.csv`.  
‚Ä¢ DB is the **source of truth for IDs, parent_id, slug**; content lives in Obsidian.

# What you can change in Obsidian (safe)

‚Ä¢ Titles, content, headings, folder placement (we update links).  
‚Ä¢ Add or remove links/embeds (`[[Note]]`, `![[Note#Heading]]`, `[[Note^block]]`).  
‚Ä¢ Add aliases in YAML.  
‚Ä¢ Reorganize folders‚Äîimport pass will read structure ‚Üí `parent_id`.

# What you should not change by hand

‚Ä¢ `node_id`, `slug`, `parent_id` YAML fields.  
‚Ä¢ `_node.md` filename inside a folder (it represents the folder‚Äôs node).

# Links: how we preserve them

‚Ä¢ **Note links**: resolve by filename/alias; Obsidian auto-updates on rename/move.  
‚Ä¢ **Aliases**: exporter ensures `aliases:` includes previous titles ‚Üí legacy links resolve.  
‚Ä¢ **Heading links** (`#Heading`): keep headings stable when possible; exporter won‚Äôt rewrite them.  
‚Ä¢ **Block links** (`^blockid`): assign explicit block IDs where referenced; exporter preserves them verbatim.  
‚Ä¢ **Embeds** (`![[‚Ä¶]]`): treated as _edges of type=embed_; preserved 1:1.

# Import (Obsidian ‚Üí DB)

‚Ä¢ Walk vault; for each `_node.md`/note:

- If `node_id` exists ‚Üí update row; else **mint UUID** and write back.
    
- Derive `parent_id` from folder‚Äôs `_node.md`.
    
- Capture `slug` (filename), `aliases`, `title`, `tags`, `order_index`.
    
- Parse links ‚Üí `edges.csv` with `kind ‚àà {link, embed, heading, block}` and optional `anchor`.  
    ‚Ä¢ Validate: no cycles, missing parents, duplicate `_node.md`. Quarantine orphans; log fixes.  
    ‚Ä¢ Mark `last_modified_by=obsidian`.
    

# Export (DB ‚Üí Obsidian)

‚Ä¢ Choose **root node** (or view).  
‚Ä¢ Create folder tree; each internal node gets `_node.md` with frontmatter:

- `node_id, slug, parent_id, title, aliases, order_index, domain, type,‚Ä¶`  
    ‚Ä¢ File names = `{order_index}_{slug}.md` (keeps sort order readable).  
    ‚Ä¢ Do **not** rewrite user content except to inject/update frontmatter.  
    ‚Ä¢ Maintain a **manifest** (`node_id ‚Üî path`) so future renames keep links intact.  
    ‚Ä¢ For cross-links:
    
- **Referenced view (preferred):** keep a single canonical file; secondary parents get an index note with links (no duplication).
    
- **Materialized copy (optional):** duplicate content but **strip node_id** so it‚Äôs clearly a view copy, not the canonical node.
    

# Re-rooted Exports (alternate parents)

‚Ä¢ Use **referenced view**: an index folder with a note that lists children via Dataview queries or explicit links. No duplication ‚Üí links stay canonical.  
‚Ä¢ If you must materialize: copy notes without `node_id`, include a frontmatter pointer `canonical_id`, and warn on edit.

# Hierarchy signals (for your scoring engines)

‚Ä¢ Upward credit: a completed leaf contributes to all ancestors on its **canonical path**.  
‚Ä¢ If a note is embedded elsewhere, that‚Äôs an **edge** but not a second parent (unless explicitly added to `edges.csv`).

# Conflict policy (one direction per session)

‚Ä¢ You either **pull** (Obsidian ‚Üí DB) _or_ **push** (DB ‚Üí Obsidian).  
‚Ä¢ If both changed since last sync, show a 3-way diff; default to **Obsidian content**, **DB structure**.

# Sanity checks (automated)

‚Ä¢ Missing/duplicate `_node.md` in a folder ‚Üí fix or flag.  
‚Ä¢ Headings referenced but renamed ‚Üí flag once (user chooses to update reference or keep alias heading).  
‚Ä¢ Block refs without `^ids` ‚Üí auto-assign IDs and write back.  
‚Ä¢ Broken links after export ‚Üí fail fast with a report.

# Why this survives heavy linking

‚Ä¢ Links/embeds are preserved as literal Markdown; Obsidian‚Äôs updater handles renames/moves.  
‚Ä¢ Stable IDs + manifest handle identity across refactors.  
‚Ä¢ Aliases cushion human-friendly titles.  
‚Ä¢ We never ‚Äúcompile‚Äù links; we **mirror** them and track edges separately in the DB.

# TL;DR contract

‚Ä¢ **IDs & slugs are sacred.**  
‚Ä¢ **Edit content freely in Obsidian;** importer reads structure/links; exporter writes frontmatter & folders, not prose.  
‚Ä¢ **Use referenced views** for alternate parents; materialize copies only with `canonical_id`.  
‚Ä¢ **One-way per sync** to avoid merge hell.  
‚Ä¢ Block IDs for any embedded/anchored content; aliases for titles; Obsidian will do the rest.

If that fits, I‚Äôll draft the short ‚Äúdo/don‚Äôt‚Äù checklist you can paste in your vault so future-you (and future-helpers) stay on the rails.

Ok let‚Äôs talk about a tree definition workflow. By far my favorite way to define a tree is using an obsidian folder structure and just keep creating subfolders, until I get to the bottom of a tree and then create notes inside those subfolders. However, I think the best way to actually *store* the tree, is in a database (csv for now). Also, this would allow me to ‚Äúexport‚Äù a tree from the database into obsidian for manipulation. It would also allow the ‚Äúexport‚Äù of different trees, into obsidian, with different nodes as the parent. Give feedback on this structure and approach.

###### ChatGPT said:

Thought for 16s

Love the plan. Here‚Äôs how to make it solid, scalable, and not bite you later.

# Big picture

- **Author in Obsidian (folders & notes) for flow.**
    
- **Persist in a database (CSV now, DB later) for truth, IDs, queries, and exports.**
    
- Support **re-rooted exports** (different parents) without corrupting identity.
    

# Golden rules

1. **Stable IDs, not paths.** Every node gets a `node_id` (UUID). Paths can change; IDs don‚Äôt.
    
2. **Single ‚Äúprimary parent‚Äù.** You can have cross-links, but the tree‚Äôs backbone is one parent per node (DAG optional via a separate edges table).
    
3. **One source of truth at a time.** Either you‚Äôre pushing DB ‚Üí Obsidian or pulling Obsidian ‚Üí DB. No ‚Äúboth at once.‚Äù
    

# Representation

## In the database (CSV now; easy to lift to SQLite later)

- `nodes.csv` (one row per node)
    
    - `node_id` (UUID)
        
    - `title`
        
    - `type` (`goal|skill|program|task|trip|sla|folder`)
        
    - `domain` (e.g., cooking, exercise)
        
    - `parent_id` (nullable)
        
    - **Tree bits:** `order_index`, `weight_in_parent`, `value_budget`, `decay`, `importance_weight`
        
    - **Cadence bits (optional):** `recurring`, `max_interval_days`, `last_done`
        
    - **Constraints (optional):** `disciplines_required`, `prev_ids` (comma-sep)
        
    - `tags` (comma-sep), `status`, `slug`
        
    - `last_modified`, `last_modified_by` (`obsidian|db`)
        
- (Optional) `edges.csv` for secondary parents/cross-links: `src_id, dst_id, kind` (e.g., `references`, `supports`)
    

## In Obsidian (authoring UX)

- **Folders = internal nodes.** Put a tiny metadata note in each folder, e.g., `_node.md`.
    
- **Notes = leaves (or actionable nodes)** inside those folders.
    
- Every `_node.md` and leaf note has YAML like:
    
    `node_id: a12b-...-z9 title: Travel-Friendly Cooking type: program domain: cooking parent_id: 91ff-...-c3 order_index: 20 value_budget: 60 weight_in_parent: 0.6 recurring: false tags: [camping, cooler]`
    
- Why `_node.md`? Folders don‚Äôt have metadata; this file _is_ the folder‚Äôs node.
    

# Sync directions

## Import (Obsidian ‚Üí DB)

1. Walk folders; read `_node.md` + notes.
    
2. **If `node_id` present** ‚Üí update existing row.  
    **If missing** ‚Üí mint UUID, write it back (or stage for a ‚Äúfix IDs‚Äù pass).
    
3. Build parent links from the folder structure (`parent_id = folder‚Äôs _node.md.id`).
    
4. Validate: no cycles, all `parent_id` exist, duplicate titles OK (IDs unique).
    
5. Write/merge into `nodes.csv`. Record `last_modified_by=obsidian`.
    

## Export (DB ‚Üí Obsidian)

1. Pick a **root `node_id`** (or multiple).
    
2. Materialize subtree:
    
    - Folder per internal node (`{order_index}_{slug}/` to keep your order).
        
    - Write `_node.md` with YAML mirroring DB.
        
    - Write leaves as notes with frontmatter.
        
3. Two export modes for cross-links:
    
    - **Materialized**: duplicate child under multiple parents (simple, but copies).
        
    - **Referenced**: keep a single canonical location, and under other parents place an `index.md` with Dataview links to the canonical child (no duplicates).
        
4. Record a **manifest** `node_id ‚Üî path` so renames/moves are tracked.
    

# Re-rooted ‚Äúviews‚Äù (your ‚Äúexport different trees with different parents‚Äù)

- You‚Äôre really exporting a **view** of the DAG. Do it two ways:
    
    - **Materialized view**: copy the subtree under a new root (good for short-term editing).
        
    - **Referenced view**: create an index folder whose note lists children via `Dataview` queries (zero duplication, always up to date).
        

# Ordering & readability

- Use `order_index` in DB. On export, prefix folder/file names with it (`20_Travel-Friendly`) so Obsidian‚Äôs alphabetical sort matches your intent.
    
- Keep a `slug` for stable filenames. Title can change without path chaos.
    

# Hierarchy-aware value & cadence (fits your earlier logic)

- Parents can hold `value_budget` and/or accumulate bottom-up ‚Äúhierarchy value‚Äù (HV) from children using decay.
    
- SLAs live as nodes; lateness computed from event logs (tagged notes or external tracker).
    
- A completed leaf credits **all ancestors** on its path (per your chosen credit rule).
    

# Integrity checks (automate these)

- Missing `_node.md` for a folder ‚Üí create it.
    
- Note without `node_id` ‚Üí warn or assign and log.
    
- `parent_id` points to unknown ‚Üí quarantine as orphan.
    
- Detect multiple `_node.md` in a folder.
    
- Cycle detection on import; refuse to write an invalid tree.
    

# Workflow you‚Äôll like (no code, just flow)

1. **Draft** structure in Obsidian (folders/notes).
    
2. **Import** ‚Üí DB (assign IDs, validate, compute ancestor/descendant sets).
    
3. Use DB for **planning** (feasibility, leverage, cadence, blended priorities).
    
4. **Export** back to Obsidian as:
    
    - A canonical tree (materialized), or
        
    - One or more **views** (referenced via index notes).
        
5. Rinse, repeat‚Äîone direction per session to avoid conflicts.
    

# Why this will scale

- IDs keep identity stable across renames/reorgs.
    
- `_node.md` gives folders real metadata.
    
- CSV schema future-proofs to SQLite/Postgres later.
    
- Views let you reorganize _presentations_ of the same underlying graph without duplicating truth.
    

If you want, I can sketch a tiny ‚Äúround-trip contract‚Äù (what fields must never be edited by hand in Obsidian, which ones are user-editable, and how conflicts are resolved). That‚Äôs the last mile that keeps this zen instead of zany.

	- [[00_Assets and Liabilities]]
- In principle, this could all be rolled into a single class.

Features:
- Some things are going to be required (e.g. data capture) to accomplish the business use case.

Methods:
- These are 'technical implementations'; how will we actually do xyz?
	- e.g. [[Account Status Rollout]]

Tickets:
- These are basically "todo".
- I considered calling them *tasks* but that name is sort of taken in the obsidian context.

Use Cases:
- These are business use cases.

Related
[[Load budget definition from gsheets Predicted_spending into Pyfi]]

Background - Presently, we have 3 different budget category definitions:
- Google Sheets Cash Flow Sheet, 
- Current Pyfi Ingest Categorization, 
- Google Sheets "Budget Categories"

Goal - Single standardized budget category hierarchy. 
Open questions: 
- Is there a reason to have more than one category Schema?
	- If yes, what are the required Schemas?
- Is there value in using *labels* (tax deductible, travel or whatever), or some type of bools?
- Gross vs Net income?
	- We should decide how we want to deal with Taxes, 401k etc vs actual "spending"

Thoughts:
- The cash flow sheet seems like it's been doing pretty well.

body:
FE Balance - On payday - "How much money can I move out of my fixed expense account?"
		- What are the upcoming transactions out of that account?

Every pay day I go through the same rigmarole where I check:
1. which bills are due between this and the next payday.
2. which bills do I need to pay 'manually' (i.e. not autopay) ‚Üí pay them
3. figure out how much I need to leave in the account for auto payments (incl. buffer).
4. move the surplus out of the account (into savings, debt servicing etc).

Currently - I use the google calendar as the 'source of truth' for upcoming payments.

# Ratios
## Emergency Ratio fund
see also: [[Runway Calcs]]
-  savings/(average monthly spend)
- savings/(average "need"categor monthly spend)
- saving/(budget "Needs" monthly spend)

# Debt-Service Ratio
- Monthly Debt Payments / Monthly Income

# Liquidity Ratio
- (Cash + Liquid Assets) / (Net Worth)

# Debt-to-Assets Ratio
- Total Debt / Total Assets

# Savings Average Ratio
- Average Monthly Savings / Average Monthly Spending
- With/without 401k?
- Gross vs net?

# Lifestyle Inflation Ratio
- Change in spending / change in income

# Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR)
((ending value)/(beginning value))^(1/years) - 1

# description
I initially developed this concept around choosing travel destinations, but it applies more widely. 

**Example**
When choosing a destination for my next trip, I might be trying to decide between a kayak trip to Finland, and an eating trip to Morocco. The choice is between adventure, and culture. To make these options quantitative and explicit: 
- if I weight "adventure" higher than "culture" I would likely choose the kayak trip.
- whereas if I weight "culture" more heavily, I might choose a trip to Morocco

The blended sorting framework deals with the question of:
- What weighting values result in the options being equal?

# Journal
## Workflow Dream

### Weekly Planning Manual Procedure 
1. Populate calendar with required and high priority tasks:
	1. Cooking, cleaning, grocery, gym, piano
2. Review remaining open time slots
	1. Decide how to spend them
		1. Software, etc
		2. Consider how much time was spent on a topic in the last few weeks.
	2. Pull up a queue of tasks using a tree filter to decide what tasks to schedule. 

### With automation
#### Daily Planning
User Story - Pull up a detailed plan for the day with details on :

#### Weekly Planning
**Focus** - understanding which related tasks, in some cases from different components, should be grouped together so that product increment contain meaningful holistic functionality improvements.
- Decide how many work blocks to spend in each domain/product.
#### Monthly
**Focus** - breaking down big goals into bite size tasks (one hour blocks)

#### Blue Sky planning
**Focus** - generate big picture ideas for goals and product direction

# tldr Where do I quickly write down tasks that need to be done? How do I surface, and sort, and prioritize tasks? How do I relate tasks to goals, features, skills, products? # About **Bifr√∂st** is the bridge between intention and execution. It spans the gap between fleeting thoughts (captured quickly via mobile or desktop) and their full realization as logged accomplishments, skill development, or product outputs. It provides an operational framework for identifying, refining, executing, and archiving tasks across domains. **Responsibilities:** - Capture tasks across all domains via lightweight input methods (e.g., Google Tasks, quick-entry inboxes) - Classify tasks by domain, related skill/product nodes, priority, and type (e.g., admin, creative, procedural) - Promote significant tasks to Obsidian-based "tickets" with structured metadata, subtasks, and logs - Maintain a Master Task Index (CSV or M√≠misbrunnr table) for filtering, grooming, and planning - Integrate with Planner Framework (**Skapandi**, **Nornir**) and Execution Logs **Features:** - Lightweight ‚Üí Deep pipeline (fast entry ‚Üí structured task notes) - Supports YAML metadata for domain, status, tags, and links to Tree of Becoming components - Enables weekly review, kanban sorting, and reflection - Serves as an interface layer between personal logistics and the deeper narrative architecture of Threads, Goals, and Trees **Long-Term Vision:** Bifr√∂st will act as the arterial system of Yggdrasill‚Äîkeeping the whole organism moving. In future versions, it will synchronize with M√≠misbrunnr, display live dashboards via Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf, and support planning automations via the Nornir. **Aliases:** - The Task Bridge - Intent-to-Action Pipeline - Ticketing + Task Execution Layer # Scope within Yggdrasill ‚úÖ **Domain: Task Management** From your **Definitive Domain List**, "Task Management" is already a first-class domain. So it has its own place in the forest‚Äîworthy of its own Skill and Product nodes. --- ## üåø **How It Maps to the Tree‚Äôs Core Components** |Tree Component|Role of Task Management| |---|---| |**Skill Tree**|Task management itself is a meta-skill: GTD, time-blocking, backlog grooming, etc. You‚Äôre training your ability to organize, prioritize, and execute.| |**Product Tree**|Could include tools you've built (e.g. task-tracking scripts, dashboards) and completed task batches or planning systems.| |**Planner Framework**|This is where your daily/weekly scheduling logic lives. You‚Äôre building the muscles of strategic and tactical execution here.| |**Checklist Templates**|Think: Daily routine templates, Weekly review checklist, Sprint planning process.| |**Execution Logs**|Each completed task or work session becomes a log entry. These could even be auto-generated from Obsidian notes.| |**Threads**|Task-related narrative: What got done, what felt hard, what shifted your approach. Especially useful during reviews.| |**Mapping Table**|Links tasks (or systems that manage tasks) to skills (e.g. ‚ÄúWeekly Review‚Äù) and goals (e.g. ‚ÄúLaunch Product X‚Äù).| |**Visualization (Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf)**|Eventually: drag-and-drop backlog grooming across domains. Filter by blocked/unblocked status. Sort by domain/priority/skill.| |**M√≠misbrunnr (Data Well)**|Central storage: list of tasks, metadata, categories, timestamps, completion logs. Your "Task Master Index" could live here.| --- # Version Plan üß≠ Strategic Guidance for Implementation ### ü•á MVP Concept: ‚ÄúThe Bifrost Bridge‚Äù Treat your task system as the bridge between raw intentions and finished artifacts. ### Step 1: Establish Your Layers 1. **Fast Capture** (Google Tasks or mobile inbox) 2. **Processing Layer** (Review ‚Üí Obsidian notes or structured rows in a Sheet) 3. **Deep Work Layer** (Obsidian notes w/ properties) 4. **Master Index** (CSV/Google Sheet ‚Üí Future: M√≠misbrunnr table) ### Step 2: Define a ‚ÄúTicket Template‚Äù in Obsidian Let each significant task have a note with: - Title, status, priority - Skill and product tags - Related domain - Work log - Subtasks - Links to Tree Nodes or Threads ### Step 3: Capture Execution Logs This can be simple: - Daily notes in Obsidian - Use `dataview` or a Python script to auto-generate a running log - Future: Streamlit visualization or task dashboard # Solution options üîß **Overview of Your Options** | Approach | Pros | Cons | | ----------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | **Google Tasks** | ‚úÖ Super lightweight
‚úÖ Mobile friendly
‚úÖ Built into Gmail/Calendar | ‚ùå No rich metadata
‚ùå No hierarchy
‚ùå Weak linking or filtering | | **Obsidian Notes (1/task)** | ‚úÖ Rich context per task
‚úÖ Easy to Kanban (with plugins)
‚úÖ Filters/tags/properties
‚úÖ Logs and links to related notes | ‚ùå Slower capture
‚ùå Less frictionless on mobile
‚ùå Requires maintenance | | **Google Sheets / Excel** | ‚úÖ Easy entry/filter/sort
‚úÖ Good for backlog grooming
‚úÖ Shareable if needed | ‚ùå Limited task context
‚ùå Not great for daily flow or deep work | | **Hybrid (Tasks ‚Üí Obsidian)** | ‚úÖ Fast capture + deep follow-up
‚úÖ Scales from lightweight to full work tickets | ‚ùå Requires syncing logic
‚ùå Potential for duplication / stale info | --- ## üß≠ Recommendation: Start Simple, Evolve Smart Since you‚Äôre ultimately integrating this into the **Tree of Becoming**, I recommend a **hybrid architecture with modular discipline**: --- ### üå± **v0.1 Workflow Recommendation** #### ‚úÖ **Capture Layer** Use **Google Tasks** (or a quick Google Form + Sheets) for fast, frictionless entry. - Fast input anywhere (phone, browser) - Weekly review migrates some to Obsidian - You can tag entries like `#tango`, `#finance`, `#cooking` in the title if helpful #### üìò **Depth Layer** Use **Obsidian** for tasks that are: - Multi-step - Worth logging (i.e. building a product or skill) - Part of the Tree of Becoming (linked to a node or checklist) **Structure per task-note:** - YAML with status, project, domain, etc. - Work log section - Link to Product/Skill nodes - Checklist of subtasks Example filename: `TASK - Build Streamlit Category Editor (pyfi)` #### üìä **Meta Layer** Keep a **Google Sheet or CSV** (can be versioned in Git) that acts as: - A task index / map - High-level filtering and batch tagging - Review snapshot (e.g. progress tracking by domain) Eventually, this can be upgraded into **M√≠misbrunnr**. --- ## üîÑ **Sync Strategy v0.1** A basic manual or semi-scripted sync: 1. Tag larger Google Tasks with a marker like `[TICKET]` if they need a note. 2. During review, create an Obsidian note for these tasks. 3. Log note location in your Google Sheet master index or create backlinks. Once that workflow feels solid: - Write a script that: - Scans Google Tasks or Sheets - Creates markdown files for marked entries - Optionally pulls note properties back into your index --- ## üß† Tips for Scaling - Use **daily/weekly planning templates** in Obsidian to pull in active tasks (via Dataview or Tasks plugin). - Create views for `#blocked`, `#priority`, `@person`, or even link to scheduled calendar blocks. - Track which tasks link to Skill Tree / Product Tree nodes so you‚Äôre always building toward something. --- ## üéØ MVP for Tree of Becoming Integration - ‚úÖ Google Tasks = raw "Task Pool" - ‚úÖ Obsidian = "Execution Log + Skill/Product Mapping" - ‚úÖ Sheet = Master Task Index (could evolve into M√≠misbrunnr table) ---

# Dream state

Workflow:
- I write stuff into Google Tasks.
- AI Agent reviews it and make a suggestions as to where it should go
	- "Task Classifier"
	- Example: 
		- I write an idea "use the leftover dill weed, from salad, to make tzatziki"
		- AI Agent takes that task:
			- Suggests an association with the skill tree, i.e. cooking
				- And whatever labels make sense
			- Suggests a list of related tasks, i.e.:
				- Check recipe database for Tzatziki recipe
					- If it doesn't exist, find some online examples.
				- Check inventory of other tzatziki ingredients
				- If I don't have them, add them to a shopping list, as an option.
- Other possible suggestions
	- When to make the tzatziki, i.e. put it on the calendar.
	- It knows I'm going to the store, it suggests to adding missing ingredients to my shopping list.
	- It might present a few options:
		- Make it today with lime instead of lemons.
		- Go to the store today, to get lemons, make it tonight or tomorrow.
			- Move another thing that was calendared.
			- "Weather is nice, <75 F, you have a goal to get exercise, may I suggest a walk?" 
		- Go to the store tomorrow, as already scheduled, make it the day after.
- After AI makes suggestions, I approve and/or correct the changes.

How this might play out in practice:
- I say "hey chat, what do you think of using this leftover dill weed to make tzatziki"
- Response: "Great idea! After checking the recipes, your goals, and the weather may I suggest doing laundry tomorrow and instead walking to the store to get lemons and cucumber"
- Optional 
	- Conrad response: "justify your suggestion"
	- Chat: "You have goals around exercise, the weather is <75 F, so nice for walking, you have a tzatziki recipe with good reviews. The last time you made it was X date and you made it with X some recipe. Tomorrow is light and you have time to do laundry before going to work the day after."
- Optional 2:
	- Conrad: "I don't really want to go to the store. Can I simplify or make a substitute verions?"
	- Chat: "Sure! Let's make it with lime instead of lemon. You don't have any cucumber but perhaps could add habanero or bell pepper, which you have, to give it some flavor"

# Bifr√∂st Design Doc

## About
**Bifr√∂st** is the bridge between intention and execution. It spans the gap between fleeting thoughts (captured quickly via mobile or desktop) and their full realization as logged accomplishments, skill development, or product outputs. It provides an operational framework for identifying, refining, executing, and archiving tasks across domains.

### Responsibilities
- Capture tasks across all domains via lightweight input methods (e.g., Google Tasks, quick-entry inboxes)
- Classify tasks by domain, related skill/product nodes, priority, and type (e.g., admin, creative, procedural)
- Promote significant tasks to Obsidian-based "tickets" with structured metadata, subtasks, and logs
- Maintain a Master Task Index (CSV or M√≠misbrunnr table) for filtering, grooming, and planning
- Integrate with Planner Framework (**Skapandi**, **Nornir**) and Execution Logs

### Features
- Lightweight ‚Üí Deep pipeline (fast entry ‚Üí structured task notes)
- Supports YAML metadata for domain, status, tags, and links to Tree of Becoming components
- Enables weekly review, kanban sorting, and reflection
- Serves as an interface layer between personal logistics and the deeper narrative architecture of Threads, Goals, and Trees

### Long-Term Vision
Bifr√∂st will act as the arterial system of Yggdrasill‚Äîkeeping the whole organism moving. In future versions, it will synchronize with M√≠misbrunnr, display live dashboards via Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf, and support planning automations via the Nornir.

### Aliases
- The Task Bridge
- Intent-to-Action Pipeline
- Ticketing + Task Execution Layer

---

## Functionality

### Scope within Yggdrasill
**Domain: Task Management**  
From your **Definitive Domain List**, "Task Management" is already a first-class domain. So it has its own place in the forest‚Äîworthy of its own Skill and Product nodes.

### Tree Component Mapping

| Tree Component              | Role of Task Management                                                                 |
|----------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Skill Tree**             | Task management is a meta-skill (e.g., GTD, backlog grooming).                           |
| **Product Tree**           | Tools/scripts/planning systems built or executed.                                       |
| **Planner Framework**      | Houses strategic/tactical scheduling logic.                                             |
| **Checklist Templates**    | Includes reusable checklists like weekly review.                                        |
| **Execution Logs**         | Completed tasks/work sessions.                                                          |
| **Threads**                | Narrative around task work, challenges, decisions.                                       |
| **Mapping Table**          | Links tasks to skills/products/goals.                                                   |
| **Visualization (Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf)** | Enables kanban sorting, domain filters, etc.                                     |
| **M√≠misbrunnr**            | Central task storage (task master index).                                               |

---

## Solution Options

### Overview of Approaches

| Approach                      | Pros                                                                 | Cons                                                               |
|------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Google Tasks**             | ‚úÖ Lightweight, mobile-friendly, integrated                           | ‚ùå Lacks metadata/hierarchy/linking                                |
| **Obsidian Notes (1/task)**  | ‚úÖ Rich context, filters, logging, links                               | ‚ùå Slower capture, less mobile-friendly                            |
| **Google Sheets / Excel**    | ‚úÖ Easy input/filtering, groomable backlog                             | ‚ùå Not ideal for deep work or narrative tracking                   |
| **Hybrid (Tasks ‚Üí Obsidian)**| ‚úÖ Scales from quick capture to full workflow                          | ‚ùå Requires syncing logic, risk of stale duplication               |

---

### v0.1 Workflow Recommendation

#### Capture Layer
Use Google Tasks or Google Form + Sheets:
- Fast capture via mobile/desktop
- Weekly review ‚Üí promote key tasks to Obsidian
- Use hashtags in titles for domain tagging

#### Depth Layer
Use Obsidian for tasks that are:
- Multi-step or meaningful
- Connected to goals/skills/products

Structure each note with:
- YAML frontmatter (status, tags, domain)
- Work log
- Subtasks
- Links to tree nodes or threads

Example: `TASK - Build Streamlit Category Editor (pyfi)`

#### Meta Layer
Track all tasks in a Google Sheet or CSV (eventually M√≠misbrunnr):
- Filter/sort/groom
- Review snapshots
- Task-to-tree linkage

---

### Sync Strategy v0.1

Start manual:
1. Tag Google Tasks that need a ticket
2. Weekly review ‚Üí create Obsidian note
3. Record note location in index

Later:
- Scripted sync: pull from Tasks or Sheet ‚Üí generate markdown
- Backfill metadata to index

---

### Tips for Scaling
- Use Obsidian templates + `dataview`/Tasks plugin
- Build views for `#blocked`, `#priority`, etc.
- Cross-link tasks to skill/product nodes to stay aligned with the Tree

---

### MVP Integration Summary
- ‚úÖ Google Tasks = "Task Pool"
- ‚úÖ Obsidian = "Execution + Mapping"
- ‚úÖ Sheet = "Task Index" (future ‚Üí M√≠misbrunnr)

# Main Decisions
- Allocate 8 non-strato work blocks a week to user stories and/or features and/or domains.
- Prioritize Task Notes

body:
# # Description
Every day I have tasks and ideas pouring in: 
- google tasks
- obsidian tasks
- obsidian task notes
- etc

For sorting guidelines, see: 
- [[Obsidian Note Property "Type" - Description & Disambiguation]]

# Steps
- [ ] Review Kanban Boards and task lists
- [ ] Decide what to tackle next and what to save for later.
- [ ] Schedule things that need to be scheduled.
- [ ] Create a list of "could be done when I manage to get to it"

# As a feature
## Feature Summary
1. Drop everything into the daily journal note
2. Have a defined workflow to process the journal notes.

## Feature Description
Basic outline of a procedure:
- so you wrote out a vision of what you want to build, does this vision exist already as a user story?
- So you thought about how you‚Äôd accomplish your vision, are these future features? Is this description already captured somewhere?
- So you brain dumped some things you need to / want to do:
	- do they exist already as task notes or procedures?
		- should they?

Related:
- [[TM-P-01 - Daily Task Planning]]
- [[TM-P-01a - Daily Task Logging]]
- [[TM-P-01b - Next Day Task Prioritization and Scheduling]]

- [ ] First alarm 0740
- [ ] Morning Routine - 08am
	- [ ] Close the windows
	- [ ] Drink Water
	- [ ] Eat breakfast
	- [ ] Make Coffee
- [ ] Work Start Routine - 0830
- [ ] Work Block 1 - 0845
- [ ] Work Block 2 - 1000
- [ ] Exercise - 1100
- [ ] Shower - 1230
- [ ] Eat Lunch - 1300
- [ ] Make Coffee
- [ ] Work Block 3 - 1330
- [ ] Work Block 4 - 1445
- [ ] Piano - 1600
- [ ] Next day planning & Shutdown - 1630
	- [ ] log completed items
	- [ ] funnel new items
	- [ ] Prioritize next days tasks
	- [ ] [[SW-P-1 Closing work for the day]]
- [ ] Flex Time 1 - 1700/1730
	- [ ] Language
	- [ ] Social Media Posts
	- [ ] Secondary Exercise
	- [ ] Errands & Shopping
	- [ ] Call a friend
	- [ ] Plan a trip
	- [ ] etc
- [ ] Cook & Eat dinner - 1800
- [ ] Kitchen clean up - 2030
- [ ] Flex Time 2 - 2100-2300
- [ ] Complete [[TM-P-01a - Daily Task Logging]]
- [ ] Bedtime routine - 2300
	- [ ] Lock the doors
	- [ ] Make sure AC is off
	- [ ] Open the windows
	- [ ] Fill a glass of water (to keep bedside)
	- [ ] Refill the humidifier
	- [ ] Start the humidifier
	- [ ] Brush teeth
	- [ ] Wash your face / skin care
	- [ ] Check time of first meeting
	- [ ] Set the alarm
	- [ ] Turn the lights off
- [ ] in bed - 2330

# Description

After allocating to high-priority and required items, I have about 8 working sessions a week to assign.

The goal of this procedure is to formalize the exact steps to prioritizing what tasks get worked on.

Tasks should be decomposed to a reasonable level (~1 hr) before being assigned.

# Steps

- [ ] Tasks and goals should be decomposed already.
	- see [[Tree of Tasks]]
Creating a new procedure entirely

# ChatGPT
**Conrad said**
ok great progress today! This is where I'm at: (1) I have a working proof-of-concept for the tree viewer using streamlit and threejs. It currently relies on a very simple csv that has two columns {item, parent} and from this simple CSV it builds the whole tree, (2) I have a good idea of how to create good dashboards using obsidian dataviewer {and tasks to some extent}. I need some recommendations, given what you know about me and my project, for how I will link the tasks to the trees (product tree, skill tree, goal tree). The most obvious way, for now, is to have a dedicated frontmatter obsidian property and/or use tags in some way to link things together. what do you think?

###### ChatGPT said:

Now we‚Äôre cooking with the fires of **M√≠misbrunnr**‚Äîyou‚Äôve got a real-time tree visualizer _and_ a structured dashboard system in Obsidian. That‚Äôs huge. You're not just building infrastructure anymore‚Äîyou're building a **living system**.

So let‚Äôs tackle this question:

---

## üß† Goal:

**Link tasks (and other notes) to your Trees**:

- Skill Tree
    
- Product Tree
    
- Goal Tree
    

These connections should:

- Be human-editable in Obsidian
    
- Be parsable/exportable to CSV/JSON for the tree viewer or other systems
    
- Be future-proof for syncing between Streamlit and Obsidian
    
- Support one-to-many mappings (a task might touch multiple skills/products/goals)
    

---

## ‚úÖ Recommendation: Use **frontmatter + namespaced tags**

Why both? Because:

- **Frontmatter = structured + parseable** ‚Üí for downstream use (Tree viewer, Streamlit, etc.)
    
- **Tags = searchable + clickable** ‚Üí for vault-native use (Tag pane, backlinks, visual grouping)
    

This combo gives you **machine-parsable structure** + **Obsidian-native ergonomics**.

---

## üß± Canonical Structure

### ‚úçÔ∏è In your task note:

yaml

CopyEdit

`--- project: Hlidskjalf domain: cooking skills: [egg.technique.souffle, baking.timing.precision] products: [recipe.eggsouffle.v3] goals: [nutrition.optimize.breakfast] tags: [#task, #product/eggsouffle, #skill/baking/precision, #goal/breakfast] ---`

markdown

CopyEdit

`- [ ] Bake and document the goat cheese version`

---

## üîó How This Links to the Trees

|Frontmatter Field|Linked Tree|
|---|---|
|`skills`|Skill Tree|
|`products`|Product Tree|
|`goals`|Goal Tree|

These fields should contain **tree addresses** or paths. You already use `{item, parent}` to construct the tree‚Äîso this fits like a glove.

Examples:

- `baking.timing.precision` ‚Üí represents a node in Skill Tree
    
- `recipe.eggsouffle.v3` ‚Üí node in Product Tree
    
- `nutrition.optimize.breakfast` ‚Üí node in Goal Tree
    

---

## üß∞ Tools That Benefit From This

|Tool|How It Uses This|
|---|---|
|**Tree viewer (Streamlit + threejs)**|Parse the frontmatter fields ‚Üí draw links from Tasks to Skill/Product/Goal nodes|
|**Dashboard (Dataview)**|Group and filter tasks by skill/product/goal path|
|**Future: Execution Logs**|Auto-link task execution to mapped tree nodes|
|**Future: Planners**|Recommend skills to train or products to push forward based on frequency or gaps in mapping|

---

## üß† Bonus: Tag Namespacing

Your tags like `#product/eggsouffle` or `#skill/piano/lockedhands` will:

- Show up cleanly in the **Tag Pane**
    
- Be usable in `tasks` or `dataview` queries
    
- Let you click across related notes manually
    

Even if a parser ignores the tag, **you won‚Äôt**.

Task Filter Note: 
- Leaving out "Procedures" folder, since those are considered reusable templates
- Leaving out "Execution Logs" folder, since those are (supposedly) done
- Leaving out "mock planner output", since it's just a mock

```tasks
path does not include procedures
path does not include execution logs
path does not include mock planner output
```

Almost everything, every little idea, is a "task", with a checkbox.
- One issue: In a perfect world, tasks would have a "status" and wouldn't really show up
	- Possible Workarounds: 
		1. tag all new tasks with "proposed" or "new" or similar.
			1. In the daily sheets/dashboards, this is filtered out

More involved tasks, and procedures, get their own obsidian note.
- The obsidian note can be linked into the tasks and will show up where the task shows up.


# Linking
## üîó How This Links to the Trees

| Frontmatter Field | Linked Tree  |
| ----------------- | ------------ |
| `skills`          | Skill Tree   |
| `products`        | Product Tree |
| `goals`           | Goal Tree    |

These fields should contain **tree addresses** or paths. You already use `{item, parent}` to construct the tree‚Äîso this fits like a glove.

Examples:
- `baking.timing.precision` ‚Üí represents a node in Skill Tree
- `recipe.eggsouffle.v3` ‚Üí node in Product Tree
- `nutrition.optimize.breakfast` ‚Üí node in Goal Tree

body:
Future Features
- "Smart" handling of tasks that got scheduled but not completed. 
	- **Example** - *I was going to do Bmajor scale yesterday and F# major today. I didn't do the B major scale, what is scheduled for today?*
		- Two modes:
			- "Pile-up", i.e. both are due today
			- "Bump" - B major scale is due today.

# Dream

**Calendar items** - exist with the (an instance) of the applicable procedure and the "time to beat" (see )

Name: Nested Procedures
Type: Feature Request
Component: [[task management - description]]
Status: Proposed
## Feature Description
I want to be able to link procedures, so that after completing on, the scheduler "automatically" know to select the child.

Conversely, I also want a concept of "prerequisite procedure"
	- i.e. when I select a recipe, it should know that I need to: make a shopping list, check inventory, go to the grocery store if necessary.
## Suggested implementations
**Option A:**
Frontmatter in Procedure A defines Procedure B as a "child" procedure.
When Procedure A is completed, the scheduler, i.e. Bifr√∂st, sets the status of the child Procedure to "Selected" or "Todo" (or other as appropriate).
*Example -* 
- Procedure A is "cook this recipe". 
- Procedure B "give feedback on this recipe".
- After completing Procedure B, the scheduler surfaces Procedure B.

**Option B:**
We define a "feature tree" via a folder structure.

body:
# ChatGPT 
## ‚öôÔ∏è **Feedback Routing Architecture**

### üß© 1. **Capture Point**:

Every checklist run (i.e., execution instance) becomes the _anchor point_ for all feedback.

- ‚úÖ **Execution Log ID** ties all feedback to:
    
    - Specific **Checklist Run**
        
    - Specific **Planner Output** (if applicable)
        
    - **Time of Execution**
        
    - **Version** of Procedure/Template used
        

---

### üóÇÔ∏è 2. **Feedback Classification**:

Each piece of feedback is tagged by **type**, and routed to one or more components:

|Feedback Type|Routed To|Examples|
|---|---|---|
|‚úÖ Deviation from Procedure|Checklist Template / Run Notes|‚ÄúUsed 1-inch of goat cheese instead of 2 TBL‚Äù|
|‚ùì Skill Uncertainty|Skill Tree (flag node as ‚Äúattempted‚Äù)|‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt know what whipped egg whites look like‚Äù|
|üìà Skill Development Task|Planner ‚Üí add to context or queue|‚ÄúFind a video of egg white peaks‚Äù|
|üçΩÔ∏è Recipe Modification|Product Tree (suggest update)|‚ÄúTry lemon zest for more brightness‚Äù|
|üõ†Ô∏è Tool/Equipment Gap|Shopping List (+ tag source)|‚ÄúAdd electric mixer, needed during this run‚Äù|
|üîß Calibration Data|Domain-Specific Sheet (e.g., oven calibration)|‚ÄúSet oven to 412¬∞F for a true 350¬∞F‚Äù|
|‚è±Ô∏è Procedural Timing Insight|Checklist Template metadata or Run Notes|‚ÄúOven is warm after 20 min‚Äù|
|üß† Cognitive/UX Friction|Planner context or future thread/journal|‚ÄúThis step felt ambiguous/confusing‚Äù|

---

### üîÅ 3. **Processing Strategy**

- **Immediate capture** happens via the checklist UI (e.g., Streamlit text boxes or structured forms during execution).
    
- **Post-run processing**: After the run, a lightweight workflow lets you:
    
    - Review captured notes
        
    - Route items to their respective targets
        
    - Flag updates (e.g., propose product revisions, queue a new learning task, mark a tool for purchase)
        

---

### üìå 4. **Data Storage & Linkage**

Each captured feedback point stores:

- The **source execution log ID**
    
- The **target** (skill node, product node, checklist template, etc.)
    
- **Timestamp**
    
- Optional tags (`flavor`, `tool`, `timing`, etc.)
    
- Status (e.g., `logged`, `queued`, `implemented`)
    

Stored centrally in **M√≠misbrunnr**, enabling future:

- Queries by type/date/target
    
- Surfacing at planning time (e.g., show oven timing tip next time a baking checklist is loaded)
    

---

### üìä 5. **Surfacing Mechanisms**

- üß† **Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf** can:
    
    - Show tool recommendations during planning
        
    - Warn about known quirks (e.g., ‚ÄúOven runs hot!‚Äù)
        
    - Display ‚Äúlast time you ran this‚Äù summaries
        
- üìÖ **Planner Framework** can:
    
    - Prioritize skills recently marked as ‚Äúattempted but incomplete‚Äù
        
    - Auto-insert micro-tasks like ‚Äúwatch tutorial on egg whites‚Äù

body:
How do I plumb the:
- journal notes,
- Execution Logs, 
- Procedure logs, 
back into their correct spot?

Incl. data regarding
- Feedback/redlines on how to improve procedures.
- New ideas generated today - for example tasks.
- Implementing changes to the goal, product, skill trees based on new information.
- etc

## üîÑ Routing Strategy

|Feedback Type|Routed To|Mechanism|
|---|---|---|
|Deviation|Product or Checklist Template|Backlink from run note + optional tag|
|Skill Gap|Skill Tree Node|Create or tag skill note + link from run|
|Improvement Idea|Product Node|Proposal block or linked note|
|Tool Needed|Shopping List|Append or link directly from run note|
|Calibration|Calibration Note|Standardized location by domain|
|Derived Data|Metadata Block in Template or Tag Note|Optional embedded block, tagged for search|

**On the procedure**
- Procedure says x, should say y.

**For next time**
- 10 lb felt light, let's do 15 lb next time.

**New/Open Questions & Areas of further research**
- What is the proper technique to perform this exercise?

file_name: UPP-TM- Task Management User Pain Points.md
body:
# Task tracking
## Tracking, sorting, ordering *my* actions
Planning step:
- Hourly - i.e. bring up the correct thing to do no, whether it's
	- A scheduled procedure: clean the kitchen, do the laundry, workout etc
	- An agenda for a meeting: 
		- What tasks are open for this {topic=Purdue} call?
			- Is there a Jira board?
		- Want to surface follow ups: "What did you think about this email I sent? Did you get a chance to look at it?"
- Daily - what do I *need* to accomplish today.
	- Schedule -> be able to see what is already on the schedule for today
	- Surfacing -> be able to see what tasks are open
		- Prioritize unscheduled tasks.
- Weekly -

## Tracking, sorting, ordering, following up on, *other people's* (and agents) actions.
What is so and so working on? 
- What should they work on next? 
	- Why?

At some cadence, I want to follow up on other people's actions to see where we are at.
	- I'm happy to set a follow up date for any action assigned to a different person.
	- The follow-up date has to get updated, if they send me a response/info/update before then.

## Task allocation - review step
- Time allocation - 
	- What was the plan for time allocation?
	- What did the actuals end up being?

## Related Procedures
- [[TM-P-01 Surface my actions]]
- [[TM-P-02 Surface meeting topics and generate meeting agendas]]



# Task editing
How do I:
1. Quickly create new tasks
	1. Map them correctly to domain, parent, estimated duration, blockers/blocking etc
2. Edit the property of a task 
	1. A task was completed -> I want to change the status.

# Supported User Stories
## Current Nominal 
**Capture** - In the moment, I capture my hopes, thoughts, dreams, desires, ideas in a {fixed location}
- For example a daily journal: [[journal_template]]

**Task and Note Sorting** - a regular cadence, I go through all the daily journals and direct the notes to their correct location. 
- See [[TM-P-01 - Daily Task Planning]]
- Children:
	- [[Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf Feature 1 - Kanban board for task sorting]]

**Prioritization and Scheduling** - Decide where to spend my time via [[TM-P-01b - Next Day Task Prioritization and Scheduling]]

**Task Logging** - Log where the time was spent via [[TM-P-01a - Daily Task Logging]]

## Future
**Time Spent Review** - Tools and methods to see where time actually got spent.
**Automatic Calendar Generation** - Based on settings related to priorities, how much time I want to spend on particular branches (Music, cooking, exercise) and possibly constraints (how much time on cooking -> picks recipes based on their predicted duration)

Note: a procedure instance might replace an ‚ÄúExecution Log‚Äù

# Component Requirements
Shall make procedure instance, ie checklist, for a given run of a given procedure.
Shall support multiple domains:
- Cooking
- Piano
- Travel / Packing
- Exercise
- Financial Procedures
- Etc
Shall produce, or interface with a component that produces, a task execution log.
# Feature Descriptions
Feature 1 - Copies a procedure template and turns it into an executable checklist. 
Feature 2+ - Generates procedures/checklists based on ‚Äúsome logic‚Äù. Examples:
- Packing list based on number of nights, weather, and planned activities (work, dance, flying, etc)
- Scaling a recipe 
- Piano practice routine, ie ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs Scale: D major‚Äù
# Implementation Versions
v0.0 - manually copy-paste a template into a procedure

v0.1 - obsidian native functionality to one time copy, ie not live link, contents of one note into another.
v1 - linearly scale a recipe
v2 - conditional logic

# About
Intent of the task priority solver is to provide a deterministic method to organize, prioritize, and surface tasks in order to decide what to work on next.

# Conceptual Examples
**Using a trip example** - 
Where do I take my next trip?
- I want to go to Scotland for tasting whisky, visiting Isle of Barra, and possibly do some kayaking.
- Kayaking there is potentially pretty extreme, I should do some more local trips first.
e.g. there are two axis: cultural interest, and kayak prerequisites.

**Explicit actions**
1. Feasible/Admissable set is anything with no incomplete blockers.
	1. Going to kayak in the San Juans is a skill prerequisite to going to Scotland to kayak.
2. Prioritization strategies along multiple axis, i.e. Kayak Skill, and Cultural interest.
3. Novel blending method, implemented with a slider to blend between axis.

# Other ideas
I want to track: "workout 3x a week" separately from "I want to do cardio at least 1x a week". Even though "cardio" is a child of "workout"
- See discussion: [[cadence hierarchies]]

# Versions
¬† **Solver Versions:**
¬† ¬† ‚ÅÉ v0 - Hide all items with incomplete blockers, then sort by {some value}
¬† ¬† ‚ÅÉ V1 - Add cadence-based list; what is most overdue, or coming up next.
¬† ¬† ‚ÅÉ V2 - Add ‚Äúunblocking‚Äù score; how many tasks, either directly or children of children, does this task unblock?
¬† ¬† ‚ÅÉ V3 - What is the value/leverage of all of the downstream tasks?
¬† ¬† ‚ÅÉ V_far_future - it automatically recommends what to work on next, based on the above. Is able to justify and explain "why this" when questioned.

That‚Äôs helpful. Let‚Äôs discuss another example to refine this even further. Let‚Äôs say I have a minimum of ‚Äúexercise‚Äù every n days. Separately, I want to make sure to hit ‚Äúkettlebell agility training‚Äù (a child of exercise), at some other (lower) frequency. Now, I want to somehow surface the kettlebell workout, if it‚Äôs overdue, even if I have been working out a lot. (1) is my description understandable?, (2) would the framework you have proposed support this functionality that I just described?

###### ChatGPT said:

Thought for 17s

Short answer: yes and yes.

1. Is your description understandable?  
    ‚Ä¢ Crystal. You want two cadences in the same tree: a parent SLA (‚Äúdo any exercise every n days‚Äù) and a child SLA (‚Äúdo kettlebell agility every m days‚Äù), and you want the child to surface when late even if the parent is on time.
    
2. Does the framework support it?  
    ‚Ä¢ Yep. Treat SLAs as first-class nodes with their own scopes and timers. Your ‚Äúunlocker + cadence‚Äù setup already handles this cleanly.
    

How to think about it:

‚Ä¢ Define SLAs independently  
‚Äì SLA: Exercise ‚áí scope = any workout; max_interval = n days  
‚Äì SLA: Kettlebell Agility ‚áí scope = workouts tagged kettlebell_agility; max_interval = m days  
‚Äì A single kettlebell session can satisfy both scopes (it counts for ‚Äúany exercise‚Äù and for ‚Äúkettlebell agility‚Äù).  
‚Äì If you‚Äôve been running a lot (parent green) but no kettlebell in 10 days (child red), the child SLA shows up as overdue. That‚Äôs the behavior you want.

‚Ä¢ Lateness is per-SLA, not inherited  
‚Äì lateness = (now ‚àí last_event_in_scope) / max_interval  
‚Äì Parent lateness = computed on its own scope (OR-mode: any exercise).  
‚Äì Child lateness = computed on its narrower scope (kettlebell_agility).  
‚Äì Parent green does not mute child red. Independent rows = independent alerts.

‚Ä¢ Surfacing logic (UI)  
‚Äì ‚ÄúDue/Late‚Äù view lists all SLAs; sort by lateness desc, then domain weight.  
‚Äì Pin ‚ÄúOverdue child SLAs‚Äù at the top so they can‚Äôt be buried by parent greens.  
‚Äì Show which parent(s) each SLA ladders into (e.g., Exercise ‚Üí Strength ‚Üí Kettlebell Agility).

‚Ä¢ Scoring (if you blend with leverage)  
‚Äì Cadence score = lateness ratio (‚â•1 means late).  
‚Äì Final priority = cadence_score boost √ó domain_weight √ó (optional leverage).  
‚Äì Overdue child gets a big cadence bump; it rises above generic ‚Äúdo any exercise‚Äù when late.

‚Ä¢ Schema sketch (no code, just structure)  
‚Äì events: id, timestamp, tags=[exercise, kettlebell_agility, ‚Ä¶]  
‚Äì sla_nodes: id, name, scope_predicate (tag filter), max_interval_days, domain_weight  
‚Äì For each sla_node: last_done = max timestamp of events matching scope_predicate ‚Üí compute lateness ‚Üí rank.

‚Ä¢ Tree interaction  
‚Äì Keep SLAs as nodes aligned with the hierarchy (Exercise parent; Kettlebell Agility child).  
‚Äì For roll-ups: parent SLA uses OR-mode (any child activity satisfies).  
‚Äì Children keep their own clocks. No double-counting of lateness; double-credit for satisfaction is allowed (one kettlebell hit can green both).

Edge cases you‚Äôre covered on:  
‚Ä¢ Lots of workouts, no kettlebells ‚Üí parent green, child red ‚Üí kettlebell surfaces.  
‚Ä¢ Only kettlebells recently ‚Üí both green (counts for both scopes).  
‚Ä¢ Multiple children with their own SLAs ‚Üí each child has its own clock; parent stays green as long as any qualifying exercise happened.

Net: your description is solid, and the framework supports it by treating cadence as per-node SLA clocks with independent scopes. The parent ‚Äúhealth‚Äù is OR-based; the child‚Äôs lateness is its own. When child is late, it pops to the top‚Äîeven if you‚Äôve been a gym rat otherwise.

**Purpose**
The Task Estimation Framework's primary purpose is to provide a means by which we can answer the question: "when will x be at y state?"
- This is question is possibly better known by it's less friendly variant: "when will x be ready?"

**Components**
Three primary components:
- Task sizing framework - how much effort is a particular task or tree of tasks?
- Bandwidth allocation budget - how much effort are we putting into a particular task or tree of tasks.
- Estimated completion - Size of the task divided by the allocation budget will give a ready date.

# Component Descriptions

## Task Sizing Framework
Only by having an estimate of the task, can we have any idea when it will be ready.
See also -> confidence.

**Favorite** - option 3
- 1 pt = 7 min
- 2 pt = 15
- 4 pt = 30
- 8 pt = 60
- 16 pt = 2 hrs
- 32 pt = 4 hrs
- 64 pt = 8 hrs
- 100 pt = 2 days
- 200 pt = 4 days
- 400 pt = 8 days

**Option 1**
- 1 pt = ~10 min or less
- 2 = 20 min
- 3 = 30 min
- 5 = ~1 hr
- 8 = 1.5-2 hrs
- 13 = 2 hrs
- 21 = 3.5 hrs
- 33 = 5.5 hrs
- 54 = 9 hrs 
- 100 = two days -> switching to powers of two for bigger tasks.
- 200 = 4 days
- 400 = 8 days
- 800 = 16 days

**Option 2**
- 1 pt = 10 min
- 2 pt = 20
- 4 pt = 40
- 8 pt = 80
- 16 pt =
- 32 pt = 
- 64 pt = 

## Bandwidth Allocation Framework
A formalized version of saying: "I want to spend 10% of my time on A, 15% on B, etc"
- Should always add up to 100%.

Multiple variants:
- "Manual" - aka "desired", aka "target". A manual target or selection made by a human
- "History" - looking back, how much time did we actually spend:
	- Can be viewed across multiple windows -> daily, weekly, monthly, whatever
- "Error" - Compares the target to the history, i.e. "for a given date: target was x, actual ended up being y" 
- "Corrected" - 
	- Target was x, i.e. "here is what Conrad set."
	- Historically, error has been y.
	- Corrected -> Based on the target, and the past errors, this is what we think the actual is likely to end up being.

## Estimated Completion
Multiple different flavors for multiple combinations of the Sizing and the Bandwidth.

# description
Task prioritization and surfacing framework constructs pools of feasible tasks and prioritizes them.

There are a few concepts included:
- filtering tasks by prerequisite - I might only want to see tasks that do not have any incomplete preqrequisites
- blocking value - what is the value of the tasks that a certain task is blocking? Direct children? Recursively?
- simple sorting -> I might sort tasks by "difficulty" or by "value" or some other metric.
- blended sort -> I initially developed this concept around choosing travel destinations, but it applies more widely. 
# definitions
A **feasible** task is a task that has no incomplete prerequisites, i.e. it is not blocked. 
**Stability Region** - 
# value estimation
Value is central to surfacing, as value/effort ratio is a primary concern. 
Effort is characterized via the [[tm_task_estimation_framework]]

# Solution Exploration and Information gathering
- What are the path options?
- Where is more info needed?
- What is the selection criteria?

# Decision tracking and recording
- "This is what we decided and why" -> implications for follow on-steps
	- Tasks on other paths can be set to archive.
	- Tasks blocked by a decision, can be unblocked.

**Description**
Once the checklist, from the [[prod_tree/product_task/yggdrasill/components/exercise_module/checklist_maker]], is filled out, takes that and writes it to the [[exercise_history_table]]

## üéØ 1Ô∏è‚É£ **‚ÄúKnowing‚Äù What Was Planned**

**Concept:**
- You maintain a record of **planned workouts** and **actual workouts**.
- They are stored separately but linked by date (or by ‚Äúsession ID‚Äù).

**Example Data Model:**

|session_id|date|exercise|sets|reps|weight|plan_or_actual|
|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
|2024-W27-1|2024-07-01|Squat|3|5|100|planned|
|2024-W27-1|2024-07-01|Squat|3|5|100|actual|

This separation lets you:

- **Compare** (what you planned vs what you did).
    
- **Compute deltas** (did you overperform? underperform? skip?).
    

---

## üéØ 2Ô∏è‚É£ **Capturing Progression Rules**

Here‚Äôs where most people get intimidated‚Äîbut it‚Äôs simpler than you think.

**Think of progression rules as metadata attached to an exercise.**

‚úÖ Example:

yaml

CopyEdit

`Exercise: Squat Progression: Linear Progression Increment: +2.5kg per week Progression Conditions: Complete all sets and reps this week Deload Trigger: Fail to hit target reps for 2 consecutive sessions`

**This is just structured data you define once.**

Then, your script can:

- Check if last week was completed successfully.
    
- If yes, increment weight by +2.5kg.
    
- If not, keep weight the same or deload.
    

‚úÖ Other progression types:

- **Double progression**: e.g., ‚ÄúAdd reps until you hit 3x8, then add weight and drop reps.‚Äù
    
- **RPE progression**: ‚ÄúWhen sets feel easier than RPE 7, add load.‚Äù
    
- **Auto-regulation**: ‚ÄúIf you felt fatigued, reduce volume.‚Äù
    

---

## üéØ 3Ô∏è‚É£ **Generating Next Week‚Äôs Plan Automatically**

This is the sweet spot where:

- You can either **encode rules in your own Python logic**, or
    
- Use the **ChatGPT API to generate the plan dynamically**.
    

**Examples:**

**Local Rule-Based Logic:**

- If all sets were completed as planned:
    
    - Add 2.5kg.
        
- Else:
    
    - Keep weight the same.
        

‚úÖ Fast, reliable, reproducible.

**AI-Generated Logic (ChatGPT):**

- Send last 4 weeks‚Äô logs and say:
    
    > ‚ÄúPropose next week‚Äôs progression for each exercise, considering fatigue and adherence.‚Äù
    
- Get a text or JSON plan back.
    

‚úÖ Flexible, nuanced recommendations.

‚úÖ Useful if you want it to feel like a coach.

---

## üéØ 4Ô∏è‚É£ **Settings and Complexity Management**

This is where people often get stuck thinking:

> _‚ÄúOMG there are so many options to configure!‚Äù_

**Tip:**  
Don‚Äôt start by trying to make it fully customizable from Day 1.

Instead:

‚úÖ **Phase 1:** Hard-code simple progression rules.  
‚úÖ **Phase 2:** Add optional parameters you can set in YAML per exercise.  
‚úÖ **Phase 3:** Build a UI or config file for editing progression settings.

**Example YAML:**

yaml

CopyEdit

`squat:   progression: linear   increment: 2.5   deload_trigger: 2_failed_sessions bench_press:   progression: double_progression   target_reps: 8   increment: 2.5`

---

## üéØ Putting It All Together

‚úÖ **Your workflow could look like this:**

1. **Define a Plan**:
    
    - A YAML or table with planned sessions.
        
    - Progression rules per exercise.
        
2. **Log Actual Workouts**:
    
    - Markdown table or form.
        
    - Parsed into structured data.
        
3. **Compare Plan vs. Actual**:
    
    - Automatically compute completion.
        
4. **Generate Next Plan**:
    
    - Python logic OR ChatGPT API.
        
5. **Output Next Plan**:
    
    - Markdown checklist ready to paste into Obsidian.
        

---

## üü¢ Example ChatGPT Prompt for Plan Generation

If you go the AI route:

> **Prompt:**
> 
> You are a strength training coach. Here is my training history for the past 4 weeks:
> 
> yaml
> 
> CopyEdit
> 
> `Squat: - Week 1: 3x5 @ 100kg - Week 2: 3x5 @ 102.5kg - Week 3: 3x5 @ 105kg - Week 4: 3x5 @ 107.5kg Bench Press: ...`
> 
> My progression rule is linear +2.5kg per week if all sets completed. If any session is missed or sets incomplete, repeat weight. Please generate next week‚Äôs plan in JSON format.

‚úÖ **ChatGPT replies with a clean JSON you parse.**

---

## üéØ TL;DR

This **is** a lot of moving parts, but each part is small and solvable:

- **Data storage:** Keep plan + actual separate.
    
- **Progression logic:** Start simple, expand as needed.
    
- **Generation:** Rule-based or AI-based.
    
- **Output:** Markdown + JSON so it‚Äôs both human- and machine-readable.
    

---

body:
It's annoying to have to sit down and plan my piano practice.
I want to take 10 min a week (not 60) and set some goals and have it spit out my routine.
Also, if it has something I don't like, I want to be able to reject it and have it give me a new thing.

It "feels like" there is a fair bit of overlap between:
- Selecting Recipes -> making a shopping list, on one hand, and
- Set broad piano goals -> create a specific routine for a specific day, on the other.

Also,

```yaml
component: Eldsskr√°
type: recipe_management_tool
version: v1.0

description: >
  Eldsskr√° is a structured tool for managing recipes, ingredients, meal logs, and culinary
  planning. It acts as a fire-tempered scroll: a living repository of food preparation,
  experimentation, and nourishment rituals.

functionality:
  - Stores recipes with metadata (tags, difficulty, domains, ingredients)
  - Supports recipe nesting and subcomponent reuse (e.g., sauces, doughs)
  - Tracks cooking events and logs with time/date, modifications, outcomes
  - Enables shopping list generation and inventory planning
  - Integrates with Goal Tree and Planner Framework (e.g., for dietary routines)

structure:
  recipe_entry:
    - name: string
    - description: string
    - ingredients: list
    - steps: ordered list
    - tags: list of strings
    - difficulty: enum [easy, medium, hard]
    - domains: list of culinary domains
    - subrecipes: optional references

linked_components:
  - M√≠misbrunnr (storage)
  - Planner Framework
  - Checklist Templates
  - Execution Logs

naming_origin: >
  "Eldsskr√°" combines "eldr" (fire) with "skr√°" (scroll), forming a name that evokes the
  idea of a sacred or practical log of fire-based transformation. It honors food as
  process, memory, and ritual.

status: active

```

Going from an idea for a recipe -> checklist creation -> capture "as run" notes -> feed back into both the recipe instance itself, as well as the recipe and checklist creation process.

# Idea
There is a solver that takes the recipe, and optimizes the steps:
- i.e. 
	- instead of:
		- in a bowl mix A,B,C
		- in another bowl mix, D, E, F
	- it has:
		- Gather ingredients A, D, F from the fridge
		- Gather ingredients B, C, D from the pantry
		- Get two medium sized mixing bowls
		- Get measuring spoons from the drawer:
			- One TBL spoon
			- One 1/4 tsp spoon
		- In bowl 1 mix:
			- 1 TBL A
			- 1/4 tsp B
		- etc etc

Basically, the solver takes in the "large scale" goals, and creates a motion plan from it.

body:
Related: [[Architect Execution Log Workflow]]

The recipe definition and creation in the python *recipes* app was quite clunky.

One issue is that in some cases recipes and meals are an amalgamation of sub recipes and steps.

One option:
- Define a recipe procedure or skill as a series of steps using Obsidian Tasks.
- Define an "aggregate recipe" as an amalgamation.

Observation:
- Recipes consists of a few main sections: 
	- Ingredients,
	- Tools,
	- Process/Procedure.
- What we're talking about here is only referring to the process/procedure portion.

Is there a way to make a Grocery List natively in Obsidian by leveraging:
- Dataview / Tasks / Dataviewjs
- The "Recipe Status" property, i.e. aggregate all of:
	- Type = Recipe
	- Recipe Status = Selected

This can give you a list of recipes, but parsing and aggregating the ingredients might be difficult, especially if we want more complex logic:
- Sort ingredients by preferred vendor
- Sort ingredients by section/location in store
- etc

*Data item types -*
- Product - something a user interfaces with.
- User story - functionality that a user wants typically from a product.
- Component - something a developer interfaces with, i.e. python package, class, file etc.
- Feature - functionality of a software component.
- Procedure - a series of steps that the user executes to complete a task.

*Visualization element types -* 
- Tree diagram - Useful for displaying hierarchy and taxonomies.
- Time series plot - for displaying financial, exercise, cooking data. 
- Sequence table- essentially a table sorted by priority. Useful for seeing what's next for a particular component, skill, person, agent, topic, etc.
- Gantt charts - useful for reviewing order and relative difficulty of tasks.
- Checklists aka procedures - useful for executing tasks and capturing the results.

**Architecture**
Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf is the visualization framework/product. I am currently in the process of scoping the work for version 2.0.
Bifr√∂st is the procedure management framework. It's primary interface with Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf is via the checklist functionality.
M√≠misbrunnr is the database. I am currently primarily using Obsidian, where effectively each row, of a table, is represented as a note. It interfaces with both Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf and Bifr√∂st since it hosts the data for both.

# v0.2 - Python
## Streamlit checkbox interface with Notes backend
The checkbox interface (of Obsidian tasks and of Google Tasks) is really nice. In a perfect world, I'd have a checkbox interface (like Tasks) but in the backend it's moving status of Notes around. This gives the completion experience of using Task checkboxes, but the Obsidian Kanban functionality of Projects (when that is needed) as well as linking tasks to goals, skills etc through the Notes Metadata.

## Tracing parent lineage
From a certain standpoint it should be enough for every note to have one parent to establish linkage and hierarchy. However, now I‚Äôm at the point where I want to define a lot of Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf ‚Äúviews‚Äù that I want to use in various procedures, so the questions here are:
- What‚Äôs the best way to define and link these views so I can surface the task note for their creation at the correct time and place?
**Example**
I have multiple views I want to create and define. Notionally any combination of daily, weekly, monthly, and calendar, kanban, checklist, sequence with associated metadata and types.
I have a user story that a user wants to complete a particular procedure with a particular view. Then I might have versions of this view as I move from obsidian to streamlit and task notes associated with doing the work to increment the version.

A ‚Äúsingle-parent only‚Äù linkage paradigm/methodology would likely be: 
- procedure -> user story -> Yggdrasill Version -> Yggdrasill Feature -> Yggdrasill Feature Version -> Hl√≠√∞skj√°lf Feature -> Hl√Æ√∞skj√°lf Feature Version -> Task note -> tasks

From a developer (as opposed to PM) standpoint, it can be relatively easy to see the user story -> task note linkage, ie if the user wants to accomplish x, then we need to build y. I think it‚Äôs just tripping me up that there is such a huge version control organizational overhead and that I need like 10 notes to capture a task and link it correctly. 
- What exactly does all that complexity buy me?

I feel like a better PM workflow might be to define the thin slices:
- Procedure - user story - yggdrasill feature - hlid feature - task notes
Then Schedule the user story and the associated features and let the versions fall out of that.

## **Documentation** ‚Äî ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs true, regardless of status‚Äù

Human-readable. Persistent. Explains the **what, why, and how** of the system _at any given point in time_.  
If a new dev joins tomorrow, they should be able to read it and understand the thing without knowing today‚Äôs to-do list.

### Examples

‚úÖ Clear cases (obvious):
- API reference for a component.
- Design rationale for an algorithm choice.
- ‚ÄúHow to run the test suite‚Äù guide.
- Architectural diagrams of subsystems.
    
‚ö† Murky cases (watch out):
- **‚ÄúPending‚Äù ideas** ‚Äî if it‚Äôs speculative _and_ not yet approved, it probably belongs in the task tree, _not_ docs.
- **Partially implemented features** ‚Äî document only what‚Äôs live or committed to be live soon; capture the ‚Äúfuture plan‚Äù in the task tree.
- **Known limitations** ‚Äî these can go in docs, _but_ also link to the task(s) tracking the fix.
- **Deprecated workflows** ‚Äî still belong in docs (marked deprecated) so people understand the history, even if there‚Äôs a related ‚Äúremove this‚Äù task.

---

## **Task Tree** ‚Äî ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs next or what‚Äôs changing‚Äù

Machine-readable. Status-driven. Tracks **intentional change over time** ‚Äî what‚Äôs being built, fixed, refactored, or removed.  
If nothing in the system changed for a month, the task tree should still evolve as tasks get completed, closed, or reprioritized.
### Examples
‚úÖ Clear cases (obvious):
- ‚ÄúAdd CSV export to reporting API.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúRefactor database connector to async.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúFix bug in step-size calculation.‚Äù

‚ö† Murky cases (watch out):
- **Technical debt notes** ‚Äî if it‚Äôs a ‚Äúwe should fix this someday,‚Äù it‚Äôs a task, not doc.
- **Design alternatives** ‚Äî if they‚Äôre under consideration, capture in tasks; once chosen, the _selected path_ goes in docs.
- **Experiment results** ‚Äî if the outcome will decide future work, it‚Äôs task tree material; if the outcome changes how the system works, that belongs in docs.
- **Performance benchmarks** ‚Äî if they‚Äôre routine monitoring, docs; if they‚Äôre part of a planned improvement effort, task tree.
    

---

## **Simple decision rule**

> If it‚Äôs **describing the state of the system as it is (or will be, once released)** ‚Üí Documentation.  
> If it‚Äôs **describing work to change the state of the system** ‚Üí Task Tree.

---

## **Linking the two**
Because the ambiguous cases often _straddle_ both worlds:
- **Docs** should _link to tasks_ for ongoing work (‚ÄúThis module has a known race condition ‚Äî see task `rs_245` for fix plan‚Äù).
- **Tasks** should _link to docs_ for background (‚ÄúThis change modifies `src/auth/session.py` ‚Äî see `docs/components/auth/session.md` for architecture‚Äù).

---
###### Conrad said:
Where do I put simple code examples, pattern demonstrations and snippets I want to keep? Source code folders? Docs? Separately?
###### ChatGPT said:
Here‚Äôs the clean breakdown for where to put those, and why ‚Äî because if you just start throwing ‚Äúcool snippets‚Äù into `src/` they‚Äôll rot faster than fruit in a sauna.

---
## **Rule of thumb**
- If the snippet is **live, tested, and part of the system** ‚Üí belongs in **source code** (with tests in your test folder).
- If it‚Äôs **reference material, patterns, or how-to examples** ‚Üí belongs in **docs**.
- If it‚Äôs **pure sandbox / experimentation** ‚Üí keep it in a **separate ‚Äúplayground‚Äù or ‚Äúscratch‚Äù folder** that is _not_ part of production build/test.

---
### **1. Production code (source folder)**
‚úÖ Snippets that:
- Are implemented as part of a package/module your system uses.
- Pass tests and are deployed as part of normal releases.  
    Example:

python

CopyEdit

`# src/utils/json_helpers.py def load_json_file(path):     """Load a JSON file and return parsed data."""     with open(path) as f:         return json.load(f)`

Here, the ‚Äúsnippet‚Äù _is_ the product. It lives in `src/` and has a matching test.

---
### **2. Documentation (examples & patterns)**
‚úÖ Snippets that:
- Demonstrate usage of your public APIs.
- Show ‚Äúbest practices‚Äù for patterns you want to encourage.
- Are not meant to be imported directly into production.

**Why:** They live to _teach_; they‚Äôre not maintained in lockstep with source code except for breaking API changes.  
Example location:

bash

CopyEdit

`docs/examples/authentication/using_api_token.md docs/patterns/retry_strategy.md`

These can embed fenced Python code blocks and link to the actual implementation.

---

### **3. Playground / sandbox folder**
‚úÖ Snippets that:
- Are experiments you might reuse later.
- Are half-baked and not production-ready.
- Don‚Äôt need to pass CI or meet code style rules.

Example:

markdown

CopyEdit

`playground/     pattern_experiment_1.py     weird_sqlalchemy_trick.py`

This folder is intentionally excluded from CI/test discovery and (often) from version control history once it‚Äôs stale. You might `.gitignore` it or prune aggressively.

---

## **Why separate them?**
- **Source folder**: must stay lean, intentional, and testable ‚Üí scaling benefit: avoids bloat & keeps CI fast.
- **Docs**: human-oriented, easy to retrieve for AI or onboarding.
- **Playground**: freedom to try things without risking ‚Äújunk DNA‚Äù in production.

# Runestone Cheat Sheet: **Docs vs Task Tree**

|Situation|Put in **Docs** (human-readable, persistent)|Put in **Task Tree** (machine-readable, statusful)|**Borderline ‚Üí Decision**|
|---|---|---|---|
|API/class/module reference|‚úÖ Public API, usage, examples, constraints|‚ùå|If it‚Äôs _planned_ not built ‚Üí Task (spec ticket). Once merged ‚Üí Docs.|
|Design rationale / architecture|‚úÖ Rationale, trade-offs, diagrams|‚ùå (except link to the doc)|If alternatives are still under consideration ‚Üí Task(s) for evaluation; after decision ‚Üí capture the chosen path in Docs.|
|Implementation plan|‚ùå|‚úÖ Steps, owners, status, dependencies|If plan is ‚Äúfinalized‚Äù but not executed ‚Üí still Task. Summarize the _why_ in Docs after it ships.|
|Known limitations|‚úÖ Describe current limitation, impact, workaround|‚úÖ Link to fix task(s)|If it affects users now ‚Üí document it; always link the fix task ID(s).|
|Bugs|‚ùå|‚úÖ Repro steps, severity, scope, owner|If the bug implies a change to public behavior, add a brief note in Docs _after_ fix ships.|
|Performance profile & SLOs|‚úÖ Published benchmarks, SLAs/SLOs|‚úÖ Improvement tasks & experiments|If it‚Äôs an experiment with pending decisions ‚Üí Task; stable baseline numbers ‚Üí Docs.|
|Experiments/Spikes|‚ùå (link only)|‚úÖ Hypothesis, method, acceptance criteria|If the result changes behavior or guidance ‚Üí record result in Docs.|
|Roadmap / feature descriptions|‚úÖ High-level ‚ÄúWhat/Why‚Äù for users & maintainers|‚úÖ Concrete feature tickets with priorities|Docs = narrative + intent; Tasks = execution + status.|
|Coding conventions / style|‚úÖ Canonical guide|‚ùå|Enforcement tasks (lint/mypy adoption) live in Task Tree.|
|Test strategy|‚úÖ Principles, coverage targets, examples|‚úÖ Gaps and specific test-add tickets|If a gap is discovered ‚Üí Task; once standardized ‚Üí Docs.|
|Migrations / deprecations|‚úÖ Public guidance, timelines, ‚Äúhow to upgrade‚Äù|‚úÖ Implementation steps, cutovers, warnings|If dates/process are fluid ‚Üí stage in Task; publish in Docs when locked.|
|Security & compliance|‚úÖ Policies, threat model summaries|‚úÖ Findings, fixes, audits as tasks|Sensitive details belong in Task (private); publish only safe summaries in Docs.|
|Ops runbooks|‚úÖ Playbooks, dashboards, on-call notes|‚úÖ Follow-up action items|If a runbook step requires code change ‚Üí Task linked from the runbook.|
|Example code / patterns|‚úÖ In `docs/examples` with explanations|‚ùå|If an example becomes production code ‚Üí move to `src/` + create tests; keep a trimmed example in Docs.|
|Configuration schemas|‚úÖ Human-readable schema & examples|‚úÖ Enforcement/validation tasks|If schema is unstable ‚Üí keep in Task (draft); publish stable schema in Docs.|

---

## Minimal frontmatter templates (to wire Docs ‚Üî Tasks)

**Docs (Markdown)**

markdown

CopyEdit

`--- id: cmp.obsidian.validator type: component source: src/obsidian/validator.py tests: tests/obsidian/test_validator.py features: [feat.obsidian.qc] runestones: [rs_001, rs_017] status: live --- # Obsidian Validator (Architecture, rationale, usage, gotchas‚Ä¶)`

**Task (YAML)**

yaml

CopyEdit

`id: rs_017 type: feature title: Add required-field checks to Obsidian validator components: [cmp.obsidian.validator] features: [feat.obsidian.qc] docs:   - docs/components/obsidian/validator.md status: in_progress acceptance:   - Detect missing title, type, parent   - Return structured report`

---

## Decision rules (for the murky bits)
- If it **describes work to change the system** ‚Üí Task.
- If it **describes the system as it is (or will be once merged)** ‚Üí Docs.
- If it‚Äôs **speculative or undecided** ‚Üí Task; link from Docs only if users must know.
- When the **decision lands** ‚Üí commit the decision to Docs; keep the execution in Tasks.
