file_name: potential future work - sorting along multiple axis.md
file_path: /home/conrad/git/yggdrasill/dev/domains/task_management/topological_sort/potential future work - sorting along multiple axis.md
body:
Awesome questions. Short, sharp, useful:

## (1) Does the ‚Äúcritical-blend slider‚Äù extend beyond 2 metrics?

**Yes, with a caveat.**  
You can generalize by driving a **single slider along a path in weight space** (the (m‚àí1)-simplex for m metrics). Pick a piecewise-linear path between corner weight vectors (e.g., 1000% on distance ‚Üí 1000% on culture ‚Üí 1000% on cost ‚Üí ‚Ä¶).  
‚Ä¢ On each segment, weights are linear in t: **w(t) = (1‚àít)a + t b**.  
‚Ä¢ Two items i,j swap when **w(t)¬∑(x·µ¢‚àíx‚±º) = 0 ‚áí t* = ‚àí(a¬∑Œîx)/((b‚àía)¬∑Œîx)** (same breakpoint idea, just higher-dimensional dot products).  
‚Ä¢ Collect all segment breakpoints, dedupe, sort ‚Üí discrete slider steps ‚Üí **every tick changes order**.  
**Caveat:** a single 1-D slider can‚Äôt explore _all_ possible orderings in m>2; it only explores those along your chosen path. This is usually fine for UI (3‚Äì6 metrics is practical). If you need more coverage, add more segments or switch to a 2-D controller (e.g., a triangular ‚Äúweight joystick‚Äù for 3 metrics).

## (2) Methods for >2 metrics (robustness vs complexity)

### A) Piecewise-Linear Scalarization (PWL utility)

**What:** Transform each metric with a monotone **piecewise-linear utility** u‚Çñ(¬∑) (captures diminishing returns, thresholds), then combine: **U(x)=‚àë w‚Çñ u‚Çñ(x‚Çñ)** with **‚àëw‚Çñ=1000**.  
**Multi-dim support:** Any m.  
**Pros (robustness):**  
‚Ä¢ Scale-insensitive (you shape each u‚Çñ)  
‚Ä¢ Expressive (knees/plateaus) yet still compensatory (bad on one metric can be offset by others).  
‚Ä¢ Our breakpoint trick still works along any weight path (just replace raw metrics with u‚Çñ(x‚Çñ)).  
**Cons:**  
‚Ä¢ Still a weighted-sum at heart ‚Üí can miss strongly non-compensatory or ‚Äúmust-meet‚Äù preferences unless you encode them into u‚Çñ or add constraints.  
**Complexity:** Low‚Äìmoderate. Define knots ‚Üí compute u‚Çñ ‚Üí same O(S¬∑n¬≤) breakpoint precompute per path segment (S=segments).

### B) Œµ-Constraint Method

**What:** Pick one metric to optimize (primary score) and turn the others into **hard constraints**: x‚ÇÇ‚â§Œµ‚ÇÇ, x‚ÇÉ‚â§Œµ‚ÇÉ, ‚Ä¶ Sweep Œµ to traverse the Pareto set.  
**Multi-dim support:** Any m. Handles **non-convex** fronts (unlike pure weighted sums).  
**Pros (robustness):**  
‚Ä¢ Truly **non-compensatory**: fails a bound ‚Üí not eligible.  
‚Ä¢ Captures ‚Äúmust meet‚Äù thresholds naturally (great for feasibility-first planning).  
**Cons:**  
‚Ä¢ UI has multiple Œµ‚Äôs. To keep a **single slider**, define a **staircase path** through Œµ-space (e.g., progressively tightening the strictest metric, then the next, etc.).  
‚Ä¢ Each step can change the _feasible set_ rather than just the ordering, which is sometimes exactly what you want.  
**Complexity:** For discrete ranking: precompute unique threshold lists per metric (O(m¬∑n log n)); each step filters + sorts. Slider steps = changes in feasibility along your path.

### C) Other solid multi-metric choices (quick hits)

‚Ä¢ **Tchebycheff (Chebyshev) scalarization:** minimize **max‚Çñ w‚Çñ¬∑|x‚Çñ‚àíideal‚Çñ|**. Good for non-convex Pareto sets; emphasizes worst metric. Breakpoint math is slightly trickier (max operator), but you can still step a weight path and detect order flips numerically. Robust; moderate complexity.  
‚Ä¢ **TOPSIS:** score = proximity to ideal & distance from anti-ideal (with weights). Multi-dim out of the box. To get ‚Äúevery tick changes,‚Äù compute breakpoints along a weight path where relative closeness ties change; closed form may be messy ‚Üí use safe numerical root-finding. Robust; moderate complexity.  
‚Ä¢ **Pareto layers (‚Äúskyline peeling‚Äù):** show nondominated set, then peel next layer. No weights needed; different vibe (great overview). Slider can walk layers; every tick changes membership, not necessarily a full total order.

## Practical guidance

‚Ä¢ **If you want one slider and predictable behavior:**  
Use the **piecewise linear path in weight space + breakpoint slider**. Works for 3‚Äì6 metrics, fast, and always ‚Äúdoes something.‚Äù  
‚Ä¢ **If you need hard must-meet limits or non-convex tradeoffs:**  
Add **Œµ-constraints** (even alongside the slider) to gate eligibility; then rank the feasible set via your blend.  
‚Ä¢ **If users care about the worst metric:**  
Offer a **Chebyshev mode** toggle.  
‚Ä¢ **If you want zero weights and pure fairness:**  
Add a **Pareto layer view** to complement the slider.

Want me to sketch a 3-metric version with a triangle (barycentric) controller and the same breakpoint logic along a polyline path around the triangle edges?

```mermaid graph TD A[Local Lake Trip
Beginner] --> B[Intermediate River Trip
Intermediate] B --> C[Argentina Expedition
Advanced] D[Italy Cultural Tour
Beginner] --> E[Norway Fjords
Intermediate] ```

# Description
How it works:

Prerequisites chains are established for each discipline.

The "feasible set" is simply those items whose prerequisites have all been met.

The feasible set is then sorted by various values:
- Trip Distance
- Trip Cultural Value

**Follow on work**
From here we, in principle, could assign a value metric to distance and/or cultural value (and/or have this on a slider) and then sequence the feasible set. 

# Versions
## v0
## v1
## v2
## v3

## v3+ Potential Follow on work
# Retrospective Notes
Great work today on Task Management. The basic concept for sorting:
- Exclude all tasks or items with incomplete prerequisites. This produces a "feasible set"
- The simplest treatment of the feasible set is just to order them along some axis, in the example case for choosing a travel destination these might be: 
	- Kayak difficulty
	- Cultural Interest.
- Me and ChatGPT developed a "trick" way of sorting. I don't really understand how it works but there is one slider that moves from ordering in the "kayak difficulty" to the "cultural interest". The "Trick" is that every move of the slider impacts the Global Priority List
- Future could involve setting up a value function across multiple axis.

# Simple Explanation
# (1) The ‚ÄúTrick‚Äù ‚Äî Plain-English, no math headache

**What problem we‚Äôre solving**
- You have two reasons to rank trips: distance and cultural value.
- A normal slider often does nothing for several clicks. Boring.
- We want every slider tick to actually change the list order.

**The idea in one breath**
- First filter to **feasible trips** (all prerequisites met).
- Then rank those trips by a **blend** of distance and culture.
- We pre-find the exact slider positions where the order would change.
- We make the slider stop only on those positions. Every tick = new order.

**How it works**
- Think of distance and culture as two ‚Äújudges.‚Äù
- We normalize them so both speak the same scale (0‚Äì1, lower is better).
- For each trip, imagine a **score line** that slides from ‚Äúonly distance‚Äù to ‚Äúonly culture‚Äù as you move the slider.
- Two trips swap places only at specific slider values (their lines cross).
- We compute all those **flip points** in advance.
- The slider clicks through those points (plus the ends). No dead clicks.

**What the ends mean**
- Slider at the left = sort purely by distance.
- Slider at the right = sort purely by culture.
- In between = sensible, deterministic blends that actually reorder items.

**Why the UI feels great**
- Every tick changes something. No placebo clicks.
- It‚Äôs predictable: same data ‚Üí same sequence of views.
- You can ‚Äúscan‚Äù the trade-off space quickly without wasted motion.

**Bonus: the 1000-sum weights**
- We show weights as `w_dist + w_cult = 1000` so it‚Äôs clear how much each judge matters.
- Under the hood, it‚Äôs just a rescaled version of the same blend trick.

**Bottom line**
- Filter to feasible.
- Normalize the two scores.
- Compute where the list would flip.
- Lock the slider to those flips.
- Every click earns its keep.

# (2) The ‚ÄúTrick‚Äù ‚Äî Engineer Edition (you‚Äôve seen linear algebra)

**Goal**  
Make a slider that _always_ changes the sorted order of trips by blending two metrics (distance, culture) without dead ticks.

**Setup**
- Work only on the **feasible** set (constraints already satisfied).
- Convert both metrics to **costs**: lower is better.    
- Normalize each metric so they‚Äôre comparable:
Min‚Äìmax: di=Di‚àímin‚Å°Dmax‚Å°D‚àímin‚Å°Dd_i=\frac{D_i-\min D}{\max D-\min D}di‚Äã=maxD‚àíminDDi‚Äã‚àíminD‚Äã, ci=Ci‚àímin‚Å°Cmax‚Å°C‚àímin‚Å°Cc_i=\frac{C_i-\min C}{\max C-\min C}ci‚Äã=maxC‚àíminCCi‚Äã‚àíminC‚Äã
    - Or rank-normalize to [0,1] (monotone-invariant)
        

**Blend (scalarization)**
- Let t‚àà[0,1]t\in[0,1]t‚àà[0,1].
- Score line for item iii:
    si(t)=(1‚àít)‚Äâdi+t‚Äâci=di+t(ci‚àídi)s_i(t)=(1-t)\,d_i+t\,c_i=d_i+t(c_i-d_i)si‚Äã(t)=(1‚àít)di‚Äã+tci‚Äã=di‚Äã+t(ci‚Äã‚àídi‚Äã)
- Sorting by si(t)s_i(t)si‚Äã(t) gives an order that‚Äôs **piecewise constant** in ttt. The order only changes when two lines cross.
    

**Where orders flip (breakpoints)**

- Items iii and jjj swap exactly when si(t)=sj(t)s_i(t)=s_j(t)si‚Äã(t)=sj‚Äã(t):
    di+t(ci‚àídi)=dj+t(cj‚àídj)‚áít\*=dj‚àídi(ci‚àídi)‚àí(cj‚àídj)d_i+t(c_i-d_i)=d_j+t(c_j-d_j) \Rightarrow t^\*=\frac{d_j-d_i}{(c_i-d_i)-(c_j-d_j)}di‚Äã+t(ci‚Äã‚àídi‚Äã)=dj‚Äã+t(cj‚Äã‚àídj‚Äã)‚áít\*=(ci‚Äã‚àídi‚Äã)‚àí(cj‚Äã‚àídj‚Äã)dj‚Äã‚àídi‚Äã‚Äã
- Keep only t\*‚àà(0,1)t^\*\in(0,1)t\*‚àà(0,1).
- Ignore parallel lines (denominator ‚âà 0).
- Deduplicate breakpoints; sort them.

**Discrete slider that always ‚Äúdoes something‚Äù**
- Build knots: [0]‚Äâ+‚Äâsorted¬†breakpoints‚Äâ+‚Äâ[1][0]\,+\,\text{sorted breakpoints}\,+\,[1][0]+sorted¬†breakpoints+[1].
    
- For each adjacent pair, take a representative ttt (midpoint).
    
- Use these ttt-values as the slider‚Äôs **only** positions.
    
- Result: every tick crosses at least one pairwise boundary ‚Üí the sorted order changes.
    

**Map to your 1000-sum weights**

- Display weights, don‚Äôt drive logic:
    
    wcult=round(1000‚Äât),wdist=1000‚àíwcultw_{\text{cult}}=\text{round}(1000\,t),\quad w_{\text{dist}}=1000-w_{\text{cult}}wcult‚Äã=round(1000t),wdist‚Äã=1000‚àíwcult‚Äã
- If you must score in raw units, use wdist‚ãÖDi+wcult‚ãÖCiw_{\text{dist}}\cdot D_i+w_{\text{cult}}\cdot C_iwdist‚Äã‚ãÖDi‚Äã+wcult‚Äã‚ãÖCi‚Äã; ranking will match normalized ordering if both normalizations are monotone.
    

**Edge cases & correctness**
- **No interior breakpoints** ‚Üí only two distinct orders: pure distance (t=0) and pure culture (t=1).
- **Numerical stability**: use an Œµ\varepsilonŒµ around 0 and 1; treat near-parallel as ‚Äúno cross.‚Äù
- **Ties**: keep deterministic tie-breakers (e.g., by distance then culture).
- **Complexity**: breakpoint calc is O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2); sorting steps O(nlog‚Å°n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn). For nnn in the tens/hundreds, this is fine. Cache per dataset/normalization.
    

**Why it feels great in UI**
- The order is constant between breakpoints; you only sample from those intervals.
- Every tick is a **new permutation**‚Äîno placebo.
- Ends are exact identities: t=0t=0t=0 = pure distance, t=1t=1t=1 = pure culture.
    

**Optional vector view (same idea)**
- Let xi=[di,ci]Tx_i=[d_i,c_i]^Txi‚Äã=[di‚Äã,ci‚Äã]T, w(t)=[1‚àít,¬†t]Tw(t)=[1-t,\ t]^Tw(t)=[1‚àít,¬†t]T.
- si(t)=w(t)Txis_i(t)=w(t)^T x_isi‚Äã(t)=w(t)Txi‚Äã.
- Breakpoints are where two projections are equal.
- In 2D these are the line crossings above; in higher-D it generalizes to hyperplanes (we‚Äôre staying 2D here).

```yaml
spec_id: critical_blend_slider_v1
purpose: >
  Produce a slider that ALWAYS changes the sorted order of items by blending two metrics (distance, culture).
  Slider steps correspond to intervals between pairwise order-change breakpoints. Ends match pure sorts.

inputs:
  dataset: pandas.DataFrame
  required_columns:
    - trip_id
    - name
    - country
    - distance            # numeric
    - cultural_rank       # numeric; lower rank = higher priority; treat as "cost"
    - completed           # boolean-like
    - kayak_required      # boolean-like
    - kayak_prev_id       # string or ""
    - paraglide_required  # boolean-like
    - paraglide_prev_id   # string or ""
    - ski_required        # boolean-like
    - ski_prev_id         # string or ""
  booleans_truthy: ["TRUE","T","1","YES","Y"]

feasibility:
  model: >
    Each discipline forms a chain via *_prev_id. A trip is feasible iff for every required discipline:
    either prev_id == "" (base) OR the predecessor trip is completed AND its own chain is satisfied (recursive).
  function_signature: feasible(df) -> df_with_columns[feasible:bool, why_blocked:str]

normalization:
  goal: Make metrics comparable, lower-is-better in [0,1].
  methods:
    min_max: d_norm=(distance-min(distance))/(max(distance)-min(distance)); same for c_norm from cultural_rank
    rank: rank ascending to 1..n, then scale to [0,1] via (rank-1)/(n-1)
  selected_by: param norm_method in {"min-max","rank"}
  note: Do NOT invert cultural_rank; it is already a "cost" (smaller rank = better).

blend_model:
  parameter_t: t in [0,1]                      # continuous blend knob
  score_per_item: s_i(t)=(1-t)*d_i + t*c_i     # d_i,c_i are normalized costs
  display_weights:                              # for UI only; sum fixed at 1000
    w_cult=round(1000*t)
    w_dist=1000-w_cult

breakpoints:
  definition: >
    Order changes only when two score lines cross.
    For items i,j with (d_i,c_i) and (d_j,c_j):
    t*=(d_j-d_i)/((c_i-d_i)-(c_j-d_j)). Keep only 0<t*<1 and |denominator|>eps.
  algorithm:
    - compute all pairwise t* (i<j); O(n^2)
    - keep 0<t*<1; deduplicate with rounding; sort ascending
    - knots=[0]+breakpoints+[1]
    - steps=[0] + midpoints between successive knots + [1] (use exact 0 and 1 at ends)
  guarantee: Each step yields a distinct permutation of the ready set (piecewise-constant ordering).

sorting:
  reference_orders:
    by_distance: sort by [distance asc, cultural_rank asc, trip_id asc]
    by_culture:  sort by [cultural_rank asc, distance asc, trip_id asc]
  global_sort(t):
    if t<=eps: return by_distance
    if t>=1-eps: return by_culture
    else:
      compute s_i(t) on normalized metrics
      sort by [s_i asc, distance asc, cultural_rank asc, trip_id asc]
  eps: 1e-12

ui_contract:
  slider:
    type: discrete select_slider over integer step indices 0..(len(steps)-1)
    label: "Global Blend Step"
    mapping: step_index -> t = steps[step_index]
    live_weights: w_dist=round(1000*(1-t)); w_cult=1000-w_dist
  views:
    - Ready Now (by distance): reference_orders.by_distance over feasible set
    - Ready Now (by cultural rank): reference_orders.by_culture over feasible set
    - Global Sort: global_sort(t) over feasible set
    - Future Unlocks: infeasible set with why_blocked

functions:
  - name: coerce_booleans
    in: df
    out: df
    desc: Coerce boolean-like strings to True/False using booleans_truthy.
  - name: compute_feasible
    in: df
    out: df with [feasible, why_blocked]
    desc: Recursive chain check per discipline; collects reasons.
  - name: normalize_series
    in: (series, method)
    out: series_scaled_in_[0,1]
    desc: Min‚Äìmax or rank normalization; lower is better.
  - name: compute_breakpoints
    in: (d_norm_array, c_norm_array, eps)
    out: sorted_unique_breakpoints_in_(0,1)
  - name: build_steps
    in: breakpoints
    out: steps_t_list_with_0_and_1_as_endpoints
  - name: global_sort
    in: (df_ready, t, eps)
    out: df_ready_sorted
  - name: weights_from_t
    in: t
    out: (w_dist=round(1000*(1-t)), w_cult=1000-w_dist)

pseudocode:
  - |
    df = load_csv(...)
    df = coerce_booleans(df)
    df = compute_feasible(df)
    ready = df[df.feasible].copy()
    ready["d_norm"] = normalize_series(ready.distance, norm_method)
    ready["c_norm"] = normalize_series(ready.cultural_rank, norm_method)
    bps = compute_breakpoints(ready.d_norm.values, ready.c_norm.values, eps=1e-12)
    steps = build_steps(bps)  # list of t, includes 0 and 1 at ends
    # UI: user selects step_index
    t = steps[step_index]
    (w_dist, w_cult) = weights_from_t(t)
    global_sorted = global_sort(ready, t, eps)

validation_tests:
  - name: extremes_identity
    assert: global_sort(ready,0).equals(sort_by_distance(ready)) AND global_sort(ready,1).equals(sort_by_culture(ready))
  - name: monotone

```

# Data Associated with a Pain Point

## Frontend Requirements -> navigation
When I select a "pain point" I want to see:
- What are the milestones and tasks to complete the resolution of this pain point?
	- How well is this defined? Do we think that the steps that we have defined are enough to complete this?
- What tasks and milestones have already been achieved?
	- What is the completion percentage?
- How many work sessions have we had?
- Where is the output of those work sessions?

Your current plan‚Äîsplitting responsibilities across `{frontend app, solver, database}`‚Äîis solid **as a base pattern**. But now that you're hitting **multi-step workflows** with **shared patterns across domains**, it's time to evolve the architecture just a bit. Here's the real talk:

---

## üß† What You're Actually Building

You're building a system where:

- Each **domain** (e.g., exercise, cooking, finance) has:
    
    - A **data model**
        
    - A **planner/solver**
        
    - A **UI**
        
    - Some **derived analytics**
        
- The system should support **modular logic**, but also let you **chain domain-specific steps** into domain-agnostic workflows.
    

---

## ‚úÖ Yes, Keep the Three Top-Level Classes

For each **domain**, you should still use:

- `Database`: handles reads/writes, persistence
    
- `Solver`: logic engine (e.g., plan workouts, suggest meals, etc.)
    
- `Frontend`: interacts with Streamlit
    

BUT‚Äîthose three aren‚Äôt enough on their own for what you're doing next.

---

## üß© Introducing: The **Workflow Layer**

You now need a **WorkflowOrchestrator** (call it whatever you want: `TaskRunner`, `PipelineEngine`, `DomainManager`, `Hamrsmi√∞r`, etc).

This orchestrator:

- Lives _above_ the solver/database/frontend trio
    
- Has knowledge of the required sequence for a specific domain event (e.g., ‚Äúsave workout‚Äù)
    
- Is still **domain-scoped**, but the _structure_ is reusable across domains
    

---

## üß± Structural Suggestion

`/app   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.py            # Streamlit app entry point   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ domains/   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ exercise/   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ database.py   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ planner.py   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ workflow.py      <-- DOMAIN WORKFLOW LOGIC HERE   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ analytics.py   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ __init__.py   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ cooking/   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ database.py   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ planner.py   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ workflow.py   ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ analytics.py   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ core/   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ base_database.py   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ base_solver.py   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ base_workflow.py     <-- BASE WORKFLOW LOGIC HERE`

---

## üß† What `workflow.py` Might Look Like

`from .database import ExerciseDB from .planner import ExercisePlanner from .analytics import calculate_derived_params  class ExerciseWorkflow:     def __init__(self):         self.db = ExerciseDB()         self.planner = ExercisePlanner()      def save_workout(self, user_id):         last_workout = self.db.fetch_latest_workout(user_id)         self.db.log_completed_workout(user_id, last_workout)          next_workout = self.planner.plan_next_workout(last_workout)         self.db.update_next_workout(user_id, next_workout)          derived = calculate_derived_params(user_id)         self.db.update_analytics(user_id, derived)`

The Streamlit button handler simply becomes:

`if st.button("Save Workout"):     workflow = ExerciseWorkflow()     workflow.save_workout(user_id)`

body: some data

## How do I filter Tasks by tag and/or file property?

### üîç The Tasks plugin supports **complex queries** using:

- Tags
- File properties (like YAML frontmatter)
- Text search
- Status
- Priority
- Due dates
- Recurrence

### üß™ Example 1: Filter by Tag

tasks
CopyEdit

`tag: #urgent`

### üß™ Example 2: Filter by File Path or Folder

tasks

CopyEdit

`path includes "Tasks/Projects"`

### üß™ Example 3: Filter by Frontmatter Property

Let‚Äôs say you have this in your note:

yaml

CopyEdit

`project: "Hlidskjalf"`

You can query like this:

tasks

CopyEdit

`project includes Hlidskjalf`

### üß™ Example 4: Combine Filters

tasks

CopyEdit

`tag: #cooking project includes Hlidskjalf status is not done`

### üß† Heads-up:

- You **must have consistent YAML** fields in the files for frontmatter filtering to work.
    
- You **cannot filter based on inline text** in the task itself (e.g., `- [ ] Do this #tag` won‚Äôt be detected as a tag unless it's parsed as a tag in Obsidian's core).
    

---

## üß∞ Pro Tips

| Tip                    | Benefit                                                 |
| ---------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------- |
| Use `heading includes` | Narrow tasks to specific sections like `## Weekly Plan` |
| Use `due before today` | Create automatic overdue views                          |
| Use `group by`         | Organize by status, path, tag, etc.                     |
| Use `limit`            | Avoid overwhelming your dashboard                       |

file_name: Bright Protein Muffins with Goat Cheese and Lemon.md
file_path: /home/conrad/git/yggdrasill/dev/examples/Obsidian/projects (plugin)/Recipes/Bright Protein Muffins with Goat Cheese and Lemon.md
body:
**Bright Protein Muffins with Goat Cheese & Lemon**

**Ingredients (makes 6‚Äì8 muffins):**
- 2 whole eggs (separated)
- 2 additional egg whites
- 1/2 cup cottage cheese
- 2 tbsp goat cheese
- Zest of 1 lemon
- 1/4 tsp baking powder
- 1 tsp cornstarch
- Pinch of salt

**Tools:**
- Mixing bowls (x2)
- Hand or stand mixer (for whites)
- Zester / microplane
- Muffin tin (non-silicone)
- Baking spray or paper liners

**Steps:**
1. **Preheat oven** to 350¬∞F (175¬∞C). Grease muffin tin or use liners.
2. **Separate the 2 whole eggs**, placing whites in one bowl, yolks in another.
3. **Whip all 4 egg whites** (2 separated + 2 additional) to soft peaks with a pinch of salt.
4. In a separate bowl, **blend together**:
    - Egg yolks
    - Cottage cheese
    - Goat cheese
    - Lemon zest
    - Baking powder
    - Cornstarch
5. **Gently fold whipped whites** into the cheese/yolk mixture using a spatula. Do not overmix ‚Äî keep it airy.
6. **Spoon mixture** into prepared muffin tin.
7. **Bake for 15‚Äì18 minutes**, or until puffed and lightly golden.
8. Let rest 1‚Äì2 min before serving.

## Metadata
- **Servings**: 8
- **Serving Size**: 2 Tbl
- **Prep Time**: 5 minutes
- **Cook Time**: 30 minutes
- **Category**: Side
- **Cuisine**: 

## Ingredients
- **Main Ingredients**:
  - 1 cup sugar
  - 1 cup water
  - 2 tbl Lavender
  - 1/4 tsp freshly squeezed lemon juice
  - a pinch of salt.
## Tools
- Saucepan
- Strainer
- Mixing spoon
- Funnel
## Instructions
1. Mix all ingredients in a saucepan
2. Heat. Boil on MED heat for 7 minutes. Stir regularly.
3. Strain lavender.
4. Boil on HIGH to thicken, until volume has reduced by ~50%, or ~4 min. 
5. Let cool.
6. Add lemon juice and salt.
7. Stir.
8. Funnel into storage container
## Cooking Notes
- N/A
## Shelf Life
- **Room temp**: 7 days
- **Refrigerated**: 1-2 months. Richer syrup lasts longer.
- **Frozen**: N/A
## Cooking Log
- **[2025-05-23]**:
  - **Changes**: Added lemon juice and salt
  - **Outcome**: Flavor was more balanced.
  - **Observations**: Quickly wash the saucepan because the syrup is like glue when it dries.

# Fundamentals
**All notes in the same folder as this note**
```dataview
LIST WHERE contains(file.folder, this.file.folder)
```
**Product Component List**
```dataview
list
where contains(file.path, "my fourth project - note linking")
	and parent = [[product 1]] 
	and type = "component"
```
**User story feature queue**
```dataview
list
where contains(file.path, "my fourth project - note linking")
	and user_story = [[user story 1]] 
	and type = "feature"
sort sequence asc
```
**Component feature queue**
Component 1
```dataview
list
where contains(file.path, "my fourth project - note linking")
	and parent = [[component 1]] 
	and type = "feature"
sort sequence asc
```
Component 2
```dataview
list
where contains(file.path, "my fourth project - note linking")
	and parent = [[component 2]] 
	and type = "feature"
sort sequence asc
```
**Feature task queue**
Feature 1
```dataview
list
where contains(file.path, "my fourth project - note linking")
	and parent = [[feature 1]] 
	and type = "task"
sort sequence asc
```
**Skill queue**
Skill = Python
```dataview
list
where contains(file.path, "my fourth project - note linking")
	and skill = "python"
sort skill_sequence asc
```
# Combinations
**Feature skill queue**
Feature 1, python tasks
```dataview
list
where contains(file.path, "my fourth project - note linking")
	and parent = [[feature 1]] 
	and skill = "python"
sort skill_sequence asc
```

**Fields**
Sequence - where is this note in the queue of notes *of the same type*.
- e.g. if this note is *type = task* then the *sequence* field refers to the task queue.

**Types**
Product -> something a *user* interacts with

Component -> something a *developer* interacts with
- should be opaque to the user, i.e. this is a dev architecture object.
- User Stories should tie to a product, not a component.
- If it looks like a user story needs to tie to a component, should consider promoting that component to a product.
- e.g. python class, or package, or file

User Story -> a child of a *product*. Functionality a user wants/needs

Feature -> a child of a *component*. A change that needs to be made to a component

Skill -> a property of a developer.

**Intent** - make a repo to act as a unit test for the creation of
- Tree diagrams (i.e. csv for use with streamlit tool) - architectural hierarchy
- Queue Tables - order in which the work will get done
- Dependency Charts -i.e. Gantt charts.
	- Inverted tress

---- 
**Fields**
Sequence - where is this note in the queue of notes *of the same type*.
- e.g. if this note is *type = task* then the *sequence* field refers to the task queue.

**Types**
Product -> something a *user* interacts with

Component -> something a *developer* interacts with
- should be opaque to the user, i.e. this is a dev architecture object.
- User Stories should tie to a product, not a component.
- If it looks like a user story needs to tie to a component, should consider promoting that component to a product.
- e.g. python class, or package, or file

User Story -> a child of a *product*. Functionality a user wants/needs

Feature -> a child of a *component*. A change that needs to be made to a component

Skill -> a property of a developer.

"Template" is just a block of pre-defined variable that get populated on creation in a "paste as value" type of a style.

To insert a template:
- While inside of the note you want to insert a template into:
- In the far left vertical ribbon, select: "insert template"
- That's it!

Note: Prerequisites for this working are:
- The Template folder is defined: Settings -> Core plugins -> Templates -> Template folder location.
- A template exists, in the template folder.

# Example of text inserted using a template:

note containing template

# 2nd version (with visual indicator)
```mermaid
gantt
    title Deployment Plan with Conditional Fallback
    dateFormat  YYYY-MM-DD
    axisFormat  %b %d

    section Decision Point
    Make Deployment Decision            :done,      decision, 2025-08-01, 1d

    section Primary Path
    Deploy Feature A                    :active,    deployA, after decision, 2d

    section Fallback Plan (IF NEEDED)
    %% This is a conditional path!
    Deploy Feature B (Fallback)         :           fallback, after decision, 2d
```
# 3rd version
```mermaid
gantt
    title Deployment Plan with Conditional Fallback
    dateFormat  YYYY-MM-DD
    axisFormat  %b %d

    section Decision Point
    Make Deployment Decision            :done,      decision, 2025-08-01, 1d
    Condition Met?                      :milestone, condition, after decision, 0d

    section Primary Plan
    Deploy Feature A                    :active,    deployA, after condition, 2d
    Verify A Success                    :           verifyA, after deployA, 1d

    section Fallback Plan
    Deploy Feature B (Fallback)         :           deployB, after condition, 2d
    Verify B Success                    :           verifyB, after deployB, 1d
```

Absolutely. `group by` in **Dataview** is super useful when you want to organize your results into logical clusters‚Äîlike by `project`, `domain`, `priority`, `checklist`, `week`, etc.

Let‚Äôs dive into an example with **grouping actual tasks** by a frontmatter field.

---

## ‚úÖ Example: Group Tasks by `project`

### üß± File: `piano_practice.md`

yaml

CopyEdit

`project: Hlidskjalf domain: piano`

markdown

CopyEdit

`- [ ] Do arpeggios - [ ] Practice Poema left hand`

### üß± File: `cooking_june.md`

yaml

CopyEdit

`project: Eldsskr√° domain: cooking`

markdown

CopyEdit

`- [ ] Test lemon goat souffle - [ ] Update spice inventory`

---

## üìä Dashboard Query to Group by `project`

dataview

CopyEdit

`task from "Tasks" where !completed group by project`

### üîç Output

text

CopyEdit

`## Hlidskjalf  - [ ] Do arpeggios - [ ] Practice Poema left hand  ## Eldsskr√°  - [ ] Test lemon goat souffle - [ ] Update spice inventory`

---

## üîÑ More Variations

### üîπ Group by `domain`

dataview

CopyEdit

`task from "Tasks" where !completed group by domain`

### üîπ Group by `checklist`

dataview

CopyEdit

`task from "ChecklistRuns" where checklist group by checklist`

### üîπ Group by computed value (e.g., file.ctime.week)

dataview

CopyEdit

`task from "ChecklistRuns" where checklist = "warmup" group by dateformat(file.ctime, "yyyy-'W'ww")`

> That gives you **week-based grouping**, like:
> 
> markdown
> 
> CopyEdit
> 
> `## 2025-W26 - [ ] Do warmup checklist`

---

## üí° Pro Tip

If a note is missing the `group by` field, Dataview will still include it‚Äîunder a `null` header. You can filter those out like:

dataview

CopyEdit

`where checklist != null group by checklist`

---

## üßº TL;DR

|Goal|Example|
|---|---|
|Group tasks by project|`group by project`|
|Group checklist runs by week|`group by dateformat(file.ctime, "yyyy-'W'ww")`|
|Group by tags (requires parsing or storing as frontmatter)|Not directly unless stored as frontmatter list|

---

# Querying Basics
### Query Type and Output Formate
Four available:
1. **TABLE**: A table of results with one row per result and one or many columns of field data.
2. **LIST**: A bullet point list of pages which match the query. You can output one field for each page alongside their file links.
3. **TASK**: An interactive task list of tasks that match the given query.
4. **CALENDAR**: A calendar view displaying each hit via a dot on its referred date.
### Data commands
Supports a lot of Data Commands:
- FROM
- WHERE - matching using meta data fields, i.e. frontmatter
- SORT
- GROUP BY
- LIMIT
- FLATTEN

See: https://blacksmithgu.github.io/obsidian-dataview/queries/structure/

where contains(tags, "journal")

LIST

```

We need a function that takes in a filename and returns a normalized version using only ASCII characters, safe for use in a filesystem.

The function should:
- Remove accents and diacritics
- Replace spaces with underscores
- Lowercase everything
task: Write a function to normalize unicode filenames

body:
## Commentary
- WHAT the code does: The `normalize_filename` function takes a unicode filename as input and returns a normalized string using only safe ASCII characters. The normalization process involves three steps. First, it removes any accents and diacritics from the filename using unicode normalization. Then, it replaces any spaces in the filename with underscores. Finally, it converts the entire filename to lowercase.

- WHY you made your design choices: Unicode normalization was used to replace non-ASCII characters like accents and diacritics because it offers a standardized way to convert such characters to their base ASCII equivalents, which maximizes compatibility across different systems. Using underscores in place of spaces was chosen because it is a widely recognised practice in file naming, and it preserves readability while eliminating issues that could arise from spaces (like command line parsing problems). Converting the filename to lowercase was done for consistency and to avoid potential case sensitivity issues.

- ANY ASSUMPTIONS you made: It is assumed that the function will be used in a context where the filename provided is a string. However, edge cases where an empty string is input or where a non-string type is input are guarded against in the test cases. For the latter, a `TypeError` is expected to be raised.

{

    "summary": "Takes a functionality description plus existing patterns/examples and produces: (1) an implementation plan with component impact, (2) a human+machine-readable data contract/ICD (single Markdown file with embedded YAML section), and (3) function definitions/header stubs. Enforces interface consistency across components.",
    "inputs": {
      "task_brief_markdown": "Generic description of the desired functionality (human-written).",
      "existing_artifacts": {
        "components_map_yaml": "Declarative map of components ‚Üí paths (src/tests/docs) and interfaces.",
        "style_guides_json": "Code/test/doc style instructions.",
        "examples_refs": "Optional: paths or snippets to similar implementations or patterns.",
        "constraints_yaml": "Optional: performance, security, compliance, or platform constraints."
      },
      "context": {
        "repo_layout": "High-level layout (src/, tests/, docs/, product/, runestone/).",
        "ids": {
          "runestone_id": "e.g., rs_123",
          "feature_ids": ["feat.xyz"],
          "component_ids": ["cmp.a", "cmp.b"]
        }
      }
    },
    "outputs": {
      "implementation_plan_markdown": "A concise, stepwise plan listing impacted components, changes, risks, and test points.",
      "icd_markdown_single_file": "A single Markdown document that contains both human-readable description and a machine-readable YAML section (see formatting contract).",
      "function_stubs": [
        {
          "path": "src/<component>/module.py",
          "language": "python",
          "content": "def function_name(params) -> ReturnType:\\n    \"\"\"Docstring per style guide (Google-style).\"\"\"\\n    pass"
        }
      ],
      "routing_hints": [
        {
          "artifact": "icd_markdown_single_file",
          "suggested_path": "docs/components/<component>/<feature>_icd.md"
        },
        {
          "artifact": "function_stubs",
          "suggested_path": "src/<component>/"
        },
        {
          "artifact": "test_stubs_hint",
          "suggested_path": "tests/<component>/test_<module>.py"
        }
      ]
    },
    "guarantees": [
      "All interface changes are explicitly listed and versioned.",
      "No breaking changes to adjacent components without an explicit deprecation note and migration step.",
      "ICD is self-consistent with the implementation plan and stubs."
    ],
    "consistency_policy": {
      "interface_registry_source": "components_map_yaml",
      "checks": [
        "If introducing/altering a public function or class, verify name, parameters, types, and return values against the registry.",
        "Callers/callees listed in the plan must match paths in components_map_yaml.",
        "If mismatch is detected, propose either: (a) adapter layer, or (b) explicit interface change + deprecation timeline."
      ]
    },
    "formatting_contract": {
      "implementation_plan_markdown_structure": [
        "## Summary",
        "## Impacted Components",
        "## Change List (per component)",
        "## Interfaces Touched (before ‚Üí after)",
        "## Risks & Mitigations",
        "## Test Points & Observability",
        "## Acceptance Criteria"
      ],
      "icd_markdown_single_file_structure": [
        "# <Feature/Component> Interface Control Document (ICD)",
        "## Purpose",
        "## Context & Invariants",
        "## Machine-Readable Schema (YAML)",
        "```yaml",
        "# id: icd.<component>.<feature>",
        "endpoints_or_functions:",
        "  - name: <function_or_endpoint>",
        "    description: <what it does>",
        "    inputs:",
        "      - name: <param>",
        "        type: <type>",
        "        required: true|false",
        "        constraints: [ ... ]",
        "    outputs:",
        "      type: <type>",
        "      schema_ref: <optional>",
        "    errors:",
        "      - code: <string>",
        "        when: <condition>",
        "    version: \"v1\"",
        "contracts:",
        "  stability: stable|experimental|internal",
        "  deprecations: []",
        "````",
        "## Examples (Requests/Responses or Call Patterns)",
        "## Change Log"
      ],
      "function_stubs_rules": [
        "Snake_case names, descriptive and intention-revealing.",
        "Google-style docstrings with Args/Returns/Raises.",
        "Type hints required.",
        "No business logic; stubs only."
      ]
    },
    "agent_prompt": {
      "system": "You are a senior software architect. Your job is to translate a functionality brief plus known patterns into: (1) an implementation plan with component impact, (2) a single-file ICD (Markdown with embedded YAML), and (3) function/header stubs. You must preserve interface consistency across components and clearly call out any proposed interface change, with migration notes. Follow the provided formatting strictly.",
      "content_policy": [
        "Do not invent unknown components; reference only those in components_map_yaml unless the plan explicitly proposes a new one.",
        "Prefer adapters over breaking changes. If breaking change is necessary, include deprecation and migration steps.",
        "Call out test points and observability hooks in the plan (log/metrics/traces)."
      ],
      "style": {
        "tone": "concise, technical, actionable",
        "bullets": "use numbered lists for steps; tables where helpful",
        "code_blocks": "only for stubs or examples"
      }
    },
    "validation": {
      "preflight": [
        "Confirm that all referenced component_ids exist in components_map_yaml.",
        "Confirm all stub paths resolve under src/ according to the map.",
        "If any path is ambiguous, emit a routing_hint with <component>/TBD and a TODO."
      ],
      "postchecks": [

      ]

    },
    "handoff_contract_for_followup_agents": {
      "implementer": {

      }

    "routing_hints_defaults": {

      "stub_path_template": "src/{component}/",
      "test_path_template": "tests/{component}/test_{module}.py"
    },
    "metadata": {

    }

Rules: 
Preferred production rules:
{
    "preferred_production_layout": {
      "frontend": {
        "description": "Streamlit-based user interface.",
        "folder_rule": "All frontend files live under /frontend/.",
        "examples": [
          "frontend/app.py",
          "frontend/components/sidebar.py",
          "frontend/components/forms.py"
        ]
      },
      "database": {
        "description": "Database and database interface layer (currently Excel/CSV, extensible to SQL).",
        "folder_rule": "All database interface files live under /database/.",
        "examples": [
          "database/db_client.py",
          "database/load_csv.py",
          "database/load_excel.py"
        ]
      },
      "logic": {
        "description": "Core solver or planner modules performing computation and business logic.",
        "folder_rule": "All core logic files live under /logic/.",
        "examples": [
          "logic/planner.py",
          "logic/solver.py",
          "logic/validators.py"
        ]
      },
      "workflow": {
        "description": "Domain-scoped scripts or routines triggered by user actions.",
        "folder_rule": "All workflow routines live under /workflow/.",
        "examples": [
          "workflow/save_workout.py",
          "workflow/generate_report.py",
          "workflow/sync_data.py"
        ]
      }
    },
    "cross_cutting_rules": {
      "dependency_flow": [
        "frontend may only call workflow entrypoints, not database or logic directly",
        "workflow orchestrates calls into logic and database layers",
        "logic may call database but must not reference frontend",
        "database must not import or depend on logic, workflow, or frontend"
      ],
      "consistency": [
        "All inter-component communication must go through explicit interfaces (function signatures, data contracts)",
        "Shared data structures must be defined in a single canonical place (YAML or schema file) and imported, not duplicated"
      ],
      "enforcement": [
        "No cross-folder imports violating the dependency flow",
        "Each new feature must clearly identify which layer(s) it touches and maintain separation"
      ]
    }
  }
  

Testing Rules:
{
    "testing_rules": {
      "unit_tests": {
        "description": "Unit tests should be collocated with their source files to validate small, isolated functions.",
        "examples": [
          "logic/test_planner.py",
          "database/test_db_client.py"
        ]
      },
      "integration_tests": {
        "description": "Integration tests live in a top-level /tests/ folder. They validate end-to-end flows across multiple layers (frontend‚Üíworkflow‚Üílogic‚Üídatabase).",
        "folder_rule": "All integration tests must be placed in /tests/.",
        "examples": [
          "tests/test_save_workout_flow.py",
          "tests/test_report_generation.py"
        ]
      },
      "fixtures": {
        "description": "Shared test data lives in a dedicated fixtures folder.",
        "folder_rule": "All reusable fixtures must be placed in /tests/fixtures/."
      },
      "naming_conventions": {
        "files": "All test files must be named test_*.py or *_test.py so that pytest can discover them automatically.",
        "functions": "All test functions must begin with test_.",
        "classes": "All test classes must begin with Test and must not have an __init__ method."
      },
      "rules": [
        "Unit tests may import their sibling source file but must not cross into other folders directly",
        "Integration tests must call only public interfaces or workflow entrypoints",
        "Test fixtures must not contain business logic; only data preparation"
      ]
    }
  }

Existing components:
Checklist maker: # Overview
A small Streamlit app that renders a **step checklist** from a CSV, lets a user mark steps complete via checkboxes, and saves the completed subset back to disk (optionally with timestamps). The UI is a single ‚ÄúStep Checklist‚Äù view.

# Components & Roles
- **`render_step_tab(csv_path, completed_csv_path)`**: Core UI renderer.    
    - Reads `csv_path` into a DataFrame.        
    - Builds a checkbox per row (label from the `"step"` column if present, else stringified row).
    - Tracks completed indices in `st.session_state.completed_steps`.
    - Writes selected rows to `completed_csv_path` on ‚ÄúSave Completed Steps‚Äù.
- **Timestamp variant**: An alternate implementation additionally maintains `st.session_state.step_timestamps` and writes ISO timestamps per completed row.
- **App entry**: Calls `render_step_tab(Path("my_steps.csv"), Path("completed_steps.csv"))` at module end, making it a single-page Streamlit app.

# Tech/Runtime
- **Framework**: Streamlit (UI, session state, buttons).
- **Data**: CSV via pandas.
- **Paths**: `pathlib.Path` for file I/O.
- **Time**: `datetime.now().isoformat()` only in the timestamp variant.

# User Flow
1. App loads steps from CSV.
2. User checks/unchecks steps (checkbox per row).
3. App displays summary: ‚Äú‚úÖ X of N steps completed.‚Äù
4. On ‚ÄúSave Completed Steps,‚Äù writes filtered rows (and timestamps if variant) to output CSV; shows success banner.

# Data Contracts (Current)

## Input CSV: `my_steps.csv`
- **Required**: none strictly enforced in code.
- **Used columns**:
    - `step` _(optional)_: string used as checkbox label; if missing, the entire row is stringified as label.
- **Semantics**: each row represents one checklist item.

## Output CSV: `completed_steps.csv
- **Base variant**: all columns from input, filtered to completed rows.
- **Timestamp variant**: same as above + **`timestamp`** column; value = ISO datetime per completed row.

# State Management
- `st.session_state.completed_steps`: a **set of row indices** marking completion.
    - Base variant: added/removed directly on checkbox change.
    - Timestamp variant: also updates `st.session_state.step_timestamps` dict keyed by row index.

# Assumptions & Constraints (Implicit)
- Row identity = **DataFrame index** at render time; completion tracking is index-based (sensitive to reordering).
- Input CSV is loadable and reasonably small (no pagination/virtualized lists).
- No concurrency control on file writes; assumes single-user, single-process.

# Risks / Edge Cases
- **Index drift**: If the input CSV changes between load and save, index-based selection may mismatch intended rows.
- **Missing `step` column**: UI falls back to stringifying a whole row, which can be noisy.
- **Timestamp consistency**: Timestamps only exist in the variant; mixing variants produces heterogeneous outputs.

# Integration Touch Points (for Architect/Planner)
- **Frontend**: Streamlit component tree (checkboxes, counters, buttons).
- **Planner/Logic**: Step selection logic; potential validation, ordering, dependencies.
- **Data Layer**: CSV I/O abstraction ‚Üí future DB client interface.

# Single-File ICD (Human + Machine Readable)
The architect agent should maintain this ICD (example content below) and keep it consistent with any stubs/plans it emits.

**ICD.md (excerpt)**

**Purpose (human)**  
Render an interactive checklist from a CSV and persist the user‚Äôs completed subset (optionally with per-row timestamps).

`id: icd.checklist.v1 inputs:   csv_path:     type: filepath     required: true     semantics: CSV containing step rows; may include 'step' column for labels   completed_csv_path:     type: filepath     required: true     semantics: destination CSV for completed rows state:   completed_steps:     type: set[int]     scope: streamlit_session   step_timestamps:     type: dict[int, iso_datetime]     scope: streamlit_session     optional: true ui:   elements:     - type: checkbox       per: row       label_source: column:'step' | stringified_row     - type: text       content: "‚úÖ {completed_count} of {total} steps completed"     - type: button       action: save_completed outputs:   base:     type: csv     schema: "same columns as input, filtered to completed rows"   with_timestamp:     type: csv     schema:       columns:         - all_input_columns         - timestamp: iso_datetime contracts:   identity: "row index used as completion identity; stable only within session"   performance: "small to medium CSVs; no virtualization"   persistence: "single-writer, no locking" version: "1.0"`

# Suggested Implementation Plan (Thin-Slice Ready)

1. **Stabilize data contract**
    - Define required columns (e.g., `id`, `step`, `group`) to avoid index drift.
    - Add schema validation and friendly error messages.
        
2. **Abstract I/O**
    - Wrap CSV reads/writes in a data layer (`data_provider`), preparing for DB client swap.

3. **Planner hooks**
    - Introduce an interface for step dependency/ordering (e.g., preconditions; optional).
        
4. **Observability**
    - Replace `st.success` with structured event logs (in memory or file) to support analytics.
        
5. **Testing**
    - Pytest: unit tests for I/O, state transitions, and timestamp behavior; integration test via Streamlit testing utilities (or fast UI shims).
        

# Extension Points / Backlog
- **DB integration**: Replace `completed_csv_path` with a persistence service (SQLite/remote).
- **Multi-list support**: Parameterize `csv_path`; add sidebar ‚Äúlist chooser‚Äù.
- **Row IDs**: Move from index-based to explicit `id` column for durability.
- **Filters/Groups**: Optional grouping, search, and progress per group.
- **Auth**: User-scoped completions.  
    (All of the above can be planned without breaking the current UX flow.)

Great. I‚Äôll now generate the implementation plan, ICD, and function stubs to bridge your existing checklist_maker and exercise_planner into a full production system that:

Plans a workout from a known exercise set.

Generates a checklist from that workout.

Saves the completed workout.

Generates the next workout based on past performance.

Let‚Äôs call this feature plan_execute_iterate.

‚úÖ Implementation Plan
## Summary

This feature enables a closed-loop flow for workout planning, execution via checklist, and progression based on past performance. The system is scoped to 3‚Äì5 known exercises and built on CSV-based persistence. It builds upon existing checklist_maker and exercise_planner components.

## Impacted Components

logic/planner.py (existing): extend to support progression logic.

workflow/workout_cycle.py (new): orchestrates plan‚Üíchecklist‚Üísave‚Üínext.

database/workout_log.py (new): handles logging completed sets with timestamp, reps, and weights.

frontend/app.py: add a new tab to display active workout and drive flow.

checklist_maker: reused as-is, wrapped via workflow.

exercise_planner: reused and extended with next-step logic.

## Change List (per component)
logic/planner.py

Add generate_next_workout(prev_workout: WorkoutLog) -> WorkoutPlan

Add optional progression strategy (e.g., +2.5kg if reps met)

workflow/workout_cycle.py

start_workout_session() ‚Üí WorkoutPlan

complete_workout_log(CompletedChecklist) ‚Üí None

generate_next_plan(prev_log) ‚Üí WorkoutPlan

Load/Save helpers for CSV.

database/workout_log.py

save_workout_log(WorkoutLog) ‚Üí None

load_last_workout(exercise_name: str) ‚Üí Optional[WorkoutLog]

frontend/app.py

New tab: ‚ÄúWorkout‚Äù

Displays plan as checklist

On completion, triggers complete_workout_log() and re-renders next session

## Interfaces Touched (before ‚Üí after)
Component	Before	After
planner	plan_workout(exercise_list)	+ generate_next_workout(prev_log)
checklist_maker	render_step_tab(csv_in, out)	wrapped as render_workout_tab(plan)
workflow	N/A	+ start_workout_session, complete_log
database	raw CSV I/O	+ structured I/O for WorkoutLog
## Risks & Mitigations
Risk	Mitigation
Checklist step drift (index-based)	Use stable step_id column
Incorrect progression logic	Unit test edge cases thoroughly
Data loss on crash	Write intermediate state on save
User confusion between sessions	UI clearly distinguishes "Active Session"
## Test Points & Observability

save/load_workout_log()

üîç Observability Hooks:

‚úÖ Next workout is based on previous log

‚úÖ Frontend flow is usable and survives reload

# plan_execute_iterate Interface Control Document (ICD)

## Purpose
Orchestrate a workout cycle: plan workout, render checklist, save results, and generate next plan.

## Context & Invariants
- Exercises are selected from a fixed set (e.g., squat, bench, row).
- Each exercise has a progression strategy.
- Workout logs are CSV-based for now, future-proofed for DB.

## Machine-Readable Schema (YAML)
```yaml
# id: icd.workflow.plan_execute_iterate
endpoints_or_functions:
  - name: start_workout_session
    description: Plan workout from latest logs
    inputs: []
    outputs:
      type: WorkoutPlan
    version: "v1"

  - name: complete_workout_log
    description: Save completed reps/weights with timestamps
    inputs:
      - name: checklist_result
        type: CompletedChecklist
        required: true
        constraints: ["all steps must have step_id, reps, weight, timestamp"]
    outputs:
      type: null
    version: "v1"

  - name: generate_next_workout
    description: Given previous log, return next planned workout
    inputs:
      - name: prev_log
        type: WorkoutLog
        required: true
    outputs:
      type: WorkoutPlan
    version: "v1"

contracts:
  stability: stable
  deprecations: []

Examples

start_workout_session() ‚Üí plan of 3 exercises, each with target reps/sets

User completes checklist with actual reps/weight per set

complete_workout_log(...) stores CSV row per exercise

generate_next_workout(prev_log) returns updated weights/targets

Change Log

v1.0: Initial version for checklist‚Üílog‚Üínext plan cycle

Existing components:
Checklist maker: # Overview
A small Streamlit app that renders a **step checklist** from a CSV, lets a user mark steps complete via checkboxes, and saves the completed subset back to disk (optionally with timestamps). The UI is a single ‚ÄúStep Checklist‚Äù view.

# Components & Roles
- **`render_step_tab(csv_path, completed_csv_path)`**: Core UI renderer.    
    - Reads `csv_path` into a DataFrame.        
    - Builds a checkbox per row (label from the `"step"` column if present, else stringified row).
    - Tracks completed indices in `st.session_state.completed_steps`.
    - Writes selected rows to `completed_csv_path` on ‚ÄúSave Completed Steps‚Äù.
- **Timestamp variant**: An alternate implementation additionally maintains `st.session_state.step_timestamps` and writes ISO timestamps per completed row.
- **App entry**: Calls `render_step_tab(Path("my_steps.csv"), Path("completed_steps.csv"))` at module end, making it a single-page Streamlit app.

# Tech/Runtime
- **Framework**: Streamlit (UI, session state, buttons).
- **Data**: CSV via pandas.
- **Paths**: `pathlib.Path` for file I/O.
- **Time**: `datetime.now().isoformat()` only in the timestamp variant.

# User Flow
1. App loads steps from CSV.
2. User checks/unchecks steps (checkbox per row).
3. App displays summary: ‚Äú‚úÖ X of N steps completed.‚Äù
4. On ‚ÄúSave Completed Steps,‚Äù writes filtered rows (and timestamps if variant) to output CSV; shows success banner.

# Data Contracts (Current)

## Input CSV: `my_steps.csv`
- **Required**: none strictly enforced in code.
- **Used columns**:
    - `step` _(optional)_: string used as checkbox label; if missing, the entire row is stringified as label.
- **Semantics**: each row represents one checklist item.

## Output CSV: `completed_steps.csv
- **Base variant**: all columns from input, filtered to completed rows.
- **Timestamp variant**: same as above + **`timestamp`** column; value = ISO datetime per completed row.

# State Management
- `st.session_state.completed_steps`: a **set of row indices** marking completion.
    - Base variant: added/removed directly on checkbox change.
    - Timestamp variant: also updates `st.session_state.step_timestamps` dict keyed by row index.

# Assumptions & Constraints (Implicit)
- Row identity = **DataFrame index** at render time; completion tracking is index-based (sensitive to reordering).
- Input CSV is loadable and reasonably small (no pagination/virtualized lists).
- No concurrency control on file writes; assumes single-user, single-process.

# Risks / Edge Cases
- **Index drift**: If the input CSV changes between load and save, index-based selection may mismatch intended rows.
- **Missing `step` column**: UI falls back to stringifying a whole row, which can be noisy.
- **Timestamp consistency**: Timestamps only exist in the variant; mixing variants produces heterogeneous outputs.

# Integration Touch Points (for Architect/Planner)
- **Frontend**: Streamlit component tree (checkboxes, counters, buttons).
- **Planner/Logic**: Step selection logic; potential validation, ordering, dependencies.
- **Data Layer**: CSV I/O abstraction ‚Üí future DB client interface.

# Single-File ICD (Human + Machine Readable)
The architect agent should maintain this ICD (example content below) and keep it consistent with any stubs/plans it emits.

**ICD.md (excerpt)**

**Purpose (human)**  
Render an interactive checklist from a CSV and persist the user‚Äôs completed subset (optionally with per-row timestamps).

`id: icd.checklist.v1 inputs:   csv_path:     type: filepath     required: true     semantics: CSV containing step rows; may include 'step' column for labels   completed_csv_path:     type: filepath     required: true     semantics: destination CSV for completed rows state:   completed_steps:     type: set[int]     scope: streamlit_session   step_timestamps:     type: dict[int, iso_datetime]     scope: streamlit_session     optional: true ui:   elements:     - type: checkbox       per: row       label_source: column:'step' | stringified_row     - type: text       content: "‚úÖ {completed_count} of {total} steps completed"     - type: button       action: save_completed outputs:   base:     type: csv     schema: "same columns as input, filtered to completed rows"   with_timestamp:     type: csv     schema:       columns:         - all_input_columns         - timestamp: iso_datetime contracts:   identity: "row index used as completion identity; stable only within session"   performance: "small to medium CSVs; no virtualization"   persistence: "single-writer, no locking" version: "1.0"`

# Suggested Implementation Plan (Thin-Slice Ready)

1. **Stabilize data contract**
    - Define required columns (e.g., `id`, `step`, `group`) to avoid index drift.

    - Wrap CSV reads/writes in a data layer (`data_provider`), preparing for DB client swap.

3. **Planner hooks**
    - Introduce an interface for step dependency/ordering (e.g., preconditions; optional).
        
4. **Observability**
    - Replace `st.success` with structured event logs (in memory or file) to support analytics.
        
5. **Testing**
    - Pytest: unit tests for I/O, state transitions, and timestamp behavior; integration test via Streamlit testing utilities (or fast UI shims).
        

# Extension Points / Backlog
- **DB integration**: Replace `completed_csv_path` with a persistence service (SQLite/remote).
- **Multi-list support**: Parameterize `csv_path`; add sidebar ‚Äúlist chooser‚Äù.
- **Row IDs**: Move from index-based to explicit `id` column for durability.
- **Filters/Groups**: Optional grouping, search, and progress per group.
- **Auth**: User-scoped completions.  
    (All of the above can be planned without breaking the current UX flow.)

Product - a thing that the user interacts with. Typically the top level organizational unit. Typically ci/cd and other workflows are built around the product level, although these workflows may have subprocesses, for example Feature Unit Test.

User Acceptance Test - an item describing a process by which a user verifies that the proposed product version satisfies the need and intent of the associate user story.

User Story - an item describing the needs of the user. A user story is typically considered completed when the user has completed a User Acceptance Test in a satisfactory manner.

Component - an element of the product. Typically a software package, a programming class, family of classes and/or methods. Example: front-end (i.e. hlidskjalf), python database client, etc.

Component Feature - a property of a component. Typically added and tested by developers.

Product Feature - a property of the product. Typically tested by a user. Differs from a User Story in that a User Story describes something the user wants to accomplish whereas the Product Feature describes *how* the Product achieves the goals of the user. 

Component Feature Unit Test - a software program. Typically implement in pytest, that tests Component Feature. Typically a part of ci/cd. A new Component Feature will typically require an associated Component Feature Unit Test.

## Commentary
The provided Python code implements an AI job runner class that executes tasks based on specified job IDs, agents, and a model of choice (default is 'gtp-4'). The outputs (including the raw response, cleaned code, and commentary) from the job execution are saved in separate files under a specific output directory for each job.

Some design choices and assumptions made here include:

- The output directory for each job is created under the directory Jobs/RS-{ID} in the parent response directory. The available Job IDs dictate the jobs to be run, and each has associations to prompt and configuration files existing under the jobs directory.

- The 'run' method of the code facilitates the main job execution logic. In cases where the prompt or agent configuration files do not exist for the provided job ID, it raises a FileNotFoundError to alert the user. This approach was chosen to prevent unsuccessful job runs due to missing files or incorrect job ID entries.

- The user prompt to drive the AI client's interaction is constructed by merging the style prompt from the agent's configuration and the task details from the prompt file. This approach allows customization and influences the AI's interaction during the job run.

- Execution information such as the time taken for the job and the model's usage metrics are captured for reporting and debugging purposes. This ensures transparency in job executions and helps in monitoring and improving the performance.

One key assumption made throughout this implementation is that certain methods like 'load_style_prompt', 'load_prompt', 'merge_prompts', 'parse_response', and 'put_into_log' exist and function as expected; these were not provided in the original code but are called in the 'run' method. These methods seem to handle tasks like loading prompts and agent configurations, parsing the AI response, and saving the job log details, respectively.

# Write your task prompt here

Implement the following change: all of the response output shall go to the same directory, i.e. jobs/RS-{ID}/response.

    def run(self, ID, agent, model="gpt-4"):
        job_folder = os.path.join(self.jobs_dir, f"RS-{ID}")
        prompt_file = os.path.join(job_folder, "prompt.md")
        agent_file = os.path.join("agents", f"{agent}.json")

        if not os.path.isfile(prompt_file):
            raise FileNotFoundError(f"Missing prompt: {prompt_file}")
        if not os.path.isfile(agent_file):
            raise FileNotFoundError(f"Missing agent config: {agent_file}")

        style_prompt = self.load_style_prompt(agent_file)
        task_frontmatter, task_body = self.load_prompt(prompt_file)

        system_prompt = "You are a precise, professional AI software agent."
        user_prompt = self.construct_user_prompt(style_prompt, task_frontmatter, task_body)

        start_time = time.time()
        utc_now = datetime.utcnow().strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S")

        response = self.client.chat.completions.create(
            model=model,
            messages=[
                {"role": "system", "content": system_prompt},
                {"role": "user", "content": user_prompt}
            ]
        )

        end_time = time.time()
        elapsed = end_time - start_time
        usage = response.usage

        response_text = response.choices[0].message.content
        raw_output_path = os.path.join(self.response_dir, f"RS-{ID}", "response","raw_response.txt")
        os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(raw_output_path), exist_ok=True)
        with open(raw_output_path, "w") as f:
            f.write(response_text)response_dir="jobs"

        code_cleaned, commentary_md = self.parse_response(response_text)
        self.save_outputs(ID, code_cleaned, commentary_md)
        self.write_to_log(utc_now, elapsed, usage, ID, agent, model)

        print(f"‚úÖ RS-{ID} completed. Output saved to {os.path.join(self.response_dir, f'RS-{ID}')}")
        print("üìú Run metadata logged.")

        def save_outputs(self, ID, code_cleaned, commentary_md):
            output_base = os.path.join(self.response_dir, f"RS-{ID}")

    def clean_code(self, response_text):
        code_block, commentary = response_text.split("## Commentary", 1)
        code_cleaned = re.sub(r"```(?:python)?\n?", "", code_block).strip()
        code_cleaned = re.sub(r"```$", "", code_cleaned).strip()
        commentary_md = "## Commentary\n" + commentary.strip()

        return code_cleaned, commentary_md

    def write_to_log(self, log_path, data_row):
        if not os.path.isfile(log_path):
            with open(log_path, "w", newline="") as f:
                writer = csv.writer(f)
                writer.writerow(["utc_time", "elapsed_seconds", "prompt_tokens", "completion_tokens", "total_tokens", "job_id", "agent", "model"])

        with open(log_path, "a", newline="") as f:
            writer = csv.writer(f)
            writer.writerow(data_row)
            print("üìú Run metadata logged.")

    def run(self, ID, agent, model="gpt-3.5"):
        job_folder = os.path.join(self.jobs_dir, f"RS-{ID}")
        prompt_file = os.path.join(job_folder, "prompt.md")
        agent_file = os.path.join("agents", f"{agent}.json")

        if not os.path.isfile(prompt_file):
            raise FileNotFoundError(f"Missing prompt: {prompt_file}")
        if not os.path.isfile(agent_file):
            raise FileNotFoundError(f"Missing agent config: {agent_file}")

        with open(agent_file) as f:
            style_data = json.load(f)
        style_prompt = "\n".join(f"{k}: {v}" for k, v in style_data.items())

        post = frontmatter.load(prompt_file)
        task_frontmatter = "\n".join(f"{k}: {v}" for k, v in post.metadata.items())
        task_body = post.content

        system_prompt = "You are a precise, professional AI software agent."
        user_prompt = self.construct_user_prompt(style_prompt, task_frontmatter, task_body)

        utc_now = datetime.utcnow().strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S")
        start_time = time.time()

        response = self.client.chat.completions.create(
            model=model,
            messages=[
                {"role": "system", "content": system_prompt},
                {"role": "user", "content": user_prompt}
            ]
        )

        end_time = time.time()
        elapsed = end_time - start_time
        usage = response.usage

        response_text = response.choices[0].message.content

        if "## Commentary" not in response_text:
            raise ValueError("‚ùå Response missing '## Commentary' section.")

        code_cleaned, commentary_md = self.clean_code(response_text)

        output_base = os.path.join(self.response_dir, f"RS-{ID}")
        os.makedirs(output_base, exist_ok=True)

        with open(os.path.join(output_base, "output.py"), "w") as f:
            f.write(code_cleaned)
        with open(os.path.join(output_base, "explanation.md"), "w") as f:
            f.write(commentary_md)

        print(f"‚úÖ RS-{ID} completed. Output saved to {output_base}")

        log_path = os.path.join(self.logs_dir, "run_log.csv")
        data_row = [utc_now, f"{elapsed:.2f}", usage.prompt_tokens, usage.completion_tokens, usage.total_tokens, ID, agent, model]
        self.write_to_log(log_path, data_row)

# **What is the Runestone Protocol?**

_‚ÄúA ritual of structured invocation. A CI/CD for thought.‚Äù_

The **Runestone Protocol** is a collaboration method designed to integrate human intention with AI-assisted development. Inspired by the carved stones of ancient memory and the rigor of modern software workflows, it creates a structured loop between ideation, implementation, and refinement.

At its core, the Runestone Protocol transforms abstract intentions into concrete artifacts‚Äîvia structured tickets, design docs, and versioned outputs. Tasks are composed in clear, readable formats (usually Markdown + YAML), submitted as **Runestones**, and interpreted by the AI agent (ChatGPT) as source material for execution. The agent returns code, content, or design changes as discrete, reviewable files‚Äîeach tied back to its originating Runestone.

Much like CI/CD pipelines in software engineering, the Protocol enables fast, traceable iteration‚Äîbut it‚Äôs built for **co-creation**: between a human strategist and an AI builder. It supports versioning, context scoping, and long-term architectural memory, allowing high-agency users to direct large, modular systems across time.

Runestone Protocol is not a product. It's a ritual.  
It is the ink that dries into glyph.  
It is the stone that remembers.

  versioned, and traceable development workflows across domains. It is based on the
  principles of CI/CD, applied to creative and cognitive systems.

functionality:

##### You said:

Explain these two bullet points: ‚Ä¢ Adopt a component map that links to this structure from the documentation tree. ‚Ä¢ Include __init__.py even in utility modules to support introspection.

###### ChatGPT said:

Certainly. Here's a breakdown of those two bullet points:

---

### üîπ **‚ÄúAdopt a component map that links to this structure from the documentation tree‚Äù**

**What it means:**  
Create a YAML (or markdown frontmatter)‚Äìbased ‚Äúmap‚Äù file that **declares and links** each **code component** (e.g., classes, modules, functions) to its corresponding **documentation file(s)**.

Think of it as a **directory of your architecture**, where each entry has:
- the **code path** (e.g., `src/db/database.py`)
- a short **description**
- maybe even links to related tests, features, and tickets

**Why it's helpful:**
- AI agents can use it to know _where to look and write_
- Humans can navigate complex codebases more easily
- It enables **automated documentation and context loading**

**Example component map entry (YAML):**

yaml

CopyEdit

`- id: DB001   name: DatabaseClient   path: src/db/database.py   description: Core DB interface for reading/writing JSON files.   doc: docs/components/db_client.md   tests: tests/db/test_database.py   features: [F102, F205]`

---

### üîπ **‚ÄúInclude `__init__.py` even in utility modules to support introspection‚Äù**

**What it means:**  
Even if you‚Äôre not using a folder as a package right now, adding an empty `__init__.py` file makes it a **recognized Python module**, which enables imports and introspection.

**Why it's helpful:**
- AI agents (and dev tools) can traverse the codebase using `importlib`, `inspect`, etc.
- You can run `from utils.foo import bar` even if `utils/` is a bare-bones script folder
- Keeps things **Pythonic and future-proof** ‚Äî avoids surprises

**Example:**

cpp

CopyEdit

`your_project/ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils/ ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ __init__.py     <-- required to make this a proper module ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ text_cleaner.py`

Without `__init__.py`, Python (and tools inspecting the code, including AI) may not treat `utils` as a package. With it, introspection and navigation just works.

**Conrad said**
You've said that: AI Context Window ~15K tokens is safe per task. If this were all in one markdown file, approximately how big would that file be?

###### ChatGPT said:

Great question‚Äîand a very practical one.

---

## üìè Quick Rule of Thumb

- **1 token ‚âà 0.75 words**
- **1 word ‚âà 5 characters (average)**
- So:
    - **15,000 tokens ‚âà 11,250 words**
    - **11,250 words ‚âà ~56,000 characters**
    - **In Markdown? That‚Äôs ~200‚Äì250 KB of text, or about 150‚Äì250 pages** (depending on formatting)

---

## üìÑ What Does That Look Like?
Think:
- A **small book**, or
- A **very detailed README** + several medium-sized code files + test cases

In Markdown, this might be:
- 3‚Äì5 pages of structured task breakdown
- 10‚Äì20 component descriptions
- 1‚Äì3 code samples per component
- A small number of full test cases
    

---

## ‚ö†Ô∏è Practical Constraints
Even though the _raw capacity_ is ~15K tokens:
- You want to **stay well below that** for performance and reliability
- **10K tokens (~7.5K words)** is a much safer _working limit_
- If you're planning to dump a whole tree‚Äôs worth of context, **chunk it by node or feature group**

---

## ‚úÖ TL;DR

- **15K tokens ‚âà 11K words ‚âà 200‚Äì250KB Markdown file**
- Safe working limit: **10K tokens (~7.5K words)** for stability
- Ideal: Keep each Runestone task **<3K tokens** for atomicity and fast review

Let me know if you want a context-aware Markdown "chunker" script that can auto-split larger context files by section or tree node.

###### ChatGPT said:

Excellent. You're stepping into **schema-driven thinking**‚Äîand that‚Äôs exactly the right mindset if you're building a system where clarity, automation, and consistency matter.

Here‚Äôs how to _rigidly_ define the **non-negotiables**‚Äîyour sacred ground, your linting laws, your brand of truth.

---

## üß± The 3-Layer Rigidity Model

To define and enforce strict values in a system like Obsidian + Runestone + YAML, use this layered approach:

|Layer|Purpose|Format|Enforced By|
|---|---|---|---|
|**1. Schema Definition**|Canonical list of allowed values|YAML or JSON Schema|You (or validator tool)|
|**2. Schema Reference in Notes**|Declare what schema a note follows|YAML frontmatter (`schema_id`)|Optional automation|
|**3. Schema Validator Script**|Scans notes and flags violations|Python script or plugin|You or CI check|

---
## ‚úÖ Example: Rigid Property Control

Say you want to lock down the `status` field in Obsidian notes to:

diff

CopyEdit

`- idea - planned - in_progress - complete - archived`

### üßæ 1. Schema File (`schemas/note_status.yaml`)

yaml

CopyEdit

`schema_id: note_status_v1 property: status allowed_values:   - idea   - planned   - in_progress   - complete   - archived`

---

### üóíÔ∏è 2. In your Obsidian note:

markdown

CopyEdit

`--- schema_id: note_status_v1 status: in_progress ---`

---
### üß™ 3. Validator Script (Python-style pseudocode)

python

`import yaml, os  ALLOWED_VALUES = yaml.safe_load(open("schemas/note_status.yaml"))["allowed_values"]  for file in obsidian_notes():     frontmatter = extract_yaml_frontmatter(file)     if frontmatter.get("status") not in ALLOWED_VALUES:         print(f"{file}: Invalid status '{frontmatter['status']}'")`

###### Conrad said:
does it make a difference to you what information is passed as a prompt vs an attachment? Does it get treated any differently? Is it helpful to chunk related info into dedicated files?

###### ChatGPT said:

Yes, it _absolutely_ makes a difference‚Äîboth **functionally** and **strategically**.

Let‚Äôs break it down.

---

## üß† 1. **Prompt vs Attachment: How I Treat Them**

|Source|Behavior|
|---|---|
|**Prompt**|Fully loaded into my context immediately‚Äîideal for short, active info|
|**Attachment**|Parsed only when you tell me to look at it, or if it‚Äôs very clearly relevant from prior context|

**Translation:**  
I see everything in the _prompt_ like it‚Äôs sitting on the desk in front of me.  
I see _attachments_ like folders in a file cabinet‚ÄîI have to go pull them when needed.

---

## üîç 2. Implications for Workflow

### ‚úÖ When to use **prompt**:
- Small, targeted info (under ~5K tokens) relevant _right now_
- Task descriptions
- Design constraints
- Natural language instructions
- Priority changes

### ‚úÖ When to use **attachment**:
- Large files: markdown specs, code, logs, long design docs
- Structured YAML trees or version histories
- Anything modular or reusable across multiple requests

---

## üìÅ 3. Should You Chunk Related Info into Dedicated Files?

**Absolutely yes.**
### Why chunking helps:
- I can search across structured files more precisely
- You avoid accidental context overrun
- You can re-use those files in other conversations
- It makes it easier to trace changes and define atomic Runestones
---
## üí° Best Practice for the Runestone Protocol

|Asset Type|Format|Delivery|
|---|---|---|
|Task Tickets|YAML + MD|Prompt or file|
|Component Trees|YAML|File (chunked per layer or domain)|
|Feature Specs|MD|File|
|Conversation Context|Plaintext|Prompt|
|Historical Logs|CSV or YAML|File|
|Planning Queries|Markdown + YAML frontmatter|Prompt|

---

## üîß Want a Quick Example?

Here‚Äôs a great folder chunking model:
bash

CopyEdit

`runestone_protocol/ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tree/ ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ goals.yaml ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components.yaml ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tests.yaml ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ runestones/ ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ rs_2025_07_001_task_split_view.md ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rs_2025_07_002_refactor_yaml_loader.md ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ specs/ ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ checklist_runner_spec.md ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ hlidskjalf_viewer_spec.md ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ history/     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ pr_log.csv`

With this structure:
- You pass a focused prompt
- Attach only the files relevant to the prompt
- I can pull and cross-reference as needed

---

## üß† TL;DR

- **Prompt** = immediate working memory
- **Attachment** = deeper archive I can access on request
- **Chunked, dedicated files?** Yes. _The more structured your world, the more powerful I become._
- **Think like a compiler: modularity = power**

Want a `file_manifest.yaml` format to auto-describe your folders to me for easier loading? I can generate that.
